column10: most underrated game ever

TLDR: This game was one of my favorite games I've played. 

I suffer from CPTSD. Trauma is intertwined in every aspect of my life. I've been working really hard to improve my life and integrate my trauma, and this game has become a step in that journey. 

Six months ago, I was emotionless, going through life in a state of constant dissociation. I couldn't cry, couldn't get angry, couldn't feel joy. As I've gone through therapy, my emotions have slowly begun to come back to me. I realized this when I took the first character to the Everdoor. My eyes welled up with tears. I was actually feeling things. Emotion!! 

This game is an utter masterpiece. It weaves complicated themes of trauma and loss and betrayal so well into the story line and characters. The gameplay is simple yet satisfying. The amount of hours it takes to complete the story is just the right amount; not too much to which you get tired of the repetitive gameplay, and not too little where you wish you had more. Each character is unique and feels whole, not like a trope. The dialogue is engaging. The loading screens don't take too long. The music draws you in and helps to bring out those emotions deep within you. It's a masterpiece of a game. I doubt I will find another as good for a long time.

I got so bored because there are so many little roadblocks that become tedious. You can't go there unless you get this upgrade. You can't get this upgrade unless you get these 3 resources. You can't get 1/3 of those resources without THESE OTHER 3 resources, all while performing the same mini-games for base maintenance over and over and over again... it's absolutely exhausting. I could feel my love for the game drain out of me like a small hole leaking air out of a big balloon.

I want to finish because it has great art style, characters, cute as heck, plenty of good story elements and I think it's overall a good game.

It was fun while it lasted, but it's just not worth the effort anymore.
Beautifully drawn and animated. A great challenge. Lovely storylines and that are heartfelt and feel real. Would definitely recommend this game.

I'll be honest - I'm not a very emotional guy, quite the opposite. It's hard for me to express my emotions IRL, and I'm a very reserved and guarded person. That being said, this game brought me to tears several times, and I don't remember when a game had such an effect on me.

It's been a wild ride, and my only regret is not playing Spiritfarer earlier. If you're unsure if you want to buy this game and you like character-centered, emotional games, get it ASAP. Don't miss your chance to go on one of the most memorable videogame journeys out there. But be ready to shed a lot of tears along the way.

When I got the game, I completely thought this was going to be a #CozyGame where I got to build a cute little ship with my cute little cat and make cute little friends. I got so much more than that. The narrative is amazing, and there have been times where I've literally *cried* playing this game because of it. Everyone has their own hug animations, and getting to know them is always so much fun. You meet the spirits of friends, family, war heroes, elders with memory problems (which really hit me hard, considering my own family), adults, and even a child.

I love this game and sure, there might be a few cons (like having to go back and forth to specific islands multiple times, and the frequency of mini-games that I just sometimes don't want to deal with, I still don't know how to meditate even though that's something one of your first passengers show you how to do), but overall it doesn't seem like any of those cons matter or get in the way of the game. I am the Ferryman, and it's the best experience I've had in a game like this ever.

Having heard so many positive things about this game, I'd say I got what I was expecting. A lot of it is genuinely beautiful and heartfelt, and had me sobbing my eyes out. The gameplay loop is satisfying, the platforming tight and the characters fun.

That holds true for the first 30 or so hours. After that, the quality didn't just fall off a cliff. It jumped into a deep sea trench. Suddenly there was no reason to try anymore. I had more money than I could ever spend, more resources than I could ever use, and my boat was populated by spirits who I couldn't care less about. There was a wonderful whimsy about the world before, now it just feels like trudging through tar.

The breaking point was Elena, a pretentious, prideful, stuck up bitch who, after you're nearly done with the game, walks up and decides she has to tell you how horribly you've been playing and how wrong you are. The fact that after you do her arbitrary tasks, gathering resources you have NO USE for at this point. And then she tells you to gather treasures that link to the past of your character, Stella, that are linked to people you've NEVER HEARD OF and treating them like losing one would be a massive toll on you.... I can't.

My interest with this game peaked with Alice, who I love very much. But after Beverly showed up, who is basically a diet version of Alice, and then Atul's ending.. this game lost all the respect I had for it.

Up to that point, even with Astrid's and Giovanni's storylines which I really didn't like, I considered this game an 8/10. With Elena, Beverly, and especially Atul's stories, that brought it down to 6/10. It's carried hard by it's early game and gameplay loop. But after that, there's no point to keep going on. I don't know what happened with the writing team, but it stinks of bad blood of some sort.

The most impactful game I have ever played.

I would recommend everyone play this game, regardless of the type of games they usually play. The core gameplay loop (the cozy) of gathering resources, crafting, and completing quests is fun and well understood (even if the location is unusual). It stands out for the characters, world building, meticulous detail, and the unique premise it is built on (the dying).

Reviewing other people's opinions, many found that their foundational views on life where impacted by this game. And I can absolutely see why. Beyond the cute, vector art style are stories based on real, hard, life challenges, told with empathy, care, and a sprinkling of subtext. After playing it, I have a lot to reconsider.

That is not to say the game does not have flaws.
- The characters will hilariously get stuck rapidly pacing on ladders or in buildings (although bugs are extremely rare).
- Being mostly open-world does mean it is difficult to know where to go to complete quests (especially when people are mentioned and not locations), and you often need to talk with very similar appearing people (who sometimes have a lot to say). Thankfully, there is a very thoughtfully made wiki to help if you get stuck.
- And, being open-world, you can do quests out of order where you will miss dialog or even events near the end of the game (although it is unlikely to impact your overall enjoyment).
- I also made the mistake of not bringing the remaining spirits to the Everdoor after the final spirit, ||Setlla and Daffodil||, asked to be brought to the Everdoor, thinking it would end the game when the boat is activated, leading to a build-up of extreme sadness.
Overall, very very minor flaws.

This is a emotionally charged game that really pulls the heartstrings. If for any reason you have trouble with emotional stuff or have something in your life you aren't ready to tackle I would suggest watching Youtube clips or something to see if you are emotionally ready to play this. I notice a lot of negative reviews tended to lean into the fact that this is an emotionally turbulent game that can exasperate pain of loss, or something similar, so just keep that in mind. I personally absolutely loved this game and while I do not express emotions in everyday life well I was on a roller coaster of sadness yet peace the entire game. That in its own way was very helpful to me in letting out some emotions I was unconsciously holding onto. 
With this game comes a sense of understanding, if you are open to it, on how life and people within it don't just leave us after their passing as the memory of them stays. Someone else put it well when they said this is Stardew Valley except its on a boat and everyone you meet, feed, house, love are people you've met throughout your life and who you will eventually help pass over.

You may find you get annoyed with the amount of time it takes to get around, earn enough money, and find people at first but once you get in the groove of things it becomes more about the story line with the activities a sort of add on. I also find it really fun to do the activities the spirits have while they are still with you as it just feels in a way a type of bonding moment, whereas after they've gone it kinda just become tedious. Most of the characters I felt connected to, which doesn't tend to happen for me with games. On top of that some of theses characters had characteristics that I had previously thought annoying, crass, thoughtless, and down right not what a good person would have. Yet, here I was connecting with them and their story line in a way I had not expected to. It gave me a real aha moment that has stuck with me and made me a better person in the real world. 

Anyway, all the characters have pretty well created backgrounds, the visuals of the game are fantastic, the little side quests and activities are fun, and the main character's life is told in a way that doesn't overpower anything else yet is told clearly and skillfully. At this point all I'd say to a new comer is let yourself be immersed in the story, keep an open mind to all the spirits and their personality traits, and just let the game lead you. 

Overall, I found it cathartic to say the least. With every hardship you hit with character's backgrounds as well as your send off of them you find peace knowing they are going to the Everdoor ready, with no unhappy ties or unwanted feelings from their life holding them back. 

SIDE NOTE:

I really hope this developer makes another game like this one with more and new characters, a new protagonist, more interactions with the spirits themselves, a bit more push to find certain information out (like the favorite dish idea in this one) before sending them off, and maybe a different environment. Though I love the boat idea so I'd be interested in seeing different island environments instead of a completely different world. Someone else discussed a train world which would also be amazing!
In the end I have to say this is my favorite game and hope to see similar ones with similar art styles come out tackling emotions people tend to avoid or have trouble processing. And then having cameos of characters of the first cropping up (I.e. Buck, Susan, maybe even the spirit constellations) would be interesting. Even starting the new story using this spiritfarer's story as a entrance would be really fun and would definitely entice me pretty quickly.

Spiritfarer is Stardew valley on a boat, except all your townsfolk are going to die and you have to care for them before they pass.

The first bit of the game is a long tutorial. Collecting resources is tedious, boating around takes days, everything is expensive, quests are all over the place, and I kept hitting physical roadblocks on the world map.

But then, my fishing pole got upgraded, fast travel to checkpoints became available, an antique dealer bought all my junk for thousands of the in-game currency, and I took my first passenger, Gwen, to the Everdoor. It was very emotional, like I was saying my goodbyes to a loved one, because canonically I was, Gwen is the lifelong best friend of Stella, the player character. I then realized, all my passengers who I feed, talk to, hug, house, do events with, and help cope with the end of their days... are going to die... Really die... They will want to enter the great Everdoor and pass from the spirit realm, from my ferry, from the home I built them, into the afterlife.

I feel like a nurse giving end of life care to those on their deathbed. It is taxing, but I feel good. I am making them better, I am getting them ready.

10/10, would cry again.

Spiritfarer has become one of my all-time favorite games. The themes it explores, and the way it presents characters and problems before you is so beautifully done.

I do personally believe in spirits and a life after passing, so some may say I'm biased in my opinion of this game. But even putting that aside, the depth of care put into each spirit you take care of is so intense that they feel real and believable. It's truly hard to put into words.

When I say other games haven't made me cry, I mean it. I've teared up before, but this game gave me a full cry session. I'll talk about specifics at the end of the review.

In terms of gameplay, the only complaint I could have is trying to get back into it after not playing for a while. There's a lot to remember, and it's very easy to get lost in that situation. But otherwise, the gameplay loop keeps you engaged and busy, and I rarely remember having moments where I thought "I don't have anything to do"
Movement is extremely satisfying, and not complicated. It's super fun just moving around your ship, and building it in a way that compliments it.
I won't bring up specifics due to spoilers, but certain events that happen throughout the game (The ones you do to get materials throughout the ocean) are so enticing and have so much good energy to them. I never thought "Ugh, I have to go get this material" It was always "Ooh, I get to do this again!!" and that's such a good feeling. I can admit that I was never bored playing this game.

****SPOILER FOR THE GAME****
-The moment I cried-

[spoiler] The moment that made me truly cry was when I brought Bruce & Mickey, a pair that I wasn't able to relate to from my real life experiences, to the Everdoor. From the start, I didn't think I'd like them at all. But as I learned more about them, I realized why Bruce seems like such a 'bully'. Throughout his time on your boat, he talks of how him and Mickey ran things on the street. How Bruce always looked up to Mickey and practically built his life around him. And having grown up in a life where it seems like everything is against you, Mickey was the one good thing Bruce had. While Bruce does lash out at others, comes off as a jerk, and really doesn't know how to handle other people, he still knows how to love, he just doesn't know how to properly express it. On his way to the Everdoor, he says "...The only thing I'd rather be is true to myself. That might make me an asshole in the end. That might make me a loyal brother to this man here. None of this shit matters. None of it." He knows how he comes off, but it's the only way he knows how to act. It's how he shows his love to his brother Mickey, and he never grew out of it. A kid that never got to truly grow up. He then mentions "More importantly, I can't see a life beyond my brother. If he goes, I go. ... Funny thing is... He went a long time ago. I just didn't want to admit it to myself." Throughout his time on the boat, Mickey never really was 'there'. Bruce just couldn't let go of him, and became a literal weight that he carried even into the afterlife. That hit.. hard. Had Bruce been shown compassion outside his brother and family, he could have led a more positive life. A laid-back, humongous, well-beloved game that's easy to pick up, and very tough to put down again.

Pros:
* Exploration EXTRAVAGANZA.
* Passengers are (w/ a few exceptions) very well-written, relatable NPCs.
* Beautiful music and artwork.
* Tons and tons of minigames.
* You really, really don't want to let some passengers go... but forcing them to stay feels like torturing them.  (listed as a "pro", as this is [u]excellent[/u] character writing)
* One passenger, Stanley... OMG, fav NPC so far this year.

Cons:
* Only had one bug, and relaunching the minigame made it go away.
* One minigame... pulsar...shower(?)...  Pulsar something, anyways.  OMG, shoot me now.  Way too tough w/o upgraded abilities.
* One of the last passengers is really, really hard to please - kiss goodbye to the "Really pleased all passengers" (not its name) achievement if you've released too many passengers w/ passive crowd-pleasing bonuses.

Meh:
* Really, really addictive - we're talking repeated "juuust 10 more minutes" addictive, at 4am.
* Auto-switching from harvesting to planting takes way too long IMO.  Only ~1 sec, but it constantly throws me off.
* Two achievements are exclusively paired - at about 1/2-way in.  Meaning you can't get all achievements in one run w/o manually caching your savegames.

For folks w/ disabilities:
* Some of the "collect rare resource" minigames require nimble fingers or judicious planning and construction of your boat's infrastructure to help you.  You can repeat any of 'em, just not right away, and there's no penalty for taking your time in this game.
* That hard-to-please passenger has several timed challenges before you can resolve her - you may want to ignore her, and lose out on a cpl achievements.

TL;DR: If you like exploration and story, 8/10; else, skip.

Spiritfarer is a captivating and emotionally poignant game that explores themes of life, loss, and the beauty of letting go. With its stunning hand-drawn visuals, heartfelt storytelling, and unique gameplay mechanics, Spiritfarer offers a deeply touching and introspective experience.

Visually, Spiritfarer is a feast for the eyes. The hand-drawn art style is enchanting, creating a whimsical and ethereal world filled with vibrant colors and charming character designs. Each location is beautifully crafted, from lush forests to serene sea vistas, and every frame exudes a sense of warmth and serenity. The attention to detail in the animations and environments is remarkable, breathing life into the game's richly imaginative setting.

At the core of Spiritfarer is its poignant and heartfelt storytelling. Players assume the role of Stella, a Spiritfarer tasked with guiding spirits to the afterlife. As you sail through mystical waters, you encounter a diverse cast of endearing spirits, each with their own unique story and emotional journey. The game delicately explores themes of mortality, acceptance, and the importance of cherishing relationships. The writing is beautifully crafted, evoking a range of emotions from joy to sorrow, and leaving a lasting impact on players.

Gameplay in Spiritfarer revolves around managing your ship, exploring various islands, and tending to the needs of the spirits under your care. As a Spiritfarer, you build and customize your vessel, cultivate resources, cook delicious meals, and engage in heartfelt conversations with the spirits. The gameplay mechanics are intuitive and complement the game's themes seamlessly. Whether it's fishing, farming, or engaging in meaningful conversations, each activity is purposeful and contributes to the overall narrative and character development.

One of the standout features of Spiritfarer is the sense of serenity and tranquility it evokes. The game's calming soundtrack, melodic tunes, and soothing sound effects create an atmosphere of introspection and peace. Sailing through the vast ocean, accompanied by gentle waves and the soft hum of the ship, instills a sense of mindfulness and contemplation. Spiritfarer encourages players to slow down, reflect, and appreciate the beauty of life's fleeting moments.

Spiritfarer's replayability is another strong aspect. The game offers a wealth of optional activities, side quests, and hidden discoveries, ensuring that each playthrough can be a unique and personal experience. Additionally, the relationships you build with the spirits are shaped by your choices and interactions, providing multiple narrative branches and outcomes. The depth and nuance of the characters make revisiting the game a rewarding endeavor, as you uncover new layers of their stories and forge deeper connections.

In conclusion, Spiritfarer is a beautiful game that delves into profound themes of life, death, and the human experience. With its stunning art style, poignant storytelling, and serene gameplay, it delivers an emotionally resonant journey that will leave a lasting impression. Spiritfarer reminds us of the importance of embracing life's fleeting moments, cherishing relationships, and finding solace in letting go. It is an extraordinary experience that will touch the hearts of players and offer solace in times of reflection.

TLDR; you will cry.
In all seriousness, Spiritfarer is a truly heartfelt story (several ones actually) about death. I cannot say for sure that this game will or will not help you deal with loss and grief, or fear of death, that is in the end a very personal experience. I will say however that if a piece of media were to deal with this subject matter, I cannot imagine someone doing it better.

As a game, it has aspects of platforming and base building, but these are just there to support the narratives, to get you more invested in the characters. And you will be invested, as their stories are more realistic than what you'd expect from such playful designs, and I'm sure a lot of people will relate with them through personal experience.

I wholeheartedly recommend trying this out, if you want an experience of the emotional depth that games can offer.

Death is a theme that is particularly prevalent in video games, because it is an essential part of how games work and create challenge. And in most games, death is never seen as strictly a positive outcome. Some games encourage you to keep trying, because death is rarely permanent in video games. Other games are simply torture devices created to psychologically torment the player (*cough* Jump King *cough*). In any case, you will have to keep dying and trying until you succeed in whatever you need to accomplish in that game. Many variations have been created around this concept of death, but very few games have managed to twist this concept in an unique way that is different and feels fresh. 

Spiritfarer is, without a doubt, one of those games. 

Similarly to other games, you kill people in this game as the main character of said game. However, the big twist is that, at least for most of these characters, it is because they directly request that you to take them to the Everdoor (this game's concept of the door to the afterlife). And they do not do this from the get-go, because the player first needs to help them to take that step and run errands for them. It is therefore really ironic that Stella, the most kindhearted person I have played in a game, has to be the one to help them to die and play "the reaper".

Is this game perfect? No, absolutely not. Not all "management mini-games" are fun, nor do I resonate with all characters nor do I think that it is perfectly paced. It became tedious at moments, I traveled many times to the same places, etc.

HOWEVER ,

I have rarely seen such a large amount of quality for a game with such a beautiful and unique vision ; gameplay, progression, character/world building, character development/story, art style and music are all stella(r) imo. 

MAN . . . . . . . . . . , what a masterpiece.



Also, on a more personal note, it helped me grief the death of my grandparents, even if this occurred quite some time ago. Sadly, my own grandfather and grandmother did not have such a peaceful passing compared to characters like Alice and/or Beverly. I hope they now have found their peace, wherever they may be.

Spiritfarer is a fantastic game, not least because it's not like anything else I've played. It's somehow both a practical archetype of the leisurely cozy game and emotionally devastating. The characters are always interesting, the art style is beautiful, the music is powerful, and the gameplay is memorable.

Having said all that, there are a few things it could have done better:

There are some surprising quality of life features absent from the game. The most obvious is that there is no quick way to process multiple materials. For instance, if you want to convert logs into planks you have to press the enter key for each log. You can't just hold down the key to keep adding, and you certainly can't type it in. This is fine for small batches but obnoxious if you're processing 50 things or more. I also would have liked some easy way to keep track of things you're cooking/growing. I was always worried about food burning (I didn't realize it could cook for 36 hours!!) so I sometimes found myself leaving a place early to check on it, etc.

Although the characters themselves are well-developed and interesting, it's a little disappointing how they rarely interact or even generally acknowledge one another (outside of Astrid and Giovanni, anyway). Maybe this is partly by design, given what we learn by the end, but given that the characters are actually supposed to be interacting with each other (their mood meters will often mention one another, and there are occasionally "group" events), it feels like a bit of a missed opportunity for some interesting dialogue and interactions.

Another issue is that the game feels too linear, with several points in which there is only one way in which to proceed. For instance there is a general order in which spirits need to be sent through the Everdoor, especially towards the beginning  of the game. There are also no real choices in the game that have any significant bearing. There really isn't any story reason to limit this order, and it can sometimes be frustrating when there is only one way to proceed that you have to discover on your own. I think the biggest reason for this was just that it prevented players from jumping too far into the endgame too quickly and while I think that is important to do, with some more work it could have done in a way that better preserved player choice.

This is definitely the type of game that's meant to be watched rather than played - video games as an art form, in a sense. The story, characters and art direction is what ultimately kept me coming back to this game, rather than the gameplay itself. Following on this, the gameplay is frankly one of Spiritfarer's weaker elements. It locks you into a loop of finding a destination, waiting to get to the destination and then running around to gather resources, rinse and repeat, along with occasional sidequests. If you're somebody who values engaging gameplay then I honestly would recommend you steer clear of this.

That being said, I adore basically EVERYTHING else about Spiritfarer. I can look past the honestly sub-par gameplay because I'm just so engrossed in this spectacular world and the lovable characters that inhabit it. All their stories are touching in their own unique ways, to the point where their conclusions made me tear up on multiple occasions. The game boasts a warm, welcoming artstyle that puts me at ease each time I see it, as well as a soundtrack that is no less than PHENOMENAL. 

Spiritfarer is a wonderful experience that will live in my head for many years to come, Maybe the game itself is rather bland and repetitive, but when everything surrounding it is as masterfully executed as it is, I think I can make an exception.

I SOBBED when Alice went through the door, but it helped me process my grief and accept that death is just another part of life. An emotional, yet wonderful journey this game takes you on. When I first started, it had a unique concept that kept me interested. Later the story got much richer and more captivating, and I got to a point where I didn't want to stop playing, and kept on going for hours, each time I played it. You both want to proceed with the story to learn what happens next, but also want to enjoy it and take it all in. 
It has some crafting, some ship design elements on top of the story. At any point, you can choose to chill and relax, look at the stars while fishing, or move on with the story and at times feel happy, at times sad, and sometimes get surprised by the events, or if you are a completionist, you can try to get every chest, fish, cook every recipe, find every island, etc, most of which are achievements on Steam, as well as rewarding in-game.

I wanted desperately to like this game. I had heard so many positive things and I really enjoy games that attempt to craft an interesting narrative experience. In terms of the art, animations, and music, this game is great, and clearly a lot of work was put into those aspects. However, I think this game is just....not that good with its fundamentals.

I won't go into detail about the nature of the story, I'm sure you've seen it on all the other reviews and in the description. The basics are that you are carting a bunch of spirits into the afterlife by completing various fetch quests for them and learning more about who they were in life as you unlock their dialogue, to eventually drop them off to their final resting place.

Seems like a really interesting thematic idea no? And it is! So...what's the problem? Its the gameplay. God, is it the gameplay.

This game is astonishingly boring. It is so, so boring. I don't mind a game that has minimal gameplay, I loved Disco Elysium and other games of it's ilk that are nothing but reading and talking. The problem is, this game is not that. It has gameplay. A LOT of gameplay. It just sucks.

This game will demand that you spend 30 hours of your time running pointless fetch quests, completing brain dead easy jumping puzzles, and doing some of the most pointless resource management that you possibly could imagine. No part of it is fun. I would even go so far as to say it is a grind for some of the later spirits, spending hours of your time running back and forth around your boat cutting logs or farming silkworms to advance the dialogue. It's not even fun in a stardew valley way where you have a constant feeling of building up your farm and making progress. After the tenth or so hour of the game your boat is done being upgraded and you're just darting around it managing resources in an effort to get the goddamn game to advance. 

I really don't even think the writing is that good in this game. It's okay. If this game was about 15 hours shorter it might be something charming, but it massively overstays it's welcome and by the time I reached the ending I was practically cheering when spirits would get off my boat. 

It wasn't for me. Clearly I'm in the minority in this so take my opinion with a grain of salt, but if you're the type of person that gets easily burnt out by endless meaningless fetch quests and starting at the exact same set of four animations on your boat over and over again, it may be worth a miss.

I've tried, many times and many ways, to explain why I like this game so much. I can't. There isn't anything especially unique about the characters, or the story, not even the game play. Yet for some reason, from the second I first set sail, this game had my heart.

Maybe it's the cute graphics. Maybe it's the little cat sidekick you can hug whenever. Could be the little gardens, the ability to cook, fish. Could be the satisfying sound effects and happy little background music. Could even be the way that there is no hurry to get anywhere, no sense of urgency, yet there is always something to do. Busy, but not rushed.

One piece of advice that I do have is that Spiritfarer is more like an interactive story than a traditional simulation/management style game; don't overload yourself in tasks and things to do and just play at a pace comfortable to you! Spiritfarer is a precious game, it offers so much... So many situations, so many things hidden under the hood, just to show you a very well-written story, with a diverse cast of characters (that you will most likely love [spoiler]and miss[/spoiler]), all rounded up in a pretty decent management game with cool exploration.

Thunder Lotus art is now on another level, this puts their previous work to the test and surpasses in every single technical detail. The art is mesmerizing, the style, the designs, the drawings, how well though everything is. It's just too stylish for me to handle, it's awesome.

The writing, I have to talk about that but not much so it won't ruin it for you. The game's writing is sublime, the character motivations, likes/dislikes, mood, activities, quests, it's just grand, and also shocking at some moments.

Now, why did I call it a decent management game? Well, the game has a few shortcoming in the gameplay department. Although all the minigames are fine and the cooking is INCREDIBLE, the late game can be very stressful, where you have to wait for some events to trigger. Of course each player will have a different experience based on which characters they get or not in the boat, but truth is, my experience could have been better. I found the RPG dude waaaay too late, and had to wait for his quests to trigger, like, literally wait... While watching a video or something.

Another issue is that it drags on for too long, although the new characters are awesome, not sure if they didn't hurt the flow of the game, in this case, maybe less was more? I wouldn't sacrifice any of the characters tho, they really are awesome, so... Yea...

Overall, Spiritfarer is awesome, it's a game I will cherish, recommend, and remember for a long time. I already loved Thunder Lotus games, but this is on another level. Thank you for the memories!

Spiritfarer is a beautiful and heartwarming game that explores the themes of death, grief, and letting go. You play as Stella, a ferrymaster to spirits, who travels across a mystical sea with her cat, Daffodil. Along the way, you meet and befriend various spirits, who have their own stories and wishes. You help them by building and customising your boat, crafting, fishing, cooking, farming, and more. The game has stunning hand-drawn art, soothing music, and engaging gameplay. It is a game that will very likely make you laugh, cry, and reflect on your own life and relationships. Spiritfarer is a game that I highly recommend to anyone who loves a good story and a cozy atmosphere. The only aspect that I found challenging was the platforming mini-games, but if you enjoy platforming this won't be an issue.

This is probably one of my favorite games. It's kinda hard to describe why so I'll just separate my points into small parts.

Story
Probably the biggest part of the game. You play as Stella who is the new Spiritfarer and your job is to make the last days of different spirits the best they can be. Every character has it's own story and they often times are linked to other characters. Your end goal is to bring every spirit to the afterlife and it's just the saddest thing. You get really attached to the different characters and it's really painful to see them go but it's kinda the point of the game. They all have their own unique story which I won't go into detail about but you do a lot of quests for them. Each characters have their preferences, for example a character could prefer a certain dish or a type of food. They could hate their loud neighbour or love that you installed a workshop on your boat. You get to learn about them and it just makes it sadder when they go. I'm not gonna say too much because I don't wanna spoil anything, but just trust.

Boat
The boat. THE BOAT. I love the boat. You're on a boat and it's very cozy and you build little houses for the characters which you can upgrade and you build little gardens and a kitchen and it's just so cute.

Gameplay
It's a very relaxed game. It's not grindy like Stardew Valley. Yes you can grow crops but you don't have to grow an industrial amount, like just a few so you can cook a meal for the characters. Resources like iron and coal are also fairly easy to get. Every rock you break gives you a ton of its resources so you don't have to go back constantly to get more. The setting is on a sea with a bunch of islands. You can explore each islands and they all have different things to do. Some of them even have spirits you can rescue. When you accept a spirit on your boat you get an obol which is a currency with which you can buy different new parkour skills. You basically go to a shrine on an island and you buy things like double jump or bounce.

Soundtrack
The soundtrack is just crazy good. I listen to it on my free time and I've even learned some parts of it on the guitar. Every character has their own background music and I think that adds a lot to the game because every time you listen to the soundtrack there are pieces that remind you of the different characters.

Spiritfarer is a beautiful game with lovely characters, whimsical landscapes, simple mechanics but most of all... a storyline that will make you feel bunch of different emotions.

Stella, the protagonist, helps her spirit friends pass into their afterlife thanks to her boat that she upgrades throughout her journey. Each of those spirits have different requests/needs that she attempts to help with. Completing quests/missions allows her to get different parts to be added to her boat, which in turn makes her able to go on more journeys and help her spirit friends better.
There are no failures in this game, as it's not possible to mess up a quest or a craft, which makes it perfect for a non-stressful relaxing cozy game.

This is a game that I recommend for those who love beautiful stories, keeping in mind that it's a game about the afterlife, and thus you might encounter some sadness.

A fun platformer/farm sim with a deep and often sad story woven throughout. 

The story makes you cry. It can touch on very personal moments inside of you, esp if you've experienced loss in your life similar to the characters in the game. But you also get the satisfaction of getting to know the people you'll be mourning.

The farm sim/resource collection game helps take your mind off of the sadness. It's very cute and thankfully there are little minigames to help with the resource processing.

The platforming is fun and fluid, with more abilities unlocking as you progress. I found it very satisfying to cruise around areas in fast and exciting fashion, often going "faster than the camera" which really adds to the illusion of speed.

The writing, outside of the larger story, is delightfully sardonic and had me chuckling at many moments. Many, many NPCs to talk to, both for plot/gameplay purposes as well as just general world flavor.

I logged 50hrs on the game but you don't necessarily need to. Plan in the 10s of hours for sure, but 50 was me trying to do everything. You can do less, still have a heap of bleary-eyed fun, and then go cry with your cat like I did.

Let's get this out of the way...

I'm not finished the game yet but already have so many thoughts. Unfortunately, mostly not living up to the hype. Spiritfarer suffers in both its game play and story telling, which is essentially all it had going for it after its artistic vision.

Originally I was extremely hyped to play because I was expecting a Hades-like amazing mix of fun game play with a highlight of story telling. And the beginning got me hooked. Everything was pretty, the music was amazing, the character designs highly stood out. The beginning felt like a proper story about to unfold. But then-

The game play ended up being a literal chore. Not in the sense of fun - chill - chores that make you strategically think about how you're going to organize your Spiritfarer day to complete some tasks. No you're mostly stuck completely every task one by one which commonly required to go to the opposite side of the map just to grab some ore. Every task is decently frustrating and stays exactly the same the whole time. There's no significant increase in difficulty or change in pace; the formula is always the same. 

Progression is very linear, to the point where you will get stuck just because you lack an ability or a spirit on your chip. It was especially frustrating when I needed an Obol to progress at all, and had to wait multiple days for the spirit I got to finally talk about their quest. There's zero difficulty to this either. Most of the time you will have every resource you need except the time it takes for spirits to talk to you about their quest. So you're stuck doing nothing (for six in game days :) ) just to progress. Just a side note there is no interesting exploration; almost every island feels the same apart from the abilities you can use and resources you can get. 

Secondly, the story telling, or lack there of. The largest issue is the main character has no personality apart from what others say about her. This is because Stella doesn't talk at all, so every interaction with another character is essentially a monologue from them. This leaves very little empathy for Stella or any spirits which ruins my interest for most characters. Most of the game was me trying to get rid of most of the spirits as fast as possible while the ones I liked went too quick. 

I would talk about the overarching story, but within 20 hours it essentially got no progression, so I will have to see once I finish the game.

I do not recommend Spiritfarer if you're looking for a meaningful well written experience or riveting game play. But it's fine for a simple no brain game you don't have to pay attention to.

Overall, 4/10

So, I don't usually write reviews, but Spiritfarer truly deserves it, because it is amazing. If you enjoy cozy games and emotional moments, this game is the one for you. Lots of very cute gameplay, a bit of platforming and some farming and gathering elements and the like, very lovely. It's nice to see old materials becoming important in later crafting again, so props for that. Also, the character designs and animation look absolutely wonderful, and the soundtrack is so fitting and lovely.
But, well, the best part is the characters.
I kid you not, I cried for each and every one of the spirits, even Elena, who I do not particularly like. It's soul-crushing, but also cathartic, really. As cute as the game is, the depth it goes into with the themes of life and death and showing different aspects of it through the different characters is both a marvel and quite dark, so be sure you're up for stuff like talking about death, diseases, hard life situations, etc. I undestand those are not easy topics to deal with, and while this game handles them with respect and dignity, for some, it might be a bit too much.
Still, this was a life-changing experience and I wouldn't change it for the world. 10/10 game, please, buy it. You won't regret it.

Spiritfarer is a great cozy game for those that want a game with a management side to it, and that can take up a lot of hours. The story is charming although very sad, it's all about our mute main protagonist although the way the game sells itself keeps pointing you to the direction of the other characters.
If you're not into loss, depression, grieving themes and dealing with it, then I do not recommend it! For instance, I'm a person that do not come into games to have a catharsis of my emotions, so these games for me are always kind of a pain... I think we already deal with a lot of drama in our own lives!
Now, in terms of gameplay it's very basic and simple: you need to pile up buildings, catch these glittering stars, cook, farm, and especially fetching things for your guests. For me the worse was fishing, the mechanic was a bit hard and stressfull.
I also didn't liked that the protagonist Stella was a mute character, and many times I felt that I was wasting my time talking to NPCs - I mean, sure they give you side quests, but there's just so much clicking and nonsense dialogues with those.
Visually the 2D platform with this cartoonish feeling to it is great, and honestly what made me buy the game.
This game could do better with voice acting added though.
Performance and menu accessibility are also great, lots of languages to chose from, you can change keybinds, I felt though that sometimes certain movements would get cluncky, not responding (I was playing with the controller).
My biggest issue was how the days would pass so fast! I mean, you have no time limit, so it's fine, do not worry. The thing is, I would wake up, just navigate somewhere, and... already night! it disn't left me with a lot of exploring time. But there's no pressure though.

The color can sometimes be hard to see against certain backgrounds. Plus some fish are just really hard to catch, though this is expected. 

Because there are 2 main players, if you're far apart from each other, it can make seeing the screen difficult because it zooms out to fit everything on one screen. Good if you hate split screen. The second player does not have a button to transport them to the first player. All players *must* travel together. I'm playing the main character and personally suck at jumping and double jumping. 

If I install any mods, if will be for perfect fishing and more forgiving double jump timing. I'm a very casual chill gamer, so feats of quick, precise timing aren't really my favorite. I dig the resource management, improvement, puzzles, and storytelling.

Spend hours on the farming, mining, fishing and exploring. In the end though, the activities are just sidequests to the spirits you encounter.

there are a lot of bugs but very few effect gameplay negatively and those that do the devs have answers for in the forum.  characters clipping thru objects or supposedly being asleep but still being found outside of shops when you're at certain cities are present, sometimes quest objectives don't load when you open the quest log, things like that.

[h3] Spiritfarer®: Farewell Edition [/h3] is a game that beautifully encapsulates the themes of life, death, and learning how to say goodbye. It's a journey that takes players through an emotional rollercoaster, allowing them to experience the joy of life, the inevitability of death, and the catharsis of saying goodbye.

[b] Life [/b] in Spiritfarer®: Farewell Edition is represented through the vibrant world that players can explore. The game encourages players to engage with their surroundings, build relationships with spirits, and create memories. It's a celebration of life's simple pleasures, from cooking meals to fishing, and it's a reminder of the importance of cherishing every moment.

[b] Death [/b] in the game is not portrayed as something to fear, but rather as a natural part of life. The spirits that players meet are all at different stages of accepting their mortality. Some are ready to move on, while others need help coming to terms with their situation. This portrayal of death is both sensitive and respectful, and it encourages players to view death not as an end, but as a new beginning.

The theme of [b] learning how to say goodbye [/b] is perhaps the most poignant aspect of Spiritfarer®: Farewell Edition. Players form deep connections with the spirits they meet, making it difficult to let them go. However, the game gently reminds players that saying goodbye is a necessary part of life. It's a lesson in acceptance and letting go, and it's a testament to the game's emotional depth.

In conclusion, Spiritfarer®: Farewell Edition is a philosophical exploration of life, death, and saying goodbye. It's a game that doesn't shy away from these heavy themes, but instead embraces them, creating a unique and heartwarming experience. It's a reminder that life is transient, that death is a part of life, and that saying goodbye, while difficult, is a necessary part of the journey. It's a game that will make you laugh, cry, and most importantly, reflect on the beauty and fragility of life.

It hurts me to put a negative review, it really does, but this game has too many flaws that ruin the experience for me.

First, the good stuff: the art and the music. Can't really say much other than it looks and sounds absolutely gorgeous, the artists clearly put a lot of effort into their game. Each major character has unique, mostly handdrawn sprites than look very good. A lot of the animations use splines to reduce the costs, but I can't say that some of those look really good as they sometimes distort in uncanny ways. Also Stella's hat is a 3D model, which is funny to me.
I do have to note however that this game loooooves to you its animations so much, it also really likes to lock you in place for much longer than necessary to let it play out, which makes repetitive tasks more annoying.
The music is very orchestral and carries a lot of the emotional weight the game can have, it's always pleasant to hang in the starting area just from how serene and pleasant it sounds.

Now, the reason I put a negative review.
Somehow, despite how polished it looks on the graphical and sound side, it looks very rushed and the other parts, being the story and gameplay.
The gameplay is pretty cute at first, but gets very tedious and repetitive as time goes on. Your main form of progression is just getting the resources you need for the next upgrade, but some of those critical resources are locked behind characters that need you to sometimes find a specific spot on the map.
Talking of the map, the boat navigation makes so you'll have to wait very often as the game progresses and the number of passengers shrink, especially when you notice that there's no real advantage to passengers being maxxed out in happiness, their benefits are literally inconsequential and you can just let them starve without much consequences. Also, the more you progress, the more empty and bland they becomes, even the more unique locations like "Sandwich Platform" (or however it's called) have barely anything to them in the latter parts.
The "open world" in this game is also an annoying illusion, the game is pretty linear in how it wants you to progress, so unless you know exactly what you need to do, you'll just be wandering endlessly on uninteresting side quests (which most don't even have reward????!!!), and chest hunting, which rarely have anything interesting when it's not a blueprint.
Lastly.... the minigames....... oh my god are they bad and grueling. I understand what they were going for but... just no, let me craft without having to do annoying maneuvers I beg of you.

The story is also... vague, but not in a way that feels intentional, more like, y'know, rushed and unfocused. Most of the "OG 5" are muuuuch more thought out, once they pass on, you're left with flavorless husks that are just here to pad out the game, and most of their deals are pretty hard to get before they get to the Everdoor, and even then some just make no sense without you looking at the wiki. They even wrote the same character twice....
The DLC part is also, odd. Now, confirm me if this is wrong, but it looks like to me than before this was released in the original version of the game, Stella's story didn't even have a proper ending, just a random cryptic entity spewing nonsense for most of it and pretending it said anything at all.

So you just have to wait for most of it; and once again the story of the two "new" characters are either rushed or nonsensical (mostly due to cryptic flourishes).
I do appreciate the "special" character that appears when enough passengers has passed on however, and it gives a proper conclusion to Stella's story (even if there was very little of it).

So many games are about death as a cursory incident in your grand adventure. It is nice to have a game that wants to take death on as a topic and help us grasp at the terrifying and necessary experience we all must go through. The way that people come into and leave our lives permanently, often without closure. The way you will also be that person for someone else.

In all honesty? This game is not perfect. The game mechanics are sometimes a bit too hard for me since I have to run up and down catching something. The caves really made me mad sometimes because I was not good at using the zip line. Spiritfarer was the first new game I played in my adulthood. I did not grow up with consoles, I did not play anything that would consume my life because I never had proper devices for games. So, you could consider me as a newbie back then, and it was challenging. Of course as time went by and I played more, it became easier, but this was not a game that you would easily recommend to a newbie who probably would love the story so much.

But, regardless of those points, I still love Spiritfarer in its entirety. It really showed me the beauty of indie games, what these small companies can give me in experience that an AAA company probably would struggle. The music is superb, my favourite is actually the Thunder Harvest. Each strike actually makes the already beautiful and powerful piece even more impactful. The art is beautiful and the dedicated hug button? Yeah, that hits hard. The story? I think each of us has our own favourite, mine is unironically Stella's story. I just.. I just feel that her story was relatable. At first I was unhappy that there was no way to personalise the main character, but I got over it quickly as I began to know Stella.

I think one of the best aspects of an indie game is that you get more after purchase service. I love the wallpapers and newsletters, some behind the scenes stories and such. It makes me appreciate the hard work that developers do to make a game. It is always fun to receive a mail from Med at Thunder Lotus. Hi, Med!! :D

[h3]Overall personal score: 5.5/10. It's -barely- a recommend from me.[/h3]

[h3]TL;DR:[/h3] 

"Worst parts of 2D platformer, collection-farm, fishing sim, immersive rpg with sometimes clunky controls and a neutral to sad story. But hey, the music's good, there are cute animal characters, and it's "pretty."

[h3]The Bad:[/h3]
* WAY too many collectables. There's a set to turn on at a 'semi-secret npc' and a set for the wandering merchant you find early on. Both of these "collect-a-thons" are suuuuuuuuuck. There's too many things to find/get/do and it's outright -painful- to complete them. Especially the fish. Could simplify the menu too, lots of same recipe for different ingredients.

* The controls are spotty and some 'power-ups' feel clunky or annoying to use. These two, [spoiler] Gliding [/spoiler] + [spoiler] Zipline [/spoiler] are particularly bad. Sometimes they do not work when pressed or get cancelled by being used too close together. 

* The damn boat speed. Even with max-upgrades, and max size, I never felt like I was getting anywhere quickly, particularly for longer journeys. This still felt way too slow.

* The "warp to zone" mechanic still requires to the zones to use it. There should just be a different mechanic in place, accessible directly from Stella's shack, and not a bus-stop/taxi system.

* Too many materials to grind out/collect just to advance through the game. Literally these could have been cut down by a third, and it would have not influenced the story much, besides getting through the already slow-feeling game faster. I felt like I did a pretty good job at most things, but I will not catch all of the fish, I will not collect all of the figurines, I will not cook all of the dishes, and I won't think I'll go back to finish the remaining 7 achievements I'm missing. It's that grind-y.

* You cannot salvage the "unique" buildings, besides one that was a 'mistake' and went unused. I understand -why- they did this because I've finished the game, but I still hate it. If they wanted the spaces for the ending itself... Why not just have a specialty building instead that you can only build after you've [spoiler]send someone through the Everdoor and gained their flower. (You could even have this change and with more flowers in it the more characters you get sent-off.)[/spoiler] done a requirement for it.

* All of the non-square/weird shaped buildings. This bothered the hell out of me. I have ocd, so that's not necessarily an 'every person' problem, but it was for me. It felt like I was juggling my own brain to ignore the horrible clump of buildings I shoved aside.

* Base story quests will not clear out the fog of war from the entirety of the map. I left literally at least a third of the map undiscovered, and due to the boat-speed I didn't feel the need to explore further either. 

* Timed material gathering 'events' ALL felt annoying to complete (at best.) Because they're all the same with different hit-boxes. Assuming you've managed to build your ship in a way that makes it manoeuvre-able, all of the events will play out and feel the same. Run/hit each 'target' zone, collect drops. I however, had more of an issue not climbing up unnecessary ladders or platforms constantly in the way, thanks to the way the buildings were made and gaps between spaces that were too small for unlock-able traversal props to help.

* Some NPC's you send off are objectively terrible and I felt horrible helping them. I get that there's a broader appeal by having more personality types and/or perhaps it's based off of real people, but I could have honestly left a few of them behind entirely.

* End story is 'complete-able' before you have all the passengers on the boat completed and sent off. I get why they did this, but it's probably something, someone has screwed up. Should not be able to talk to [spoiler]Lily[/spoiler] that quickly as it spoils some character information that you might not have had figured out yet. It just felt out of place for me.

* [spoiler]Daria's flower really should have a quest attached for where it is post going through the Everdoor.[/spoiler] Had it not been me looking up a different quest entirely, I wouldn't have realised this is in a different spot than it is for -literally every other spirit.-

* [spoiler]Night-time sailing.[/spoiler] This takes way too long to find and have. That should be something you get at companion 2 showing up, regardless of who it is.

* The ending is a cliche and predictable before [spoiler]Hades' third meeting or Lily explain it to you in full making it so that you can guess exactly how and why [/spoiler] it happens.


[h3]The Good:[/h3]

* Music is great, I had no complaints, all of it was good, drew me into the situation at hand, and made sense per scene or character. I enjoyed the sound-track the entire way through, none of the music felt off or wrong to me.

* Art style/direction is really good, the characters all kind of felt like that's how they should move/act. Animations looked great, and the overall transition from one thing to another wasn't jarring. It all flowed nicely.

* Most of the colours look good with one-another, even if the buildings are clumped together.

* Overall I did like the general plot and story. If the ending was different, I'd have no complaints about it.


[h3]Detailed summary:[/h3]

There is not a single word that covers how I feel about this game. The closest I have is that the game is just "boring." For me a game really sucks when the more I play it, the less I actually like it, and by the end I have zero intention to go back to it ever. Once this review is posted it's being uninstalled forever. It just isn't good. If it had no positives, I'd feel ripped off lol.

This game just wasn't a fun experience for me, at all. The story was a bit depressing and the controls felt BAD at times. It's not the worst set of controls I've used in a platformer but it didn't feel crisp or fun to me to play through. The platforming doesn't -feel- nice to do. It's got clunky, slow feeling controls that don't always work well together when you need to do stuff quickly, and the cool-downs on these two skills [spoiler]Dash[/spoiler] and [spoiler]Light Burst[/spoiler] can make it annoying to difficult to complete [spoiler]Elena's[/spoiler] quests.

Every 'timed event' felt the same, with a different thing to chase down. All of those quests felt the same, only with more need for specific skills mentioned in the spoiler above, to complete. Oh and they are necessary to complete some of the upgrades, so you do need to do all of them more than once. Painful. The story wasn't interesting enough for me to enjoy the grinding or slog of gathering all the materials just to upgrade the ship, to get to specific parts of the map or upgrade things on the ship, or to turn in for quests. 

The ending is a total cliche and not at all surprising. I saw that one coming a mile away even before I finished the specific story parts with 2 specific characters. [spoiler]Hades and Lily[/spoiler] I feel like [spoiler]Lily[/spoiler] doesn't even like Stella, and resents her for how things go down. The first character just doesn't need to exist, or the second character doesn't need to exist. They both show/say the same things essentially so why not just have it be one character? Convoluted.

In other words, I didn't enjoy the game play at all, I didn't like the ending, and I didn't like the way the game made me feel about the characters you're "supposed" to care about. There's some where I legitimately felt they were a "good riddance" because of their specific dietary requests or their annoying traits.
I really want to play the game again but doesn't that kind of go against the message of finding closure?

What is there to say about Spiritfarer that hasn't been said before? It's a relaxing game, one that through the gameplay loop itself makes you feel the whole range of emotions from contentment and happiness to grief, a wistful sense of nostalgia and sadness. The dialogues are masterfully written, everything is beautifully drawn and animated and the music fits the tone and world very well. There are more than enough other reviews that cover the rest.

Local co-op works well and while it is a pleasure to experience the game alongside a friend, it's still a little clunky that the co-op character can't talk to the ship's residents (well, in the game's defense, the co-op character is the cat and it wouldn't make all that much sense for Daffodil to talk, but still). Steam Remote Play is also a pain to get to work (it always is, but in this game there's some days where it just won't work at all), so be aware of that. 

Should you, after seeing the Overwhelmingly Positive rating of the game and reading the reviews still question if this game is for you, play the demo. That's what convinced me, at least. 
While the demo is actually pretty bland story/character/dialoguewise, it still manages to capture the artstyle, the delightful music and the main gameplay elements (farming/building/etc). The game is absolutely worth the full price, but it does regularly go on sale for up to 75%, so be aware of that.

Tl;dr: Go play it. Be happy. Get sad. Be happy (in a sad way). Forget/repress what made you sad in the first place. Repeat.

At first I didn't know what all the hype was about, most of the reviews I read said this game will bring out my emotions.
But because of the positive reviews and the sale, I gave this game a shot. I have to admit, at first I didn't feel much connected to the characters as I hoped, but they are well written and diverse and different in their own ways.

It was until, I let the first one pass on... The game will often times throw new faces and characters at you, and because of that, you feel like everywhere you go is a place of unfamiliarity. But this works. The ones you once deemed "Stranger" becomes more and more like an anchor to run back to. This works because, each character will sometimes reel you in giving you advice and task that will help progress the adventure. Being with them makes you feel like you're going in the right direction of where the game wants you to go. There can be a lot going on at times from collecting resources and uncovering new locations, to building up the ship and fishing. There have been times where I felt lost on what to do next. BUT.. when you decide to hone in on a familiar character, especially ones that been on your ship for quite some time, you can't help but to feel a sense of comfort and calm with them, even at times of being lost. This feeling slipped underneath my radar when I decided to let them pass on. When continuing my adventures, I start to realize that I miss them more and more as time goes on. This game has made me realize I am someone who doesn't know what they have until they're gone. Of course I can restart the game and have them back, but it wouldn't be the same.

I miss you Gwen...

Alright, I don't want to be too critical, but I'm going to be upfront about this review. The game started out feeling like it was my style, but then I drifted away from it as tike went on. That doesn't take away from what the game achieves, though.

As a game that involves dealing with facing death, interacting with characters who are based on real life people and situations, I LOVED that aspect. There were moments that I connected to this game, and it brought me back to times where I had to face passed loved ones in my family. The stories are wonderfully articulated, the characters feel real, and the difficult trauma and trials that all the characters go through are relatable. 

As for the gameplay, I did like the loop for a bit. Find Spirits to work through a quest line, gather resources to build their home, build related equipment and buildings to make more unique items, etc. However, it got kind of ho-hum after a bit. Things didn't feel particularly enjoyable to go out of my way to get. Something just didn't click for the reward factor of gathering up these things.

That, and the pacing of getting items, upgrading buildings, and helping Spirits just felt... off. I felt like once I accomplished something with building or finished a couple of quests with a Spirit, I was already sending them away to go find another one. It might have been my fault because I didn't take my time with the game, but if you go too slow, then you're just fishing, farming, and foraging. Not super enjoyable when you want story. 

However, there was LOTS of story to be had. I just wish it was paced out just slightly better. 

Do I recommend you try the game? Absolutely. The times I cried from feeling the pain from the characters outweighed much of the frustration in the game moving too fast or feeling too "grindy". I kught have completed the game in just shy of 40 hours, but 100% would surely be a good 50 hours.

Thunder Lotus have always been great in the animation department, but with Spiritfarer they deliver a strong narrative and competent design as well. The parts stand well on their own but the game is more than its parts - the gameplay is helped by the story, and the story itself works better because of the gameplay. Skillful use of ludonarrative synchronicity, one might say.

Importantly, Spiritfarer is a game for the time in which it was released. In times of stress and sadness, it is a calming game about solace. In times of division and hostility, it is a happy place and a friendly face. More practically, it has a remarkably solid co-op mode that works well remotely when so many people are quarantined. Without question Thunder Lotus' best game to date.

Whether it's the simple gameplay that slowly widens into more variety and complexity, or the way the 3D visual effects blend into the hand-drawn art style to create such an eye-catching look.  The multitude of collections for recipes, crafting, expanding your ship, etc.. most of which are helped along by minigames and activities to break up any potential tedium.  There is a lot to recommend about Spiritfarer, but it's definitely the characters who stand out.  It's funny how these cartoon animals could wind up being some of the most human "people" I've seen in a video game.  Some start out annoying, or are even deeply flawed, and yet I always found myself appreciating my time with them, and lamenting when it was finished.  The full story is an absolute emotional roller-coaster, and I continue to recommend the game to friends to this day.  Easily a favorite and worth the purchase price.

I can tell those who made this game poured a lot of love into this game as they've talked about it and how it helped the people who made it work through their grief. This game is currently helping me through my grief in a way that's difficult to explain. It hurts to see someone go, but you should try to focus on their legacy rather than their absence. Grief hurts, because grief is the fear of oblivion. But, the wave needs to return to the ocean. The creator's love for this game is apparent in every aspect of it, it is a very well crafted game that has so much style and personality on top of an amazing story. I would recommend it to anyone who loves beautiful games with a sweet message, anyone who's grieving, and/or to someone who's looking for a slower-paced, relaxing, slice of life game that has a story you can follow/pursue. Loss is an incredibly difficult thing, not only to process, but also to convey. Thunder Lotus has created something very special in this game. What a delicate and special way to introduce loss into a "feel good" game. The game elements are super solid, minimal crafting, base management, etc. Totally separated from the story, this game would  stand alone all on its own merit. its very well conveyed, its theme is consistent, and it can be beaten with sufficient commitment. 

Where i think we really get to *experience* something is the spirits. Each one is very different from one another, adequately suited to there spirit forms, and has a well rounded but still ambiguous back story. We learn just enough to connect, but not necessarily love each spirit. I feel like every player will have strong feelings in a different configuration from one another. Its not death that connects us all though, its loss. Loss and moving on, past the moment that these spirits leave us. Despite the fact that we are all dead in this sea, on this ship, still growing and learning with one another, sending them on their way is still an obstacle of growth. Ill admit, some, i was more than happy to speed through. But others, i wanted to pamper, learn all i could about them, and witness their epiphanies in the time between. 

I cannot stress this enough, buy this game. Do yourself a favor experience these feelings and these moments.  Whether you have been fortunate enough to never lose someone in your life, or agony is all too familiar to you, this game very eloquently skirts the edges of an extraordinarily difficult part of living. 

Thank you Thunder Lotus, for producing this game. And breaking my heart into a million tiny pieces. It feels good to hurt and remember the things that remind me how beautiful it is to be alive and develop the sensations of life.

A soothing and emotional game that can either be the best wind down evening game or the biggest emotional trap. Though the themes of the story are centred around spirits and the concept of an afterlife or limbo, it's easy to forget that and find yourself deeply attached to those you pick up in game. The mini games can be a pain, particularly near the end of the game and especially if you are more of a management game person than a platformer person. That being said, there is no real pressure to complete everything before you finish the game. Many things are under no time limit, particularly story tasks, and you can take as long as you want or need to which is necessary for a game as emotionally engaging as this one.

The magic of Spiritfarer is how it squeezes so much heartachingly beautiful melancholy out of what is a very humble, unpretentious game. You'd expect a game dealing with the reality of death in such a matter-of-fact way to be morose, sad, perhaps blanketed in blues and blacks. Instead Stella flies around with a gorgeous ship on a gorgeous ocean, fishing, weaving and cooking in an idyllic oceanfaring lifestyle, always with a smile on her face. Character moments in a BioWare fashion are few and far between, but the writing is so incredibly strong that they stick in your head regardless. These moments are bolstered by a game that encourages frequent, if shallow, interaction with these characters. Wake up in the morning, hug your passengers, give them their favorite food, maybe improve their house and have a short conversation. By the time you take them to the Everdoor, you've grown attached to these characters even with what is ultimately not much dialogue with them. And let me tell you reader, once it was time to say goodbye I cried at leaving pretty much every single one. Not because they're the most fleshed out characters in the world, but because the game was so good at bringing it's main point across. The ending was such an overwhelming experience that I had to lie down and decompress for a few hours. It is at times, an incredibly rough game to get through if you're anything like me, despite it's cheerful appearance.

For me, Spiritfarer is an incredibly powerful game. I can think of very few ways that touched me in such a raw emotional way as Spiritfarer. I could sit here and talk about some of it's flaws - it's a bit bloated, the sidequests seem largely pointless, and maybe the experience is a tad overlong - but honestly it doesn't matter. Because for me, someone who struggles with the very concept the game is built on, Spiritfarer opened me up and rearranged my interior in a way I don't think anything else has. When I said I cried at every character's goodbye, I wasn't kidding, and that stands all the more in stark contrast to my usual unaffected mentality with most media. That alone means this game is doing something miraculous, and it means the flaws basically don't exist to me. Engage with this game, REALLY engage with it, and you might find one of the most heartwrenching pieces of media to ever exist.

Spiritfarer is a breathtaking game, but it's also bittersweet. The tranquil world and endearing spirits make it an unforgettable experience. What pains me most is that these dear friends must eventually leave. Each farewell is a heartfelt, emotional punch that I hate to endure.( that's why i stop playing)Yet, this poignant aspect of the game, as painful as it is, serves as a powerful reminder of the transient nature of life and the importance of treasuring the time we have with our loved ones. :(((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((
At first, I was skeptical but now I love this game :')

In Spiritfarer, you do a lot of things. You ferry lost souls into the afterlife. You fish. You hug your cat. You plant seeds to feed the souls aboard your ship. You farm; you cook; you build; explore; collect. By the time your 30 hours are up, you will have done just about everything: built houses, made friends, lost friends, laughed, cried. You will also probably have about 400 too many lightnings-in-a-bottle (about 390 more than you'd ever realistically use) and about zero patience left for at least a few of the various mini-games spread around the game world and attached to the resources on your ship.

For what it's worth, Spiritfarer makes this incredibly clear right up front. Your job is to help people. I expected to help people. It just so happens most people just want you to do their chores. Sometimes they want you to go to places that require upgrading your ship. To do that, you need to collect rare resources (obtainable only through mining or sawing them yourself, and, on rarer occasion, provided in little chunks by some of your passengers). Then you have to sail back to Alfred to hear another joke and install your upgrades. You go to the location you originally wanted to go, and now, you have a new location to head to, and suddenly none of the resources necessary to make it happen. So you get back to the grind. I need X; the only X I see on my map is half a world away. Well, I guess I better cook to pass the time. It becomes very clear very quickly that Spiritfarer is mostly going to be watching the "Are we there yet?" bar fill up on the way to your next destination, watching the same landmarks pass by as you go in search of ever-precious beef and peach seeds.

If the game wasn't so rewarding, I would probably describe it as busy work. The reward? It's the dialogue, this storytelling. Despite my slowly ramping frustration with the management elements of this game, the writing never let me go. Each character carries such a presence through their appearance and their particular mannerisms that even if some names get lost in the process of ferrying souls, the memories and stories still remain. And the way activities tie directly into the characters is so wonderful! Even as the activities themselves became boring, I could still feel the impression of those around me stuck to my ship. Death lingers; life lingers. It's impressively powerful, even when all these wonderful words are condensed into little more than occasional hums and single sentences.

It's a real triumph underneath all those bright jellies and lightning storms, real, beautiful art. Even if dying is sad, death can be beautiful. And Spiritfarer is beautiful. I just wish that it wasn't covered in so much sawdust and ectoplasm, that the game let itself be as beautifully brief as its dialogue.

It took me a while to finish this game.

I initially picked up near its release, then stopped playing for a while, and then went back and finished it. I liked the idea of a game where you play as the boatman ferrying souls through the gate and helping them with any unfinished business. It deals with grief, loss, and remembrance. It's an intriguing proposition.

I don't really know how I feel about it. It's a recommendation because its art and music and atmosphere and writing are all great. But as for the game itself, I don't know, I don't think it's that good.

Okay, let me qualify that. It's not that it's not good. It's more that it's not for me. I like sad games, difficult games, complicated games. I've cried through a few endings in my time. But in, say, Celeste, the emotional payoff is gated by tight and satisfying platforming. In Undertale, it's bullet hell and puzzles. Here, it's... farming.

I'm not a fan of grindy stuff. I don't like when my games are routine. Routine is for my daily life, not my virtual escapism. I know all games are ultimately repetitive, but I prefer those that at least make an honest effort at hiding this repetition.

But the thing is, the grind here is also part of the experience. It's one of those "story supported by mechanics" type deal. Your daily tasks represent Stella's journey through the underworld. After all, taking care of those around you is often a routine, and it's often not very fun. That is the whole point.

So I can't really knock off points off of it. Yeah, I thought the gameplay was painful, but so is Stella's story. You can't really extricate one from the other. And at the end of each of those quests, you do get a very emotional scene with an interesting character. But I wish I could just skip through most of it. But then, wouldn't that cheapen the experience?

I guess it's good. Not my game of the year, but good. Yeah, okay, let's make that a recommendation.
