[i]Spiritfarer[/i] is a management sim and sandbox action game developed and published by Thunder Lotus Games.

[b]Story[/b]
You play as Stella, who together with her pet cat Daffodil take over a role from mythological Charon of spiritfarer, a ferrymaster who sails the seas to find spirits, grant them their wishes and ultimately send them to afterlife through a gateway- Everdoor.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Spiritfarer is about spirits and ferring with exploration, management and few platformic bits added to the mix.
Discover areas and lost souls looking for your help, meet their needs and constantly improve your vessel along the way with different resources found from exploration or crafting.

Your ship will not only serve as a way to travel, but it will be a home to all spirits you find along the way, and Stella herself. While she and Daffodil nap in captain's cabin, any other characters will be temporary placed in guest house, though sooner or later a question of building a little cozy space for them will come.
Besides personal houses you will be able to make production buildings with all types of purposes. From places focused on utilizing different materials you collected to showing off your green thumb with gardens or orchards, all important to improving your vessel and to keep up with spirits needs.
Additionally you have a little fishing spot in the back, so while you travel to a location you can relax with little fishing minigame and catch some old shoes or glass bottles! Sea creatures every once in a while too.

Everything you collect, from sealife and resources to products can be sold for glims, games currency used to buy items from vendors or to fund crafting buildings.

As you progress throughout the game, your ship will need to expand and improve too. Upgrade crafting table to unlock new buildings, add accessories to reach new areas and simply make your vessel bigger so you can have extra space needed for whatever lies ahead.

All upgrades and buildings are useless if you have noone to use them for. So sail forth to find different spirits scattered across the game and bring them to your cozy ship so you can take care of them. Each spirit has a mood meter, which changes based on multiple instances. Main one, hunger. Everyone needs to have a meal every once in a while, and each spirit has their likes, favourites and dislikes. You will spend quiet a while in the kitchen, learning and experimenting with all ingredients you have to discover new recipes. Having their own house, improving it, completing their quests or just a specific company from other characters can also make them happy. Oh and don't forget to give them a nice hug! It's good to keep everyone satisfied as spirits with great mood will offer help with tasks on a ship or some sort of support in other way. On the other hand, keeping low morale will have unpleasant effects. Once you are done with character quests, there will be time to say goodbye.

Beside mentioned spirit requests serving as main quests and a tab to keep a look on what resources are needes for another ship upgrade, game offers "shenanigans" which are different type of quests from other characters you encounter during your travels.

Speaking of travelling, it's a key part of Spiritfarer. Each location you discover offers something, and game is seperated into differently themed regions. You will find mist covered forests with tress to cut down and berries to numb on, colorful villages with merchants or deep, deep mines with valuable ores. Each location has a little list near it so you can know what to find in and clears out a bit of fog on the map.
Additionally few places offer different minigames related to spirits.
Because map is quite massive and ship not a rocket type, there are bus stations spread across it used as a way to fast travel.

Finally, Stella does a bit of acrobatics in the game to help you travel. Double jumping, gliding, bouncing, though you will have to unlock them in shrines.
Some areas will be not accessible at the start due to your lack of specific move so there will be some backtracking one way or another.

If something is confusing or might feel like tad much, don't worry! Game offers great tutorial that slowly introduces you to all mechanics it contains.

[b]Playtime, replayability and other modes[/b]
Oh you know how it is with those management games. Hard to point out how much time one will spend on it. My full 100% playthrough took me 35 hours but it was not my first, I assume average playtime should take 30-40 hours, even few hours extra if you want to do everything.
With lenghty playtime and all emotional pieces not having same impact second time around, you don't have to give game another go unless you have not played it after updates with new spirits rolled out, didn't finish it first time around or if you want to play it with someone special in coop. I would say it's more of a "return every once in a while to fish and enjoy peace" game after you beat it.
There is option of online coop through Remote Play where second player steps into the paws of our fluffy companion Daffodil!

[b]Pros and cons[/b]
Spiritfarer is a fantastic title.
From gameplay perspective, it offers great management mechanics mixed with sandbox and few action platformic bits.
By any means it doesn't do anything new nor fresh. Craft materials, utilize them to build and expand your ship, focus on spirits and keeping them satisfied. You know, the usual. But it's nonetheless enjoyable, especially if you seek something slower paced.
It does have a lot of backtracking which might not tickle everyone in a good way, and certain tasks as time goes by can become repetitive once you mine ore or cook a meal for hundreth time. But it also offers fun platformic thanks to design of locations and abilities, fantastic artstyle with detailed animations and wonderful orchestral score accompanying you all the time.

And to level it up, you add whole emotional part regarding spirits, to create this mix of...colorful, wholesome, feels good game that at the same time covers topics of death, of people left behind and possible light of hope to achieve bittersweet balance. As you encounter new charismatic characters, discover their backstories and ultimately have to send them away in really emotional moments, before returning to cat petting, fishing, hugging whoever is left or trading with greedy raccoon. And in a weird way, even if not all characters have same impact, this difference between their personalities and your favourism is what makes it more..humane. That not everyone will affect you and won't be there for you forever, some people will come and go faster, will not be up your alley and you will have to deal with their flaws, yet all might teach you something and spark hope. It hits you even more if you know the feeling of losing your closed ones, of people who might have played an important part in your life and how those final moments felt, so game can be even more reletable.

As I've said before, gameplay at certain moments can become a bit repetitive if you play the game too often. Backtracking can be tiresome. Sometimes platformic sections are frustrating. It's best to take it in short sessions and when you have that feel for slow paced, emotional title. But when you do, there are very few, or maybe even no better games to scratch that itch than Spiritfarer. I adore this game.

[b]Final words and conclusion[/b]
There is a playable demo on Steam if you want to check out gameplay side of the game before purchasing it! 

Spiritfarer offers perfect balance between cozy, wholesome management gameplay and emotional narrative covering death, abandonment and hope. Cannot recommend it enough.

Spiritfarer is very unique game.

The character, known as animal spirits are what make this game so emotional and grew up on me. All their backstory, personality and sense of humors are well-designed including their own unique quests. The grinding and story pushing are very addicting and fun to do.

But that being said, I still find some of the issues as the gameplay: 

1) While the grind is fun and very addicting, it is also annoying and tedious later on. Especially you have to manage all of the resources and knowing your plans what to do, where to go in order to catch up the story (this isn't including grind to 100%). 

2) The event is also annoying, too because it will force you to go to that character to play or not play. Of course all of the events are important for story and grinding grim to buy more resources and upgrade your boat. But having to run down to that character every time is very tedious. Sometimes I don't want to do the event becaus but I have to go that character to disable the event. I wish there was a way to auto-disable the event while going to the next location without getting asked to play the event.

3) The control is very buggy for me. Movement in this game are very basic even with special movement, but sometimes the input started to get stuck and can lock yourself from running around to go inside and interact with NPC or animal for resource. A good example is zipping; with zipping, sometimes pressing W to zipline didn't work properly or the hitbox of zip line is very precise?

While I find the grind is starting to get boring later on, you can't pass out this story. The character, artwork, backgrounds and OST are what makes me addicted to play more. Recommended for everyone want to enjoy the story and be patience because this is a farming simulator after all.

Steam says I spent about 40 hours over two weeks playing this game.  I finally got to the point where the game would allow me to reach the end scene and, despite having three more 'spirits' and thus three more stories to yet complete, I took the sweet, sweet release of death, instead.

Well, not literally. The game isn't THAT bad.  It's just it isn't that good, and worse, it isn't that fun. The ponderous story is pretty good and pretty deep, but it is strung together with some of the worst skinner-box clicker-like gaming that I've ever had to put up with. 

So, the story. The story is about death. Yeah, you knew that already. But it's more about the end of life. The game can be heart-rending. It reflects far too well the experience of caring for aging and dying parents. It digs deep into philosophical questions about if a leopard can truly change its spots, given the opportunity of a deathbed confession. Subtle it is not.

The game lets you skip through dialog. Thankfully.  There's a silly nod to fast-travel, sort of.  But that's the end of what's skippable, and there is the core of my angst with this game. It is soooo sluggish and non-responsive. It requires you to be constantly doing the silly make-work of watering your plants, for instance.  But the hot spots are slow to appear, and if you try to rush it, you're likely to water the wrong place.  And when you do, the game will punish you with a lengthy animation of your character watering the already-soggy ground.  You cannot interrupt this.  

There are a number of skill challenges that essentially come down to knowing how long to hold down a button before releasing it.  If you hold it down too long, the game punishes you by locking out your controls for what feels like an eternity.

You need to shear and feed a pair of sheep? Oh, that's gonna cost you.  The animation that is amusing the first time, is infuriating the hundredth time when you're literally limited in the number of hours in the day.

The game attempts to balance itself out in its later hours. Your passengers become somewhat less demanding, travels starts getting faster, and a lot of the manufacturing and economy tasks begin to fade from importance. But it's just not enough. 

The straw that broke me was when another pair of just-plain-unpleasant passengers showed up on my boat and started making demands. Uggggh.  Just kill me now.

And the game let me. Kill me. It let me just die.

And for that, and in the end, I'm grateful to the game.

I really wanted to like this game. The concept seemed right up my alley, the art direction is lovely, and (to a point) I enjoy a resource management game done right. But playing it, there were several areas that really hampered my overall enjoyment of the game.

I really wanted to like these characters, but the only opportunities you have to get to know them is when you're doing things for them. You can't chat with them outside of quests, and the 'talk' option is really only there so you can get items or so they can tell you they're hungry. [i]Very[/i] occasionally you use it to advance other quests. The pacing of the questlines and the overall story is also bizarre. Some characters quests come one after another, rapid-fire and then they're gone. Others end up taking forever (or simply get put on pause for an extended period because the item or ingredient is in a location that can't be accessed until a different character's questline has been completed). The layout of the map frustrated me as well, though I fully admit this is likely due to personal preference rather than being an actual fault. I also feel like content added in later updates wasn't implemented into the rest of the game very well.

I wanted to play the whole game through before leaving a review, in case my experience got better over time. But unfortunately, I'm left at the end of this feeling like I could have spent the time I sunk into this game doing something else.

Did I cry? Yes, of course who wouldn't. But did I enjoy it as a game? Absolutely NO.

The strongest point of the game is in its story. However, don't confuse its strongest point with the main game loop. This main game loop is platforming & grinding where you've spend like 90% of the time doing them (compare to the story which surfaced occasionally like only 10% of the time). And that's the issue here: platforming is suck and grinding is boring.

The platforming: To summary, it is not tight. While I don't expect it to be that tight (like those specifically platforming games, e.g. Mario, Metroid, Celeste, Ori, etc), but I do expect it to feel good to some extent. Which this game fails to implement these details (no recoil animation when landing, no jump buffering, use the same button for double jump and gliding, and many many more). While these imperfection could have been ignored and/or forgave for such story-based games, this game does feature intensive platforming sections (dragon's mining, comet/lightning collecting, bat's tower-climbing). Those are unenjoyable times which I wish the game should not have them iff the game have these wonky platforming mechanic.

The grinding: Normally, every game that feature grinding in them can (and even sometimes, should) be boring! But there are many technique to subdue these unfun aspect of the game. Take Animal Crossing for example, that game force players to wait for days IRL for the resources to regenerated; or Terraria that let players have other source of fun by grinding w/ friends. This game does it plainly, which, in itself is not wrong. But the requirement of resources is so humongous it get boring real quick. That's half of the story which, again... might be forgivable(?) However, the animation for collecting resources is so freakingly badly designed. Cutting [i]A[/i] tree would take [i]minutes[/i] when the main character is too far from the companion character (so the cat will be slowly floating into your position, and the control-takeaway after finish cutting tree is so damn long). Watering a desired vegetable plot is so damn easy to be mistake (result in watering its neighbor plot, which has been watered just a minute ago, instead). Miss-mining for ore took a very very very long penalty recoil time. Oh boi... the list goes on and on to the point that I think the developer just want to torture us players by designing a game that's NOT RESPECT OUR TIME AT ALL!!!

Appreciate it as a heartwarming story. But think twice if you gonna play the game by yourself.

This game has a beautiful ending and endings, but in the end, I do not think this game fostered the connection for me to really appreciate it.

My main issues reside in the tedium of the game.
The characters have small bouts of dialogue, but I was so busy running back and forth between shenanigans and taking care of each of them (i.e. making sure they were fed, hugged, and upgraded, which entailed a lot of farming for resources) to remember their stories. I barely remember anything about all of them because of how irksome and repetitive the game gets. 
Most of the time is spent farming for resources or silly side quests over actually getting to know the characters, and that's where my main issue resides.
I think I had a worse time with the game *because* I 100%'d it and ran the shenanigans, when I could have spent more time with the characters.

My other issues lie with how the game drags itself out by the end. It takes time to wait between requests, so you just end up leaving the game running in the background. I got the privilege of faring all of the spirits they have added to the end, but by that point I was just longing for the game to finally be over and forcing myself to the finish line.
I actually really like Jackie and Daria. A lot. But it took so long to complete their stories, because I had to wait a full day or two between the next request, and I ended up doing nothing substantial during that time.

All in all, I think the game intended to be tedious sometimes, but I think it just gets way out of hand to the point where it was at least for me, dreadful. It became so boring doing the same tasks over and over again for 50 hours. 
And because I was spending most of the time doing these, the supposedly amazing stories were drowned out.

I honestly don't even know who this game was intended for. I originally bought it for my wife to play, likely due to a recommendation. However, at some point, I completely forgot that it was for her and figured it was some side-scrolling adventure game and started to play it myself (39M). At first, I stared at the screen and then my wife and said "uhmmm... I think this game is for you." But decided to play it for a while.

Immediately when the game got going I said "Oh wow, the music is beautiful." Then "Oh wow, the animation/graphics are beautiful." And suddenly I was immersed in this extremely beautiful game - with a great story (that at one point hits you like "Well holy ****"

I enjoyed almost everything about this game. It made me laugh, it made me tear up at points, it made me think, it was as best as I can tell, a mostly perfect game. 

If I could name a few downsides - they would be:
1) The game doesn't seem to know its audience. If this game was meant for casual gamers - I don't know how they'd manage half of the tasks requiring skillful 2D platformer abilities (you know, like being able to beat Super Mario Bros 1 on Nintendo, with running and jumping, something my wife has never figured out and perhaps few stardew valley aficionados would be good at). Throughout my game play I asked "Who is this game made for?" I still have no idea. I loved it, but have no idea, because while you can do farming and other 'lax' sort of things, I felt the game required some skill level that casual gamers may not have had (and I don't mean it to be derogatory towards those folks, I just know my wife's controller skills, and they're too limited for this game).

2) I remember being very confused by the story and had to look up who the characters were and how they knew the main character (your character). I'd look it up and say "How was I supposed to figure this out?" It didn't detract from the game, but something I still wonder.

3) Perhaps lacking replayability? When I 'finished' the game, I knew there was more to do, but I felt like it wasn't really worth continuing. I'm not sure I'd play the game again, but I don't know because I love the art style and music so much, I could see myself picking it up again

These 'negatives' are pretty minor to me. I got 50 hours played on this game and that's well worth it. 100% excellent game and I list it as one of my top games I've ever played. I moved on to Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom and was actually depressed, feeling like it lacked a lot of the beauty, creativity, and contemplativeness that Spiritfarer contained. This is just one of those amazing games that you stumble across and has an impact on you. For these reasons - I recommend it to anyone I can.

How can a game about death and end-of-life-care be so soothing? A very big part of what makes Spiritfarer so great is, in my opinion, the depth of the characters, including protagonist Stella but extending to - well, each and every creature you'll meet along the way. All spirits have complex personalities, good traits and bad ones, secrets, regrets, lifetimes of memories, and each of them would make for a great spin-off. The mechanics is probably not as intuitive as it is for many other games, but learning how to navigate this excellently built world is very rewarding and I promise you'll grow doing so. Some platformer elements were challenging, using a controller helped a lot. In case you struggle a bit with the controls in the beginning, I can only encourage you to give it another go, it will get a lot easier. I'm saying it because I gave up after 20 mins or so initially (couldn't figure out how to move stuff around the boat, which is very basic but I somehow overlooked it...) and I am so, so glad I tried again after a few weeks.
Dealing with loss, grief and the sheer intensity of being with someone at the very end of their life is certainly not easy and the game depicts the beauty of it without concealing the sadness, rather channelling it. Overall it is strangely uplifting and encouraging. I imagine it can truly help people while they go through their own grief. I played it after Stardew Valley and didn't expect it to be on eye level with my favourite game. Now that I've finished this one too, I hope to be able put all the lessons I've learned about letting go to practice. 

And the soundtrack! It's great.

[h1]Something truely special[/h1]

As you get older, dealing with loss and death becomes a natural part of life. Having lost familiy and unfortunately also a two childhood friends, you become aware that having the opportunity to say goodbye can not be taken for granted. The opportunity to give someone a final hug, tell them you love them, that you'll think about them and that they will be missed, what I would give to have that moment..

Spiritfarer took me on a journey where these characters gave me the feeling that reminds of so many of those people. My grandma who would fall all the time, couldn't really take care of herself anymore but refused any help we offered. Walking out of her home and forgetting where she was supposed to go before her feet hit the curb in front of her house. Spiritfarer gave me that exact feeling, wanting to take care of someone, having difficulties to accept their time has come and then.. letting go. 

Each of the final boatrides in this game was overwhelming, always with a smile and most of the time with a tears in my eyes. How beautiful is it, that a game can make you feel this way? That every character feels genuine, that your own path is made by those who came before you and were part of some of the chapter of your life? 

Spiritfarer isn't just a game, it's a life experience and I urge you to see where it takes you.

Verdict: buy it when on sale.

I wasn't really a fan of this game for a few reasons. 

1. The tone of the game. Overall this is a heartwarming game as mentioned in the game's description. I personally enjoy more melancholic and sad stories and this is most definitely not all that sad or melancholy from what I played. 
2. Everyone basically already knows each other. They reference past events like "Remember that time we were at that place doing the thing?" I like forming my own opinion about characters and whether or not I like them or befriend them. I also like forming new memories that I can then think back on, but having characters like this means they know things I don't, so there's a fundamental disconnect between me and the protagonist.
3. Characters. Similar to number 2, I feel like all the people in this game have preformed friendships, attachments, and so on, especially with the main character. For a game about connecting with others, I failed to really enjoy this. 

Overall though I did like the gameplay. The music was also really good. That being said, there is no automation so daily tasks become repetitive very quickly, and they only increase in the amount you feel like you need to do.

I don't know if I'd recommend this or not. A game that fails to connect with someone doesn't mean it's a bad game necessarily, just that I didn't enjoy it. Others clearly do though as 95% of all reviews are positive for it, so I'm in the minority. If you want to play, go for it. Don't let my negative opinion dissuade you from doing so.

I am always on a lookout for narrative driven coop experiences so I naturally got really excited as I learned that Spiritfarer can be played in a local coop. Playing this game with someone was definitely a better experience, since I am not a big fan of games that make you do daily chores. I always preferred crafting over mining in Minecraft and Spiritfarer is no different.

The concept of the game is awesome. You have your own ship and you sail to different islands on a map, completing quests. Sorts like the 2D version of The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker. However upgrading the ship is a core mechanic that makes you progress in Spiritfarer. You collect resources and then craft / build new buildings for your crew or upgrade ship to access new areas in the ocean. While you are doing that, you spend a lot of time talking and caring for your spirits onboard. Apparently the game is heavily inspired by the Ghibli's Spirited Away and I see the connection.

Spirits on your ship are quite demanding. Requesting you to build expensive upgrades, cook specific dishes and taking them to specific places. Through completing their requests they will tell you insights about their lives. Spirits are vibrant and memorable. You spend quite some time with each of them before saying goodbye. However piecing together all the fragmented bits of information that the spirits tell you about themselves, proved to be rather difficult for me. It is like reading a book where the story makes sense only at the very end. So the patience is required when playing this game.Especially considering hefty 30 hours of playtime, required to complete the game,

But I would lie if I said that the game is boring. You easily end up playing for several hours straight, telling yourself to complete only one more task before closing the game. However mid to late game does slows down significantly as you already discover most or all the map and you just cruise up and down gathering resources. And at this point game does become repetitive. Depending how much you are entertained by the mini games onboard your ship, this last part will drag. I liked crafting mini games - sawing wood, crushing materials, smelting metals... but gathering materials in different events wasn't doing it for me. Such events usually feature materials falling from the sky that you just need to catch. My co player was luckily greatly entertained by the cooking mechanic, although figuring out new combinations that produce new dishes, was almost impossible in the late game , as you didn't have proper way of tracking your cooking experiments.

But regardless of repetition, playing this game felt good. The art direction is superb with diverse themes and color palettes of different areas and islands. Soundtrack is memorable and NPCs add liveliness to the places you visit with well written dialogue that entertains you.

Luckly I do not have much experience with death - a core theme of this game. But it defenitely got me thinking about the concept of dealing with the loss and ultimately accepting it. I will definitely remember this game when such event ultimately comes in someone's life.

I went into this game fairly blind, having only seen parts of the trailers. I have mixed feelings on parts of the game, but would overall still say it was an enjoyable experience for me. That being said, there were some things that sort of bogged the game down.

Aesthetically, the game is very nice. The graphics are beautiful and the animations and music are all pretty good as well. A lot of my issues come from the gameplay and parts of the story. Initially, the gameplay loop is fine and fun, and the story was personally engaging enough for me to want to keep playing. But Spiritfarer seems to be quite front-loaded. I found most of the characters that I found to be enjoyable to interact with were ones you find at the beginning. Towards the middle and end of the game, a lot of the characters come off as rude or just generally not as likable as the earlier characters, though some of them do "redeem" themselves as you go through their story. This wouldn't be too much of an issue on its own, but I also found the gameplay started dragging around the last 4th of the game. You are constantly looking for/creating resources, so to me personally it became much more about getting stuff to complete the requests rather than actually taking my time to get closer to the characters. The time you start spending to gather all the resources start to increase as you have more and more different resources that you will need, and this is not really alleviated that much as there is nothing to automate these processes. The only thing you will get is maybe faster or double the resources depending on the type. This also led to a problem where some characters came and went incredibly quickly because I had unknowingly finished some of their requests beforehand via buildings or upgrades and the like. This on top of some of the characters being generally unlikable led to me not really connecting with some characters at all, which kinda sucked the enjoyment out of the game at points. 

Overall, I still enjoyed the game, but the combination of the gameplay loop becoming pretty grindy and the later characters being generally lackluster made the last 3rd or 4th of the game pretty miserable at times. There are some more minor complaints I have, like some animations being quite long, so when you start having to see that same animation multiple times it starts to eat up a lot of time and lose its charm.  Regardless, I would still recommend trying out the demo or playing the game if you like a more chill management kind of game.

I can't believe how much I enjoyed a seemingly simple game. It's easy to learn, fun to explore, and I wanted to return to the world everyday until I beat it. There is freedom yet a trajectory that is both enjoyable and easy to follow to accomplish goals. There is enough customization, yet not so much its overwhelming. Challenging enough to keep you entertained, yet relaxing enough to call it a laid back game. You get attached to the little characters you're taking care of on your boat, and it's almost always hard to say goodbye. The characters are well rounded in that they are both touching and prickly, each with their strengths and weakness like any human being, most of them still lovable anyway yet everyone will walk away with a different experience and different favorites - like life itself. Such a touching narrative that highlights a difficult part of life. Not many video games successfully hit so many notes, especially in a subject so sensitive such as confronting with and coping with death. 

The game play is similar to a lot of laid back games in that there's cooking (crafting), exploring, fishing, and challenges involving the dexterity of your character. The narrative is also how you get through the game, but its not belabored or boring, and I think it adds the depth the game needs. Most of the types of game play are not required, but if you do not like some of those types, you may want to reconsider.

Eu gostei da premissa de Spiritfarer desde que o vi pela primeira vez. Você assume o papel de Stella, que com seu navio, conduz espíritos, que são apresentados na forma de animais, em sua transição para a morada final, o céu, o além, ou como você queira chamar. A mecânica do jogo é centrada na administração de recursos e em quests pra satisfazer as últimas vontades desses espíritos que estão prestes a partir.

Como acabo de mencionar, um dos pilares que sustentam o jogo são seus personagens, os espíritos, afinal, é eles que você tem que abrigar, alimentar, e até mesmo abraçar ‒ o que aliás foi uma das mecânicas mais legais e únicas que achei nesse jogo ‒ para tornar esses momentos finais tão acolhedores quanto seja possível. Os personagens são em sua maioria simpáticos e tem interessantes histórias de vida que fazem você se importar com eles. São eles que trazem os momentos emotivos do jogo que fazem até mesmo você refletir sobre determinadas coisas.

O segundo pilar que sustenta o jogo é a sua mecânica. Você basicamente obtém recursos para construir casas para os personagens, para expandir o tamanho do seu navio e poder construir estruturas especializadas como cozinha, moinho, serraria, forja, curral, galinheiro, etc, para obter outros recursos necessários para alimentar seus personagens e completar quests.

O problema é que ambos os pilares do jogo tem alguns problemas estruturais. O jogo começa com um ritmo bom, os primeiros espíritos são simpáticos e tudo flui bem. Mas à medida que o jogo avança, você precisa lidar personagens mais chatos e tediosos, as quests e a busca por certos materiais mais raros se tornam maçantes, com muita repetitividade. Algumas áreas do mapa só são acessíveis quando você faz certos upgrades no seu navio, e chega um certo ponto que você empaca, pois a última evolução do navio, para ultrapassar áreas de nevoeiro, depende de um material que não existe em lugar nenhum. Tive que olhar na internet pra descobrir que[spoiler]você precisava PESCAR um personagem aleatório, que depois de um tempo teria um besouro de estimação na casa dele que dispara um evento que lhe dá o tal material.[/spoiler]
Forçou horrores a barra.

Pelo que li, alguns personagens e quests foram adicionados através de atualizações depois do lançamento do jogo. Até o final do jogo e a história de background da protagonista foram alterados por meio de updates, o que demonstra que as coisas foram meio que surgindo ao invés de terem sido planejadas, e isso transparece na diferença de qualidade da história dos personagens e de suas quests da primeira metade do jogo em relação à segunda. E pra um jogo que você pode jogar por 40 horas ou mais, é uma bela bola fora. Parece que acrescentaram mais conteúdo em um jogo que poderia ter sido muito bom com 20h de duração, para artificialmente estender essa duração mas com conteúdo pior.

Visualmente o jogo é lindo, com gráficos bem desenhados, cenários dos mais variados, incluindo ciclos de dia e noite, belos nasceres e pores do sol, e até eclipses, assim como mudanças climáticas. Não faltou esmero no visual do jogo, e essa parte é impecável. A trilha sonora também é muito bacana e complementa de forma muito competente a experiência.

Fiquei no limiar da dúvida se recomendaria ou não esse jogo, mesmo eu tendo comprado ele durante uma sale. Mas aí eu lembrei do querido tio Atul e resolvi recomendar. Mas com asterisco. É um jogo que requer bastante paciência, e que apesar de ter seus bons momentos, também tem uma mecânica um tanto arrastada, algumas quests sem sentido, alguns personagens que não agregam muito, e até um final fraco, o tornando uma experiência que pode frustrar muitos jogadores. Mas muitas outras pessoas relevam essas coisas. Este não é o primeiro, nem o vigésimo, e não certamente não será o último, que traz uma premissa muito interessante mas implementada através de uma mecânica que é falha e sinceramente quase bota tudo a perder ([i]The Witness[/i], estou olhando pra você).

This game has a really strong central narrative theme and that is one of passing away. Many of the gameplay and presentation elements are used effectively to present this central theme. To start with, most of the characters feel nuanced and complex, and the game is able to share a ton of information through relatively little. Everything from the way characters walk around the boat to their favorite foods to the way that they hug the main character stella say things about who they are as people. What probably helps in this regard is that I believe all of the characters are based on real family members of the development team.
With the realism of the characters, the game is set up for you to care about them, and that makes the gameplay all the more cathartic and bittersweet when these characters do meet their end. Your role isn't as savior here, its mainly towards facilitating and guiding these lost spirits through experiences for them to find some sense of closure, while trying to minimize their physical suffering as much as possible during the process through simple things like a nice meal, a comfortable place to sleep, and regular social and emotional interaction.
Gameplay wise there are a ton of similarities to other life sims, but this game is not really meant for optimization. Cooking a spirit a laborous expensive meal fills their bellies just as much as a simple to make cup of coffee. Whats more important is learning what a characters favorite food is and what that says about their character. Similarly, one could hoard resources, but the gameplay loop doesn't demand or reward you for doing so and much like in real life, hoarding resources doesn't do you much good in the afterlife. I think that gamers who get the dopamine rush of optimization might not find as much satisfaction from that aspect here. Rather, this game asks for you to take its roleplaying to heart and invest in these characters, not through resource grinding/optimization but through emotional connection

This is one of the cases where I wish Steam had a 1-10 rating system instead of a Y/N one. I initially marked this as a Yes but the more I write the more I don't think I'd recommend this. 

I bought Spiritfarer ages ago, and could not get past the tutorial because of how much hand-holding was happening; I was trying to figure things out myself but instead had to follow exactly what the game told me to. It got old pretty quickly so I gave up about one hour in. Then recently I decided to give it another go as so many people were recommending it, and got really into the story. I've cried tons of times playing this, and this is why I'd recommend the game. The concept and story are really good (even though you're basically playing Fetch Quest - The Game). 

There are however quite a lot of flaws that made the experience very frustrating for me: 

1) The game doesn't know whether it wants to be open world or linear. There were many times where I'd unwittingly explored past where the story had progressed to, but I was required to backtrack and do every single step in the way the game wanted. This was very annoying because I really wanted to figure things out on my own, not be guided so much. Either you want me to explore, or you lock me into linear gameplay. You can't do both. 

1b) As a byproduct, I ended up exploring too much and unlocking very important plot points out of order. This really ruined the experience for me, as after uncovering a major point I didn't even feel like finishing the game properly. I just did the final quest and decided to call it a day. After 35 hours of gameplay, this is what bothered me the most. I didn't even get to explore the game in its entirety, and now I don't care enough to go back and fill in the gaps. It's a shame because I think 100% in this game would be quite rewarding. 

2) There is way too much hand-holding. I don't like to be flat-out told how to do things or where to go - for example sometimes you'd get quests where characters would talk in riddles, making me think "okay so I've got to figure out what they meant, nice" just for me to open the Quest tab and see that the game had already indicated a location for me, taking away the fun part. I don't get why. The themes are very mature, so I don't think this is geared towards children - so why so much guiding? Just let me immerse in the story and use my brain.

3) Quest reminders. Characters will give you a quest that might take HOURS to fulfill (totally fine with this, it's what makes fetch quests fun for me), and then constantly remind you that you haven't fulfilled it yet. Thanks, I know. I'm waiting to get there, and you're just making me hate you by constantly remarking on how long I'm taking. I have a Quest tab for a reason. Stop pestering me. I legit stopped talking to several characters, didn't even feed them for a long time, because I was tired of being reminded. S t o p. 

4) Too much of the lore is not explained in the game itself. I took a look at the Wiki and turns out each character (including the protagonist) had tons of background which is never properly explained in the game - what's the point? I don't want to have to buy the Artbook to get lore. Either you leave the player to make their own assumptions (which is what I did, just read the dialogue and made my own ideas about characters and their stories) or you find a way to add the essential lore to the game itself. Some of the things I found out through the Wiki were pretty essential and would have really enriched the game; why do I have to read about them on the Wiki/Artbook? 

I think I'm just gonna leave it at this, the review is long enough as it is... a shame, really. I constantly went from deeply connecting to the characters and story to hating every second of it and just forcing myself to get to the next character so I could get more of the story. When you look at the experience as a whole, it wasn't worth it.

Should you play this game? If you like wholesome life sim type games, then you certainly should, since this is about as good as that type of game gets in my opinion - but it goes *so* much further than that in terms of character development and storytelling. This is a really well deserved 'overwhelmingly positive' rating.

The writing itself does it's best to not get in your way - this isn't reams of excessive lore dumping, it's just a handful of lines of dialogue from the denizens of the ship every now and then, but they've really maximised everything from those really limited interactions. Each chat is so full of heart and soul, all the characters are written with so much empathy, even the negative characters have upsides and there really needs to be more of this kind of characterization in games. This isn't "shades of grey" or "black and white" just... everyone has their things, life is complicated, people aren't perfect, but everyone is trying, and everyone has a little good in them regardless of the circumstances. It's honestly beautiful.

It doesn't sugar coat the bad stuff, and it doesn't drown the good bits in sickly sweet "wholesome" vibes, it's just real and empathetic, and I totally adored this games world view.

From a gameplay perspective, I don't know what else to play since I don't play a whole lot of life sims, but I really thought the core loop was great fun. You sail around the world collecting resources, doing jobs on the ship, making dinner for people and uncovering more of the map. There's a lot to see and do in the world and they really made the most of the 2d perspective - the game feels much bigger than it truly is, and I really like when games can pull that off. 

I didn't find it too grindy, which is something I think life sims suffer from occasionally, but towards the end as I had less guests on the ship, I did start to feel the grind just a tad, but not enough to dramatically affect my enjoyment.

Overall, it's a beautiful game about how people relate to each other and about what happens when they pass.

Spiritfarer is an incredible game. It has helped me confront, relive, and live with my grief. I've cried multiple times, I love the gameplay loop, I love exploring and learning who these people were and are, I love it all. To me, this would be one of my all-time favorite games, if not for one thing; I can't recommend it in good consciousness, because it is a photosensitive person's nightmare.

If you are photosensitive, don't bother. Don't buy this. If you bought it, refund it. There are mandatory storm segments that have intense flashing repeatedly for at least 2 minutes straight. The screen flashes after every single spirit recruited, every material harvested, and ability gained. I've had to take multiple breaks, I've thrown up, I've been left jittering and nauseous with intense headaches for 20-60 min at a time. I love this game so much, so I've REALLY been trying to just suck it up, but at some point, it becomes a danger to my health. Memorizing when to look away from the screen helps, but I can't predict every time the screen is going to flash for seemingly no reason other than.. I dunno, to look cool? It doesn't look cool to me. It looks like losing my lunch and being bedridden with a massive headache.

When confronted about this, a developer stated that it was "epileptic cleared", that "we will not be updating the game any further", and "try being in a well lit room, or not drinking alcohol". Frankly one of the most insane responses I've ever seen to asking for an accessibility option, which is all the stranger after seeing how they were willing to change offensive dialogue for a disabled character. It's honestly baffling reading their only response, seeing how many people were affected by it and just wanted to play the game. If it was epileptic cleared, then whoever cleared it needs to be scrutinized for their stupidity. 

TLDR; Fun game, love it a lot, would love to play it without becoming extremely pained, sick, or bedridden. Photosensitive people deserve to play your game, too. Frankly, I don't think I'll ever be giving money to Thunder Lotus again seeing how they've responded to their clear accessibility issue.

[b]Spiritfarer[/b], another beautifully animated game form Thunder Lotus, opting for less gameplay in favor of a more slice of life (slice of death?) approach.

[h1]X-Factor[/h1]
You are Stella, the new ferryman taking spirits to their final rest, and the atmosphere is not dark and drab as one might imagine, but leaning more on the bittersweet, a lot of happy moments followed by introspective ones, your objective being helping spirits make peace with their past before having them move onto the afterlife.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Simple and varied, mainly a platformer, navigating the small islands you’ll visit, and the other half comprised of minigames, either by cutting wood, making fabric or helping plants grow and many more, all tied up by a string of gathering/fetch quests that keeps the story and progress chugging forward.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The main narrative, is composed by many shorter stories, namely the ones of the passengers aboard your ship, some are good, some less so, but unfortunately, in my opinion, none truly shine to make this an unforgettable experience.
[hr][/hr]

I recommend this game if you want to play something with no rush, lovely visuals and some interesting bittersweet stories here and there.

Spiritfarer, for those who will enjoy it, is something close to a perfect game. The experience is almost like reliving a storybook from your childhood, but as you yourself playing the main character. As you travel the sea, visiting new islands, you meet more and more varied and interesting characters, all with unique visual designs, personalities, dialogue, and gameplay implications. 

The game offers a staggeringly large collection of different gameplay challenges, far more than you'd expect from what appears to be at face value a largely story-focused experience. From jumping around collecting fireflies, to catching lightning in a bottle, to tending to crops, to placing buildings on your ship so they fit optimally, to jumping between cliff faces on a gusty island, making use of upwards drafts to ride higher, the list is nearly endless. As a result, there's never a dull moment playing spiritfarer; there's always something to do, and it's almost always something different.

The most impactful part of the game, however, is the story. You play as the replacement to the ferryman of the dead, leading lost souls to their final resting place. Every character you meet, no matter who they are, always eventually has to be taken to their final destination under the bridge, where they permanently depart from your ship. Most games shy away from removing characters as the story progresses. Spiritfarer does exactly the opposite. 

Each character's arc, from initial meeting, to development, to their final journey, is treated with grace, respect, and dignity. You know you won't spend forever with each new character you meet, and the game knows that too. But instead of reveling in the character's departure, and milking it for emotional impact, the game's plot and story structure focuses on the breadth of the positive time you *do* spend with each one. The final moment where you ferry each passenger to their final resting place is not a sad occasion; it's a memorial to all the amazing things you did with them while you two traveled together. It's one of the few games that's managed to make me shed a tear.

Spiritfarer is a game about recognizing the fleeting nature of life, but at the same time, recognizing its powerful beauty it has in the time it does exist. It chooses not to focus on the end, but instead on the journey that carries us there.

[h1]An aesthetically pleasing, and truly touching management game with diverse characters you won't want to part with, despite tiring you with its drawn out pacing.[/h1]

You take on the role of the newly appointed spiritfarer, taking on lost spirits in the afterlife, and catering to their every need until they are ready to move on: giving them lodging and food, keeping them happy, and fulfilling any other requests they may have. Throughout that process, you learn about each spirit's life stories.

[h2]The good[/h2]

The game's main highlight are the spirits you take care of, who are all well written, and diverse in their background, motivations, and even in morality. (To not spoil anything,) some are much easier to please than others. Some will be in a much more dire need of help. Some are brimming with positivity, while others will literally drag people down, and some will even treat you like a complete tool. The game urges you to treat them all with kindness in their final days. (Although there's no severe punishment for neglecting them outside of their necessary requests.) 

I've found myself feeling attached to almost everyone I've gotten close to over the game, and some of them particularly shined through. Though I am far from emotional, I can assure you that letting your friends go is going to be a very hard thing to do, and you'll be doing that over a dozen times.

The artstyle is also a highlight. The environments, with its clean (almost mural-like?) art style is pleasing to look at, and the animations are fluid.

You can also hug everyone, and pet the cat.

[h2]The bad[/h2]

The core gameplay loop is harvesting resources found around the game's many islands, and processing them to fulfill the requests of your spirits on board.

This can easily feel very grindy, especially if you're trying to have all your facilities constantly running, there will be a lot of handiwork in between all the brief moments you're actually getting closer to the spirits, which either involve long timers, or minimally engaging minigames.

You're also likely to came across requests that require materials from regions or events you only unlock later, this puts a halt to a relationship with someone, and can also sometimes confuse you, in cases where you miss a spirit, or otherwise think you can ignore the one that unlocks that material.

An advice I can give you while playing is to focus purely on the requests that you have, do everything that you can do. You don't need too much of anything. Just harvest whatever you come across, and don't stress over constantly having everything running. The gameplay is not the core of the game.

The spirits' requests will also become predictable after some time, they all follow a general pattern.

Expect your casual playthrough (releasing all spirits) to take up to 30-40 hours, with many periods of minimal activity. By the end of it, I was getting tired, and just wanted to be over with it.

Overall, spiritfarer is a very touching game, but your experience will mainly depend on how emotional you are. If you usually take grief well, and/or you're focusing too much on the gameplay, like I was, Spiritfarer is not going to have the impact on you that it actually has.

The best aspects of this game are its characters and their stories. They are more than beautifully written! I saw others refer to this game as "bittersweet", which is the best word to describe it with, in my opinion. There were more then a few moments which gave me literal goosebumps.
For those who are not familiar: the story is all about heavy topics like death, loss, regrets and acceptance. The characters are so well written that quite a few of them made me think of real people that are or have been a part of my own life.

Audibly the game is beautifully serene and visually it is nicely drawn like an anime.

The gameplay is pretty well balanced, except for the last couple of hours during which it slows down too much for my taste. It starts of great and ramps up in a perfect tempo. I didn't feel overwhelmed and also never felt bored during the startup-fase of the game. When the gameplay loop reaches full speed it felt just right for me as well. There always was a lot for me to do in a way I never felt rushed.
Unfortunately the loop did get stale towards the endgame, which for me was like the last 6-8 hours of the game. I wanted to complete all optional content, during which I sometimes had to wait for the game to catch up with me. This is because the amount of things to do quickly dwindles when the main story reaches its end.

All in all I think Spiritfarer is an almost perfect experience and I'm very glad I didn't miss out on it.

I finally finished Spiritfarer, and boy it delivered my expectations with a jar of tears.

[h1] Pros [/h1]
[b] - A management sim about palliative care : [/b] Or more like, limbo care? Anyways it had a fresh take of letting you take care of your passengers, building up your relationship with them before sending them away with a smile.
[b] - Story : [/b] Of course, when it is about dying, you have to have good writing and scripts to be able to deliver the message and not come across as cheesy. I cried many times, nuff said.
[b] - Interactive and innovative gameplay : [/b] You have a lot, and I mean [u] A LOT [/u] to do, and each interaction in acquiring and converting resources is unique.
[b] - Pleasant art : [/b] the art direction, UI, and the transitions are pleasing to the eyes, reminiscent of you reading interactive storybooks.

[h1] Cons [/h1]
[b] - Repetitive : [/b] Even if the interactions are unique, if you do it a hundred times, it does get repetitive and can get on your nerves, especially since it loves shoving you the resource acquisition animations. [b] JUST BE DONE WITH THE RESOURCE GATHERING, STELLA! [/b]

[b] - Achievements : [/b] [spoiler] Due to the lack of manual save, if you missed it, you have to restart the game again, rewatch and send three spirits to their way, have another go at resource gathering, to reach the halfway of the story, all for that single damn achievement. 0/10. [/spoiler]

[b] - Buggy at times : [/b] I have experience minor bugs and glitches here and there. It's not really game-breaking, but it takes away from the flow sometimes. I'm having a moment here!

Overall, if you want to soften your [i] cold, rocky heart [/i] because of all of the bad news in the world, then go grab a cup of hot chocolate [i] (or milk, or whatever you prefer) [/i] and play this game.

Spiritfarer is, in my opinion, one of the best games ever made. The narrative it presents has much more depth than it may seem, the characters are all loveable in their own way, and the "management sim" gameplay is fun, with a progression system that feels rewarding as you upgrade more and more things on your boat. 

Not without a couple faults, the coop mode is a bit lacklustre, with only player one being able to actually progress the game and player two being stuck with more of a "janitor" role. 
There were also times where certain early characters quests seemed to just be on pause for a while, since you needed a far away upgrade/resource but were not told that you couldn't complete it at the moment, leading to some circling of islands trying to find where the heck you missed something.

These minor details though were massively overshadowed by just how good this game is. It will have you crying happy and sad tears, and you will fall in love with the world and the characters within. Definitely worth the purchase!

This game built me up, then broke me down, then built me up again. I cried at this gamer so much. It is a beautifully crafted story that leads you through the sorrow and sadness of losing people you love. Some though long journeys where they lose themselves slowly, some where they're there one moment  and gone the next. The joy of a life well lived, and the tragedy of a life far, far too short. People who were good to their very core, and some who were not, but who loved deeply (to a fault perhaps). There is such a wide range of emotions to be felt in this game, but it is also very cathartic. The characters are all flawed people, but ones who love regardless.
It's not all sobbing your heart out, there is an actually resource management game here, but you do need to be emotionally prepared to face some heartbreaking goodbyes to progress. 
There's a beautiful metaphor here, for how you get to decide when you're ready to go through the next stage of grief, no one can make you go any faster than you're ready for. But you also can't move on without loss, and without facing the heartbreak that comes with it.

Awesome game. 
1. There is no way to screw it up. No lives to be lost (lol!), no consequences for failures, just go do it again.
2. There are some things (like food items you can buy along the way) that if you're going for 100% complete, you may want to be mindful of, but at most you're missing out on a cosmetic or two. Absolutely zero effect on gameplay. 
3. This game does an AMAZING job balancing grinding with easy to achieve goals. Nothing ever felt impossible to get, and a lot of goals were accomplished fairly easily while I was doing other things. As someone with ADHD, I never felt like any task was impossible for me. Even when I struggled with a task ((the super pulsar challenge late game comes to mind), it asked if I wanted my efforts taken into account, and made it easier until  I COULD do it. I really appreciated that. Like, can I get that built into every game? pretty please?

This game will hurt, you will cry. but the journey is worth it, learning peoples lives, and trying both succeeding and failing to make them better or improving them. failures, successes, making memories. its all worth it and it gives you a hard perspective on what to value in this world. i recommend this game, but be prepared for hard emotional damage.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

Wow, this game was an experience. I was not expecting this game to have the emotional gutpunch that it does. Sure, it's a cozy management game about dying, but there are ongoing, periodic revelations that everything might not actually be what it seems. There was a fair amount of dark topics and cursing to make this seemingly light-hearted game get pretty, pretty heavy at times. 

Mechanics-wise, it's very easy to play. Platforming ramps up in slight difficulty towards the end, but nothing actually hard. Everything feels fair and balanced. The world events are all great, the simple farming mechanics are all great, and usually 1-2 button presses. That's not where the game shines though, really, it's all about the story. And what an amazing story it is.

Art style, pffft. Hand-drawn in video games is always a winner in my book if they put any actually effort into it. And they did. It's a beautiful game.

TLDR: A casual game with a lot of hidden depth and enjoyment to be found

Spiritfarer is a mostly-relaxing game where the player assumes the role of Stella taking the reins from Charon and becoming the boatwoman that guides spirits to the Everdoor, the gateway to their eternal rest. Several of the spirits are loved ones from Stella's life and it soon becomes obvious there is more afoot than first revealed.

The controls are easy and simple to master, as is sailing about the map of the ... not-quite-afterlife. Various islands dot the map, where the player can find and meet the waiting spirits, who will join Stella on the boat. The passenger spirits take the form of anthropomorphic animals, as do many of the spirits of importance, such as Albert the shipbuilder, who appears as a wise-cracking shark. In fact, the game has a sense of humor; you can watch a talking deer spirit in high heels berate a price-gouging raccoon by calling him a trash panda and a striped weasel. Other spirits appear as ghostly forms, adding either background flavor or an odd request here and there.

Each passenger spirit has specific needs and wants, and a task or three to fulfill before asking Stella to carry them to the Everdoor. Each likes to have their own house aboard the ship, and certain foods. Each has a happiness meter while on board, ranging from angry to ecstatic. Mood is affected by feeding them regularly, building and upgrading their houses, or even offering a comforting hug from time to time. There are no consequences for some spirits going angry, though others will wreck buildings on the ships, set livestock loose, or otherwise become uncooperative, so it is important to keep them at least at a middling happiness level. Their personalities range from sweet and adorable to abrasive and unlikable, and I am sure everyone will find some their favorites (I loved Atul and Alice) and least favorites (yes, Bruce and Mickey, that means you). It became very hard to let some of them go through the Everdoor and as time goes on, the player realizes that's not quite what has happened ... but no spoilers. By the time the story ends, it is quite a melancholy tale.

Fortunately, to keep her passengers happy, Stella can harvest resources on the islands, go fishing for food and items, sort through shipwrecked debris for treasure, and build structures on the ships. The player will have to manage several resource types and glims (currency) to upgrade the ship for room and speed, and to build more advanced buildings. Crops can be grown, sheep corralled and sheared, zircon chunks smashed to make silica dust, and many other possibilities. There are special events for special resources scattered about the map, and new areas which are initially gated off. Both resources and areas can be unlocked as the correct spirits join the ship. As Stella travels, the player will also be able to unlock new abilities, such as double-jumping and emitting a burst of light, which will help acquire resources or reach areas previously unavailable. There is a roaming merchant who always seems to be close (to sell treasures and barter for money and rare resources through tasks) and a network of fast-travel portals run by an excitable seal, that prevent long stretches of sailing across the map or back to port to unload.

Unfortunately, the progress through into new areas is very regimented as the player needs to pick up exactly the right spirits to progress from area A to area B, and again from area B to area C, and so on. It's not an afwul approach but it is somewhat limiting and less "open-world" in design. Many building upgrades will become available long before the player has the right spirits to unlock the special events for critical resources, and will sit around in your "Available Upgrades" for a while. If you find yourself stonewalled with progress over one resource, keep looking for the spirits you've missed. Also, I have to say in mid and late-game, managing all of the tasks on the ship--growing crops, cooking food, feeding animals, converting logs and ore to boards and ingots, scraping shellfish from your hull, etc, can become very tedious. You'll also hit a point late game where money means nothing, which robs some of your main secondary actions (doing tasks for the merchant and salvaging treasures) kind of moot.

Graphics are a minimalist, cartoon-style that works well for the gameplay. Sound and music are excellent. The game itself feels very clean and error-free. I had no glitches or crashes, and scene transitions loaded with quick efficiency.

Steam Achievements are all attainable by an average-skilled player, if they want to dedicate the time to do it. I believe (i could be mistaken) that it requires at least one full and one partial playthrough (for one pivotal decision) to get one-hundred percent.

Spiritfarer is going to be one of those games that is going to be what the player makes of it. I imagine someone could zip through the main storyline in less than twenty hours, or spend more than twice that collecting everything, seeing everything, and engaging the spirits in banter and camaraderie. Either way, it's definitely worth a look.

Pros
- Relaxed, unhurried gameplay
- Melancholy, nostalgic story

Cons
- Very regimented progression
- Task management can become a burden

Final Score: 7.5/10

Not sad tears, but happy ones, small droplets filled with the memories of their lives.

Experiences like this one, is why the beauty of life is like an elixir of wisdom for our mind.
I remembered traveling across a great ocean, visiting islands and exploring beautiful vistas.
Meeting interesting characters and befriending them, relating to their stories or at least grasping an understanding of what they needed, before they could pass on. As with the people we meet in our life and those that leaves us behind, there are always fragments of regret, words left unsaid and things unfinished. But there is also, acceptance and a feeling of gratitude for the time given.

If art moves you, this one is for the ages.

What starts as an overwhelmingly positive start soon turns to utter monotony as you perform the same repetitive tasks over and over for decreasingly likable characters. I feel like it is death by a thousand cuts, nothing too egregious by itself but all of the small problems add up, turning my fond feelings into disdain, for both the game and the characters. The writing, while good at points, doesn't stick the landing for many of the characters and does not redeem the game play. A lack of quality of life improvements adds to the slog, the slow animations made me hesitate doing all the tasks between fishing, logging, mining, and even exploring.

If you feel like the writing of the character dialogues and the fond farewells will be enough to get you through the end, then like many other people you may truly love this game, as it is very unique in what it sets out to achieve. The differing opinions come from whether you think they reached those intended goals. I wish I loved this game as much as the others, but by the end I was begging for myself to be taken to the Everdoor . However, if on the fence, I urge you caution, and to maybe read the wiki and leave the games stories in your imagination - it'll save you hours of tedium and boredom.

Stunning hand-drawn and hand-animated story of dying and traveling through the afterlife in Styx, don't be fooled by the initial look of this game. This plays as a much more relaxed and broader-focused [url=store.steampowered.com/app/493200/RiME/] RiME [/url] type of experience, both are equally as sad though this one is far less tragic and leans more towards wholesome in its own way. I don't want to go into too much detail here and risk spoilers, but if you've lost anyone close to you then you'll likely connect with the story and possibly one or more of the passengers you meet along the way.

I replayed this recently after the free expansion and all of the final patches had been released. The new character additions added a few more layers to the adventure with some of the experiences diving a lot deeper into their issues and letting you help them directly, similar to the Sea Serpent in a way. The expansion also added a few new features, additions to the boat, and new music that's themed to each person.

As for technical bits, audio and visuals are top tier, and the soundtrack does an outstanding job of adding to it all. Oh man the music that plays when meeting Hades, I wish I could go back and experience that scene again for the first time. The hand-drawn everything in this really goes a long way and I'm glad they stuck to it, it's basically animated in Shadowbox style because of the excellent layering and visuals. The game did have bugs at the time of release and the devs were quick to fix them as they got reported, nothing for me was game-breaking. I'm extremely glad that they added an option to turn off the Seal's music, oh man, that track was clearly made on an offbeat day.

My gripes with the game in its current state shouldn't deter anyone from playing this, these are very minor issues. The game has finished development which is good unless you encounter a bug, the problem now is that the Devs will respond to bug requests but are seemingly unmotivated to fix them anymore. I dislike that many of the upgrades you get for the ship come way too late in the game, nearly by the time you've finished farming/crafting materials and it all just becomes excess. It also bothers me that the ship is powered by your Everlight, but it can't move at night because... reasons? You can eventually do this via a late-game character that joins you, but honestly why was this ever a thing. Additionally why can't the navigation room be moved, let alone accessed at night if I just want to view the map?

Note: I highly recommend reading each character's artbook entries in the fan wiki as you help them along, it will uncover more of their story and involvement with you while not really spoiling anything.

This is by far one of my favourite games of all time. There is so much love put into this game, you can really feel it in every aspect. The visuals, the characters, the stories, the gameplay, the music, they are put together with all the care in the world. The only slight downside for me was that the gameplay got a bit pointless after a while, but other than that I can recommend this game wholeheartedly to anyone. If you would like to get on a very emotional journey with a simplistic management system and a risk free, cozy gameplay loop, then definitely try this game.
[list][/list]
I want to get the only thing that bugged me out of the way first:[list][/list]
- Gameplay: I played this game with my wife in coop and at the start it was wonderful. Managing the ship, getting resources, making food for the residents, trying to prepare all the resources needed for the upgrades, it all worked really well. The minigames are fun and keeping all these tasks in mind is engaging. At the beginning gaining money is still a challenge, so we had to plan what we wanted to do next, what things we need more and we wanted to/could sell. Then we started the cloth and fish business and it pretty much broke the gameplay. At around halfway through we had pretty much infinite money, had all the resources ever and apart from the interactions with the characters, the gameplay became completely pointless. Don't get me wrong, the movement system is butter smooth, the basic gameplay loop is very fun but if you are worried about the money like we were, you might end up making your gameplay unnecessary. I don't know how common this might be among the players though. Also, important to mention that there is no failure in this game. You cannot loose. This might be off putting to some people and that’s completely understandable, there were occasions where we were hoping for some consequences. But eventually this game is not about that. It is about the stories, the characters and the feelings it evokes. So let’s get to that part.
[list][/list]
The good stuff:[list][/list]
- Music/Graphics: Regarding the music, all the songs fit perfectly with the scenes and locations, it adds a lot to the atmosphere. On the graphics side...well...I mean just look at those screenshots. Everything is hand drawn and the whole game is absolutely beautiful. Every single pixel in this game is gorgeous, the animations, the locations, the characters, the effects, everything.[list][/list]
- Characters: The basic idea is that there are plenty of passengers on your boat and you get to know them more and more. There are a few characters who will be more active and some who will just have a quick and simple story. Their personalities , however, are the absolute best things for me in this game. As you get to know them more, you will learn their background, their interactions with Stella (the protagonist) and it is all executed perfectly. BUT, I think in order to enjoy this game, a recommendation is to be open to other people's personalities, getting to know their point of view of the world, being open to what they are about to say and enjoying deep, personal conversations, stories and tragedies on some occasions. I am really into this kind of stuff and we had so many late night conversations with my wife just about the characters, trying to figure them out more and more. If this sounded interesting to you, I think you can safely buy this game. The main part that really got us with the characters though is how real they felt. In the artbook the developers talk about real life inspirations for characters and they added a bit more backstory to the creation of the characters, but we could already feel playing the game that these characters really do feel like people. For me this is so incredibly rare that I don't think I ever experienced this in any other game on this level. I know there are plenty of games with interesting and compelling characters but I never felt them being so human like in this game.[list][/list]
- Story: The reason I didn't talk about Stella in the previous point is because she is the story pretty much. It is her journey and I really want to avoid all spoilers, so all I want to say is that the story is absolutely wonderful. If you are willing to play through a very emotional game, then there is a good chance that you are going to cry at the end. The whole “story” is simple, but fits perfectly with the smaller adventures of the characters. There is no real story here to be honest, it really is just people talking about their lives.
[list][/list]
These are the reasons why this is by far one of my favourite games of all time. I am sooooo glad that they added coop with the cat (who is the CUTEST THING EVER and Daffodil is one of the cutest cat names I've heard), because experiencing this game together with my wife made it so much better. This was a very memorable game for both of us, one that we refer to regularly whenever we can.[list][/list]
The only thing I am sad about is that I could only experience this game once as I think there isn't replay value in it at all.
