I don't want to go too in-depth about the story as it ruins a lot of the more though-provoking aspects of this game. You are essentially given the title of Charon, the ferrymen to the afterlife. You are tasked with helping those you find to crossover to the other-side. You learn their stories along the way as well as their likes and dislikes before taking them to the afterlife after they feel content, or unable to cope, with their current state of being.

The majority of this game is indeed resource farming. There's a lot of it. Luckily it's a lot of different things that don't feel unnecessary but I understand the feeling of it getting boring towards the end of the game.

If you have any shred of empathy or have had to deal with the death of a loved one; at least one story in this game will hit you right in the feels. It's hard to play this game, see the stories of others, ferry them to the other-side, and not end up crying. But it's cathartic in a way. The way it weaves topical discussions of existential crisis in what is essentially a glorified resource management platformer is second to none.

There is a lot more to this story that you uncover while playing this game. It's not the most complex game and it definitely won't take up all of your time but it's a very good game that will probably leave you crying at the end.

This is one of the most moving games I think a person could play.
From organizing the buildings on your boat, to crafting things for your passengers. This game is so emotional as each passenger is a spirit you take care of. Each spirit is FULL OF CHARACTER, that its so charming! some characters have their flaws or rather all of them but they have their bright side as well. Some characters made me angry others made me feel comforted. 
Each spirit gives you tasks to do while traveling all around this purgatory world, and whats so cool is that the environments never get old. The tasks you do could vary from just having to confront other characters to resolve conflicts, exploring, crafting, or more unique request, such as just bringing them to a place they want, in order to explore past memories. 

But on top of all of this, the best part is that you can HUG EACH SPIRIT YOU TAKE CARE OF. 
IT SO ADORABLE. Some spirits are hesitant to show affection but appreciate and return the love, others just wrap their arms around you. 

The music (wonderfully made by MaxLL) was done so well that the melody is so memorable, from characters themes, different cities and environments, various activities like fishing, farming, weather (sunny, rain, snow), and finally the end. The song that plays when you help a spirit move on from the after life. It's the main lesson from the entire journey. This is a game about death after all. 

SPOILERS AFTER THIS POINT

After finishing all the tasks, giving your hugs, and food to your spirit friends, they ask to be brought to a place called the ever door a place where they move on to the afterlife. And the word Bittersweet would be an understatement. Because its inevitable, you can't progress the game without letting some spirits move on, but it hurts just as much as when someone passes away. But that is like life, it happens and its going to be rough, but life moves on. 

You row them to the everdoor, they say their last words giving off their wisdom, or a reflection on everything. and finally they glow bright, float up and disappear. The music really does a great job at a punch in a gut because of how memorable it is. The moment you hear it, you accept that when you bring them to the everdoor, thats it. 

But some spirits don't get to have a satisfying ending. For example you meet this one spirit Frog named Atul, his ending wasn't at the ever door, you just wake up one day after a great night of having a feast with everyone, and he's gone. up in the sky as a constellation. Or Stanley a mushroom spirit who is 8 years old, near his end, his innocence is lost, realizing the world isn't sunshine and rainbows 24/7, what hurts the most is that he expresses fear, he didn't want to go. He was too young, yet death came after him anyways. Or an old grandma Hedgehog who experiences dementia and doesn't even recognize you, the one who's been taking care of her since you found her. 
And then the grand finale, you. 
The music is different. its similar but at the same time its a song made specifically for you, in the end of your journey. the character Stella, (Who you play as) doesn't say anything. She just accepts her fate and hugs her cat Daffodil, and its the same ending, they glow bright, disappear and become a constellation in the sky. 
Finishing the game after 57 hours, it was worth it, to know what its like to face the unknown, learning to let go and move on, appreciating the time you spent with these wonderful characters, and so much more. I'm not gonna lie, I cried a LOT during this game, but I want the developers to know they did an OUTSTANDING job at creating such a cozy game, with so much life into it. so thank you so much for helping not only me but so many other people to think about, what will we leave behind?

Please buy this game and see what the journey is like for yourself. Because if you like taking care for others, this game rewards you for doing so, but never forget, everyone has a different ending.

This game blindsided me like a brick to the face while asleep. Going into this blind made this a beautifully fresh experience and it quickly became an all-time favorite for me. This game deserves all the love it's ever gotten and more. More people in this world need to play and experience this game.

I finally crossed the Everdoor. 

I honestly don't know why I did this to myself, as someone who struggles a lot with letting loved ones go especially my friends that I adore so much, this game brought me to experience different journeys and endings of the characters.

Atul was one of my favorite spirits, he's like your typical cool uncle who'd let you play outside when it rains, and defend you when you get in trouble. I did everything I could to make him stay happy with giving him hugs and food he loved, but it broke my heart when he suddenly left the ship without telling me. He was just gone and then there was a new spirit flower in his room.

I also didn't love some of the spirits' personalities. I had 2 or 3 spirits that I wanted to bring to cross the Everdoor so soon when they arrived. And the way that the elders spirits started to slowly forget everything when it neared their time to go also saddened me.

My favorite spirit was Stanley. He was a weird kid, loved to play around, hated veggies and fruits, and he was lonely because everyone was mean to him. His pet bug was the only friend he had, which he told us to take care of after he's gone. He was like your adorable little brother that you'd protect at all costs, even from his own family that is mean to him. I released all spirits in time except him (and Bucky whom is apparently not releasable). I just had to hold some time before I finally went to the Everdoor to release Stanley. Also the part when he cried before he went down the ship was adorable. 

Overall, Spiritfarer is a sad and heartwarming game about death and farewell that you could play for hours after a hard day at work. It is relaxing, the art and music are gorgeous, the story is not heavy but it shows you the slice-of-life of the characters, and the mechanism is great for a platform game. You could do a lot of things, but there might be a little control difficulty when you need to finish some mini games because you have to jump between platforms quickly. It's not very grindy too compared to the games I usually play. Personally I found it to be not difficult! :]

TL;DR - loved the storyline, hated some of the gameplay.

PROS: Dialogue is well written (mostly) with an engaging storyline.  Novel concept ferrying spirits to their "final rest" after you help them resolve some issues.  Spirits all have their own personalities, which can be both entertaining and occasional annoying. Some fun with working out which meals they don't mind, hate, and absolutely love.  You may get attached to some of the spirits.  There's some fun of growing crops and otherwise creating materials you need as you progress, and experimenting with various recipes.  Developing your relationship with the spirits is rewarding, and I personal found also really painful that the Bridge (someone on the boat is cutting onions, I am NOT crying).

CONS: The mini-games in the beginning are a basic grind.  Later on, they can be PAINFUL.  Be prepared for lots of button mashing if you manage to not get certain things (especially jumps) lined up, as you have to go back and forth and back and forth and back and forth and back and forth and back and forth and back and forth until you hit the sweet spot to make it work.  There's also button mashing to get essential crafting items, as part of the mini-games, which can be extremely tedious.  The save system is somewhat automatic, so you may want to write down what you were going to do next.  The mini-games can be painful.  Trying to get some kind of pretty/cohesive look to your boat with the buildings is nigh impossible, as they just don't really fit together; like a bad game of tetris.  Painful mini-games.  Because you're waiting to sail from location to location - which is great for you to be able to do tasks on the boat - it's a bit of a "time suck" game, in that you only plan to play for an hour, and find that 3 hours have gone past.  Did I mention that a lot of the mini-games SUCK?  Because they do. So, so, so bad.

Despite my long litany of cons (OMG I hate the mini-games), overall, this game is great.  I just wish that progress in the game wasn't so intrinsically linked to your success in button mashing mini-games

TLDR: This is a good game but it's not for everybody. Artistically it's a masterpiece but gameplay it's a basic platformer.  8/10

Pros:
- Great animations & perfect artwork
- Lots of mini-game variety
- Interesting/emotional plot and characters
- The developers truly cared to make this game something special
- The sheep shearing animation made me smile every single time

Cons:
- Character upgrades are almost non-existent to speed up repetitive tasks. You will be farming/mining/chopping/fishing/etc. slowly for 99% of the entire game so be prepared for that.
- By the time you get most useful skill/building upgrades the game is almost over.
- Heavy grinding on mini-games gets very repetitive. Prepare to replay the same mini-games a million times.
- By late game, the repetition was exhausting and I decided to end it by pushing the ending even though I still had 2 spirits left to finish (Buck & Jackie). After 35 hours of the same tasks, I was done with it
- I hated the ship layout. Almost none of the buildings fit together neatly so you have a giant mess of random platforms levels.
- The ship become cluttered with empty buildings after the spirits leave the ship. The only reason to keep buildings after Spirits leave is to trigger their minigames but this creates a cluttered mess near endgame.

People are getting upset because the game is very grindy. It's an adventure/management/crafting game, so if you don't like to grind, don't pick it up. If you however, want to experience one of the best stories written out there regardless of anything else, prepare yourself for a real roller coaster of emotions!

Let's get down to prons and cons!

+ PROS
∎ Outstanding soundtrack. Catchy, memorable and very emotional.
∎ Beautiful rich story. You embark on an adventure to help lost spirits of your friends pass on to the afterlife. You learn about their life, how they parted with this world and why they still keep clinging onto it. I don't think any other game has done it better. As you progress in the story, you learn more about the main character and her purpose as well. 
∎ The game is an artistic masterpiece in terms of 2D animation. Characters feel so natural and each island you travel to has its' own unique atmosphere and likeable characters. 
∎ Gameplay can be addictive (gamers who are used to farming and grinding will enjoy it a lot). Housing management lets you stack up the houses or place them horizontally. There are lots of possibilities to choose from, and the more spirits you meet, the bigger your boat becomes!
∎ Lots of side quests, so you will always find something to do.
∎ The game can be completed within 50 hours, and that's upon going for all the achievements. It's totally worth the full price for the story you get. If you can get it on sale, even better!

- CONS
∎ If you stop paying attention to what the spirits share with you, or you're bad at reading between the lines, the game can become a bit confusing at times. 
∎ Gameplay does get very repetitive after a while as it forces you to farm for the materials in order to upgrade spirits' houses/shops to tick off quest objectives they give you. If you're not into grinding and you tend to get bored easily, skip this game.

[h1] A Life Lesson Disguised As A Game. [/h1]

I have a phobia called Thanatophobia which is the EXTREME fear [i] of death. [/i] Since exposure therapy for death would be [i] VERY [/i] hard to accomplish, I used this game to help introduce me to the idea that dying will be a peaceful process... And it worked! My panic attacks lowered significantly and I began to enjoy life for what it is, life. 

The visuals are absolutely breathtaking. I have found myself crying because of the beautiful visuals and animation. The amount of character put into every single location, NPC, item, quest... Anyone who has an appreciation for a beautiful story must play this game.

Never thought a game could bring me to tears, let alone several times! Spiritfarer is my favourite game (tied with Ori) and I wasn't expecting it to mean so much to me.

If you've lost someone really close to you and have grieved / are grieving, this game helps soothe your soul. In terms of story, without ruining your own experience and revealing too much, you're basically looking for spirits and helping them cross over. But there's more to it than you initially think.

You're also managing your boat and upgrading it, building rooms and decorating them for your spirits, exploring islands, tending to your garden, fishing, collecting items, trading, completing challenges, going for errands, etc. There are busy periods in the game, but they've also created the space for you to just enjoy the beautiful artwork, the animation and the music whenever you needed to. I've also tried to delay sending some spirits to the Everdoor coz I just couldn't deal LOL! That's how emotionally invested I was with some of them.

I think if you're someone who wants to get through a game quickly and looking for an adrenaline rush, this isn't for you. I can't tell you how many times I would just go fishing or watch the stars or listen to the musical masterpieces created for the game or cook dishes - all sorts of things instead of having Stella sleep through the night. I also made sure to hug the spirits on my boat tons of times, check how they're feeling and feed them every chance I got. 

There are moments that got repetitive or I got a bit tired of running errands or didn't want to help a spirit coz they weren't particularly interesting or nice. But the beauty of this game + the intention and story behind its creation trump everything else. 

I played Spiritfarer back in 2021 and until now, I haven't found a game that can compete with it. It remains to be my favourite game and I even bought a shirt with Stella and Daffodil on it! Of course, secretly waiting for someone to recognise them so we can talk endlessly about the game :D

Jokes aside, the art style and animation are charming, the story deals with death and closure in a beautiful way, and the music is a delight. It was recommended to me by a friend, and I couldn't be happier!

Once upon a time, somewhere on the Internet, a meme once existed saying we needed games with baby-sitting mode. A mode where you get to play games with the child you are baby-sitting and the character they play does not get damaged.

Well, if you are still looking for one, look no further than Spiritfarer. 

A beautiful and relaxing game with equally beautiful and relaxing art and music, this game makes the hours fly by in the blink of an eye. While you are not rushing around anywhere, you are definitely not being idle the entire time either. Being the Spiritfarer, you are always sailing the seas, docking only when you need to visit an island or to overcome some challenges. You are also never alone as there will be passengers onboard your ship - all of whom you are responsible for caring. You could grow crops and trees on your ship, raise animals, cook meals, smelt metals and glass, or even cut logs for crafting. 

Your day - and night - is never quiet and boring.

But while all these feel like you'd have a hectic day, no one said you needed to rush through them all at once. You are the Spiritfarer, the captain of your ship, so pace yourself at however you feel comfortable and enjoy the events that unfold around you. 

Just don't forget to keep a box of tissues within your reach as the game is very - and I mean **very** - emotional at times.

Not the game for me but I’m sure it will please a lot of people.

I liked the exploration of new islands and to find new people. In the beginning I felt I had time to enjoy the beautiful environment and fish or do whatever. 

As I got a bit deeper into the game, I started to have more chores and spent more time than I wanted trying to keep people happy, making sure the ship buildings would work well and getting resources to build more stuff.

Usually, the camera stays very far to give you a better overview of everything and one of the opportunities you get to see the art quality and animations closer are the dialogs. Unfortunately your eyes will be reading the text and not noticing the characters’ expressions.

DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME!

That is, do not play this game if you are prone to being overwhelmed by emotion at the sight of losing someone that you've grown close to. This game is all about saying "Goodbye". If you are not good at that, play this game. If you are good at it, play it anyway. The developers have put a LOT of hard work into making a charming and sweet game full of little stories that all work together to paint a larger picture that culminates in a satisfying, bittersweet ending. 

I read somewhere that the development team used important people in their own lives as inspiration for each of the characters that you help, though I haven't seen this confirmed or denied anywhere. Even still, each individual has their own story that tells you about who they were in life which aids you as you work to help them move on. 

Speaking of, helping as spirit move on is part of the main progression of the game, and you will not be able to beat it without doing this, but it is also the hardest part of playing. Knowing that you will never interact with that character again, but still remembering all the lessons they taught you about being strong, being empathetic, listening, understanding, and withholding judgement. I have a friend who, to this day, refuses to bring anymore spirits to the gate because she doesn't want to let them go. Maybe that will be you; maybe you'll bring your first spirit to the gate, have a heartwarming exchange, see them move on and only think about it fondly, you might even cry a bit. But in the back of your mind you'll know that you will never get to talk to them again, you'll miss their unique personality, you'll walk past their house every day wishing you could have one more moment. You might be overcome with regret and put the game down. 

Eventually it will pop back up in your mind and you'll remember that you never finished it. Maybe you'll push through and make it to the end of the story, maybe you won't. What matters is what you make of the time you have with each character. Above all though, my favorite thing about this game how well the lessons you learn can be applied to real life and real relationships. You will never be the same after playing this game.

I was really tossing up between give it up thumbs up or thumbs down, but i ended going with thumbs down despite me actually finishing the game. The initial several hours was actually fun, with lots of exploring, figuring new mechanics out, and unlocking more spirits to take onboard. However in the latter half of my playthrough, the gameplay loop got tedious, slow and incredibly frustrating when you get stuck. You will likely spend hours just lost as to where to go next, and coming up against walls where you know what you need to do, but stuck in a catch 22 situation where one goal requires another goal to be completed, which cannot be completed because you need to complete the first goal. You only get into those situations because you may have missed something hidden somewhere, and you need to go online to look up guides. There were a couple other ones later on that took my interest, but most character backstories weren't super interesting. One of the issues about this was that the dialogue went on and on, and I ended up just spamming X and skim reading the dialogue, a lot of which seem to just be filler dialogue that doesn't really go into their story.

This game is so gorgeous. It feels incredibly polished. The platforming is smooth and I encountered few bugs playing through it.

But this game *way* over stays its welcome. At 30% completion I was already starting to feel the grind. There's a lot of busywork, carting back and forth between the islands running meaningless and disconnected errands. Normally I don't mind that sort of thing, but everything in the game is so darn slow it gets pretty tedious after a while. Every action you take on the boat has these delightful animations, but after the twentieth time shearing your sheep you might wish for a way to fast forward and get it over with. In order to view the map and plot a course you have to go into the cabin, but you're not allowed to even view your map at night. Even the fast travel is a headache. You have to plot a course to the closest "bus" stop, hop off your boat to talk to the guy, watch a prolonged animation, hop back on your boat, and run back to the cabin to select your destination. Hopefully night doesn't come around during this process, otherwise you'll have to watch another animation while you go to sleep until dawn or putter around on the boat until you can start moving again.

A lot of the writing in the game actually comes off as surprisingly cynical. Most of the characters are whiny and entitled, acting like they're doing you a favor by being on your boat. None of the people show much in the way of character growth, acting out the same harmful patterns even in the afterlife. They might show the slightest glimpse of reflection as you paddle them to the spirit door, and that's about it. I gather there's some message about unconditional love and acceptance, but it gets a little tiresome after a while trying to serve a bunch of ungrateful people. It starts to make Stella seem a little ignorant and vacuous, hugging and accommodating people who are actively antagonizing her and others on the boat. I was generally pretty happy to offload them when they were ready to go.

Other gripes:

* The farming and resource management piece doesn't have much depth and doesn't leave much room for creativity. It mostly just clutters up your boat, making it hard to navigate during challenges and often a pain to find the room or person you're looking for. It makes me wonder if it wouldn't have been a better game by leaving out that piece entirely.
* Accessibility: I'm a relatively well abled person, but I found the text hard to read even on a large TV screen.
* 2 player: I tried playing it with my son, and the 2 player experience was mostly just frustrating. The way the game zooms out when players move away from each other, the way the screen goes dark when one player is in a room, and the way you can't even see yourself when you get too far apart. It's even harder to read text on the screen, and can be really hard to even figure out where your character is at.

Spiritfarer is more than just a game - it's a deep reflection on life, death, and farewells. It teaches us to value the journey, not just the destination. This game stays with you after the credits roll, touching your heart and encouraging you to appreciate life's fleeting moments. If you're searching for a game that moves beyond fun to touch your soul, Spiritfarer is a perfect choice.

I feel comfortable recommending this game to anyone who is patient with dull mechanics in order to experience exceptional story content.
The character writing is fantastic and could only come from people experienced with death. For some people, I imagine this game's subject matter will greatly enrich their perspective and help them emotionally access this topic in a way movies or books can't. You'll be encountering a range of perspectives on loss and death presented in a completely unpretentious way. After personally talking to a few people who were dying, I can say these characters are written in a mature way that rings true to me.
The characters might lash out at you in fear, or ask you to participate in their self deception, for example. The game trusts that you have the emotional maturity to navigate that uncomfortable dynamic.Dying people don't necessarily contain wisdom in their final moments, but if you keep an open mind you might still learn from them.
Mechanically, Spiritfarer is NOT interesting enough to entertain for it's duration. Don't go in expecting a platformer or interesting logistics or something like that. The busywork you're tasked with is probably best thought of as calm periods where you're reflecting on the big emotional moments in the game. If you're not someone patient enough to "tolerate" that busywork, I recommend you don't play this game.
I imagine most people will get the most enjoyment out of the first 20 hours, and their interest will drop off as their attention to the mechanics starts to wane.
Still, what's here seems completely unique and probably very valuable to a lot of people. Wishlist it if it's too pricey, because it goes on sale every once in a while.

Spiritfarer is a visually beautiful and sentimental story with an interesting cast of characters, but with a very monotonous and sometimes dull gameplay. I first heard about the project from the first trailer, where I was hooked from the first seconds by the visual design and gameplay in the dynamics of the trailer. It was interesting to play this product.

  And after 47 hours of gameplay and passing all the available quests, not just the main story, I can say that the gameplay is not the strongest side of this project, as it is monotonous and aimed not so much at the exciting problem solving, but more on the atmosphere and the relationships between the characters. But even despite the different characters, which are revealed through their extensive monologues, the essence comes down to the execution of their quests and extraction of the necessary resources. Perhaps I am not the target audience of this project, but after spending a few days in the game, I can say that the game can get boring, even in terms of passing the main story. At some point I want to finish the game as soon as possible and not go back to fulfill the whims of the spirits and the resumption of resources through a huge number of mini-games, simply because there is no exciting alternative game in this project, unfortunately.   Despite the minuses of gameplay, I want to say THANK YOU to the visual artists and designers of this project for the work done and detailed world.   

You have to understand that Spiritfarer is first and foremost about the visually beautiful story, relationships and emotions and secondly the gameplay, where you need to chill out, enjoy the everyday things and sometimes strain your brain on how to solve certain problems, because the game does not give you readable hints.

As an art experience, Spiritfarer is a very calming and beautiful game. I was super charmed from the get-go by the animation and the music. The premise was good and I liked the gameplay loop that was being presented. The main tonal theme of "moving on" I found especially engaging.

As a game experience, it really falls flat after 3-4 hours. There is so much dialogue and it's honestly not very high quality. Often a cutscene will start and characters will talk to each other about something that has nothing to do with the world or the story, but just to very obviously flesh out their character, which is fine except that for many of the spirits on the boat these single cutscenes are the ONLY times they have character moments until the end of their story. The spirits never interact or have conflict with each other, which I think is a result of the non-linear style of the game resulting in different players having different spirits on board at the same time in the story. As a result - the ship actually begins to feel quite empty. Accidental dialogue lines repeat infinitely. Dialogue for receiving a meal, a hug, a gift, is identical per spirit every time. The happiness stat doesn't actually make them happy. Spiritfarer desperately needed more time spent on writing for these characters, and a stronger creative editor to cut down on the huge number of unnecessary conversations.

As a technical achievement, I don't think the game was tested quite enough, which is kind of surprising for a game that has been re-released as a "GOTY Edition" kind of deal - you really expect major bugs and design oversights to have been fixed with a re-released title. I found two different softlocks in my first 4 hours of play, the most glaring being jumping off the front of the ship into the water when we hit an iceberg and came to a stop. The iceberg indicator had an arrow pointing off to the right of the screen so I'd thought that there would be a minigame there like many of the other events that function similarly. My character fell in the water behind the iceberg and was completely stuck, not able to move or even open the pause menu. I understand a screen for reporting bugs in a massive 3D world like Subnautica. Here - just put an invisible wall if the player isn't meant to jump there.

Critique aside, I think most people will enjoy Spiritfarer a lot. I HUGELY enjoyed my first few hours. I recommend it, on a deep sale. I just think it's a shame that it didn't get the polish that I think it deserves.

Spiritfarer is a curious management-platformer hybrid that’s good, but short of greatness. Unlike other reviewers, I found its narrative to be too uneven and lacking in interactivity to be deeply moving. The visuals and the music are fantastic, but while the gameplay features many thoughtful touches, there was also a little too much friction and incoherence for it to completely gel for me.

Silent protagonist Stella begins the game dumped rather unceremoniously in Charon’s shoes as a guide of souls to the afterlife. It seems you’re already in a kind of purgatory, and the recently-departed must attend to their unfinished business before passing through the “Everdoor” to what lies beyond. So you set about pottering about the game world on your boat, amassing resources to please these pushy spirits, platforming around the 2D levels which form Spiritfarer’s islands, gathering the usual planks, ores and foods, and reading the spirits’ rather inconsistent dialogue. Spiritfarer describes itself as “cosy,” which I think refers to its whimsical atmosphere and the absence of a fail state. Resources are only expended upon progressing the storyline, not consumed in your voyaging. This renders the management side of the game a little grindy, though it is relaxing, if you’re in the mood for that.

While Spiritfarer grants you some freedom to explore new areas and search off the beaten track for hidden chests, the main thrust of the campaign is surprisingly linear. Regions of the world are gated behind ship upgrades which in turn require you to complete storylines, while abilities necessary to advance are likewise locked behind recruiting a small number of available spirits. Soft-locking progression seems a surprising direction to take in a game that would seem so well-suited to freeform problem-solving. The campaign gives you an abundance of recipes to cook, ingots to smelt and sauerkraut to pickle, but little of it impacts substantially on the core gameplay, and new resources tend to be used a couple of times at a particular stage of the campaign, then forgotten.

All of this platforming and resource-management is in service to the requests of the game’s spirits, with a couple of imaginative ones but mostly along the lines of “bring me this resource” and “travel to this location.” Progression allows Stella to learn more of their stories before finally bidding farewell at the Everdoor. Spiritfarer’s tone is a distinctly indie muddle of solemn, snarky and meandering; the game’s avoidance of anything scary or excessively dark feels a little at odds with the theme of death. 

The cast is well-written, with a diverse selection of characters, though rarely straying too far from one-note sweet old ladies, incorrigible rogues, kindly uncles and the like. Questlines can occasionally be opaque, or even bugged. I had difficulty triggering dialogue for Gwen and Alice, though got there with perseverance and the wiki, and was crushed to have Atul’s final quest misfire completely, due to a previous character’s departure. The writing isn’t great at responding to player actions; nor do spirits interact with one another, and too often attempts to enquire about backstories are met with another request for food or a minor gift. Interactions overall can feel creaking and flat compared with masters of dynamic, reactive ensemble dramas like Hades and even the classic Baldur’s Gate. Beyond the core cast there’s a sprawling mass of anonymous and identical spirits with lots of whimsical dialogue, some of which I found overlong and, frankly, tiresome. Stella herself is depicted as a child, which given some the relationships that are hinted at by older characters, seems strange. Her story becomes more clear as the game wears on, but she remains an anonymous cipher for too long. Individual dialogues and story beats certainly still deliver an emotional payload, but both the world and the characters’ place within it felt to me rather indistinct. Characterising Stella, making the script more responsive to player actions and the game state, or adding more meaningful dialogue options, might all have helped Spiritfarer feel less weightless.

The visuals, however, are stunning, a gorgeous example of the indie tradition of reinventing classic cel animation for gaming. Capturing something of the golden age of American animation, Spiritfarer’s visuals could easily go toe-to-toe with the likes of The Banner Saga and Klei, which have turned out wonderful reimaginations of classic 2D art styles for contemporary gaming. The sound, and especially the music, are also fantastic. Lush strings, mellow piano-plinks and jazzy brass all give each area of the world a distinct feel. This is definitely a soundtrack I’ll enjoy returning to outside the game. Developer Thunder Lotus’s musicians and visual artists deserve major props for producing such a charismatic and well-realised vision of the afterlife-as-half-remembered-childhood-animation.

Overall, Spiritfarer offers an unusual blend of management-sim, 2D platformer and interactive fiction that didn’t quite come together for me, wrapped up in a sumptuous audio-visual feast, and with a generous single-player campaign. Despite the nitpicking, Spiritfarer is well worth your time, and evidently the work of a talented and passionate team. Its ambition perhaps exceeds the final level of polish and artistic coherence. If you’re after well-executed interactive fiction with a melancholy vibe, I recently loved both the more modest Mutazione and Eliza, while Cultist Simulator offers an incredibly deep – and strange – masterclass in writing and world-building for video games. For a stellar single-player adventures with fantastic ensemble casts, don’t miss hack-and-slash roguelike Hades, or the Spiritfarer-adjacent Potionomics, which pairs a much deeper and more satisfying management challenge with a vibrant aesthetic and similarly sublime art.

It is both a form of afterlife, reliving one's memories until one's final days, and of letting go. And, of course, it made me want to cry until I had no more tears.

You will come to fall in love with the spirits you carry on your boat, and you will not want to watch them leave. But the process of them leaving is so beautiful you will do so anyway. The lives they lived and the memories they recant will live on through you, the player. The flowers that they represent, individual to each spirit, are carried on their final bed. Until, inevitably, you yourself pass through the gateway.

我的朋友们全都不喜欢这个游戏，但是我超爱！比起传统意义上的操作类游戏其实本作更偏体验向，但是又避免了许多文字类游戏的不真实感或局限性，更像一个海上星露谷物语，还不用担心体力值为零。当然本作跟星露谷物语的区别还是很大的，种田是手段，跟灵魂交流才是目的（？），而且以各种动物的形态出现，很好地避免了我对人型生物时不时出现的厌恶感，比起一个明艳高傲的大美人，当然还是一个有着美丽长角的毛茸茸鹿姐姐Gwen更能打动所有人。
所有灵魂的故事和性格都是通过一件件委托和时不时冒出来的小对话自己一点点品味出来，对我来说也非常tasty，每个灵魂都有非常鲜明又不同的性格，在他们身上你能看到自己家人，好友，邻居各种各样熟悉又陌生的过路人的身影，在普通又熟悉的表面下又有着独属于个人的挣扎纠结，和解或者没能和解。我很感动于制作者对死亡的思考，和对濒死之人内心深入地挖掘和理解，年轻有为的肺癌患者，挣扎多年的抑郁症病人，出生后不久就离开的小孩，他们的困惑和遗憾，他们的执着和迷茫，而这一切都不是制作者告诉你的，而是你在与他们的交往中感知到的，“我不是让您描绘大天使来时的那场大雨，而是请您用一场大雨把我淋湿”，而我很荣幸确确实实被淋湿了。
总的来说这是一个节奏很慢的，休闲风的，画风简洁可爱，细节超多，玩久了会忍不住哭的超级棒的作品。你会成为命运选中的“The One”，你有一艘自己船，你有一只无论被困在悬崖还是掉进海里都不离不弃跟着你的猫（本作的玄幻的地方也在于此），你有一只可以遮住整个人的魔法大帽子，你可以开着船在海上转来转去，钓鱼，做饭，在船上种地，养羊，喂牛，孵小鸡，寻找宝藏，拜托，这也太酷了！

This game really tugs at your heartstrings. Without giving away too much, you really get to know some of these characters and start to feel for them - especially as you learn why some of them are on your boat, how they got there, and why they have the requests they do. 
It's a great blend of adventure, cozy, rpg, and open world gaming. A bit of resource management thrown in there, too.
Sometimes it feels a bit grindy to get all of the resources you need for certain upgrades, or to remember to socialize in all three ways with each person on your boat, but I suppose that's part of the challenge.
Overall, I'd definitely recommend the game, but please be warned that there are sensitive topics that are covered in this game (suicide, abuse, terminal illness, etc.). Just keep that in mind and maybe just do a little bit of further research if you're worried anything may be triggering.
In conclusion, it's a heavy game that gives you many moments of light and levity to balance out the serious moments, and can even be cathartic at times to go through the time on the ship with each of your people.

Being cheap as always, I was scanning specials, and came across this gem at just the right time in my life. I know it's uncool to trama-dump online, so I won't be too specific, but my brother (who I share a house with) has recently been diagnosed with terminal cancer...

Back to the review: This game fit a lot of little niches I like in smaller games. Resource/time management, base building, exploration, and a subtle story that requires some brains/paying attention to fully grasp exactly what's going on. The best part of these elements is the gameplay loop is as YOU make it! Getting bored listening to NPCs blab at you? Go explore! Not sure where to go? Go back to NPCs to tie up loose ends. You are never forced to do anything until you want to. Which is good because this also happens to be one of those management games where you don't have enough time in the day to do everything, and that would normally drive me nuts!!!

Best part of this game: This game deals with sensitive themes, yet (thankfully) isn't heavy-handed with it. Also, most games that deal with death have an annoying tendency of having one dimensional characters where they focus on nothing but positivity. Here characters flaws are put on center stage, making them much more relatable. Not once did an interaction feel forced, and eye-roll worthy. It's a truly rewarding experience that will have you coming away from it with an appreciation for even the smallest things.

Worst part of this game: There are a lot of mechanics to learn, even into the late game. The way they are tutorialized makes sense at first, but can easily become one of those situations where, because you didn't do things in a certain order, you now have to teach yourself a newly introduced mechanic. What the game doesn't tell you is if you're having a hard time grasping what a certain thing does, there are full explanations in the options menu.

If the games' tags don't interest you, then skip this one. Otherwise, this game is worth every penny! Especially if you are dealing with hard times, or just miss someone really badly...

I am genuinely scared of playing this game. Not out of primal fear, but out of the fear as to how hard this game will impact me emotionally. I am so fragile with these topics,and i want to talk about why.
Spiritfarer is a game about letting go of those who are truly close to you,and caring for those in death. You play as Stella, a silent-ish protagonist who takes the role of the spiritfarer, one who assists those who have died by fulfilling wishes and making sure those who have died and have not moved on completely to the afterlife.
Now for why i am so scared.
Stella's story when it comes to lily absolutely killed my heart. From beginning to end she was always incredibly outgoing and passionate to help those in need. In the beginning lily always said that she outshone and outpaced her,and all of that. 
She was great with socializing,and all of that. Eventually moving to japan for a while, and writing a heartfelt letter back to her family. But during the trip,the family never told her about the sickness of her father. When she had came home, lily described her as "not even recognizing her own father anymore" and all of that. But she stayed with him until the end. This also lead to her nursing job,caring for those in their last few moments,hours,days,weeks,or months even. Meeting jackie,  who she enjoyed around but also daria,who she dearly enjoyed, having even snuck art supplies in for her,
She works there for a good while,and stuff. 
Then the main thing that happened. 
Stella is diagnosed with a unknown disease that leads her to becomin g frail,getting off work for a few months with bad news, calling lily, with her claiming that she was schizo rambling about the trees and the air. Lily had to call the center for her work, as to why she took work time off. Two-ish weeks after finding out, she calls lily. with a shaky, heavy voice going on about the trees and the air continuously. Talking about how it felt like death over there with lily saying she didnt know where "over there" was. with a silence, eventually broken with the statement of her coming home in "a few days". With how lily struggled with her father's death via alcoholism and all of that,she was scared a good bit by this too. 
Leading to more. the scene before stella's final voyage. With both her mother [i think rose,i really hope atleast some dev sees this] and lily by her side,with her laying in the hospital bed and lily talking about how much she loves her and that theres no need for loneliness anymore, or even that she never was alone. Something about it just kills my heart.  the realization that the family left is grasping for whatever hope they have and all of that, or just saying their final goodbyes. Ive never lost someone close to me,but this game really has me thinking alot about it. i guess i lose a lot of friends and i see that some people as of recent have been losing a lot of people close to them. It has me wondering as to who i will have by my bed, if i ever succumbed to an illness. it has me wondering if ill even have someone by that bed. and i fear the feeling of dread it gives me.
And thats why this game is so efficient. it is a game about learning how to say goodbye, even if your not ready to say goodbye. Stella being taken early despite being mid-30s, especially by illness and with some of her closest friends, and her having faced down the hell that was hades [a dark part of stella's subconcious,iirc] and all of that, she had to eventually come to terms with her own fate. that she was not going to recover,but she was going to have to follow charon into the everdoor. what could have been hundreds of nights bringing comfort and safety to lost souls who could have been stuck in the afterlife/spirit world were maybe hours for her in real life. Maybe it was a dream or something,maybe it actually happened. 
I love this game so fucking much. i cant get over the underlying sadness with each passing day in the game. I love all of it. and i cant properly put all of it into words right now because of the fear of something i dont know how to describe right now. its beautiful.

I bought this game initially for my boyfriend thinking it was a single player game. Much to our surprise it had local coop, so we opted for that and both sat down to play with no real expectations for what the game would be. 

I played the little cat (who's animations, especially the glide) are absolutely adorable and well-thought out. While the second player can't do everything the main player can do (only one person interacts with the actual progress and story) you can help fully with all the exploring, tasks, mini platform games and puzzles. I actually really prefer that you both drive the story together and it forces you to interact and progress together. I should mention as well, this game is not hard mechanically- but it never feels boring or lacks a challenge in terms of what you need to prioritise or the content it introduces as you progress. Anyone could pick up this game and enjoy the play through - and I think that's fantastic game design. 

The game itself is beautifully made. Everything fits perfectly together, the music, character stories, overall execution of themes is done so well. I read reviews before purchasing talking about making peace with the grief they've experienced in their life, and as someone who lost their Mum at 25 it shows such a peaceful side to death, especially learning that the characters you meet and get to know eventually make their peace with it themselves. The entire game is very moving and emotional, I would be very surprised if it doesn't move you in some shape or form. 

I can't think of a single game that does with Spiritfarer does. My biggest sadness is that this game will eventually end as it's set such a high standard for future games that I play. I couldn't recommend this more, whether you play through alone or grab a friend or loved one to play it through with. I don't know who wouldn't appreciate the little details included in this game (was so excited to see some of the characters mention other games or DnD references for example!) 

I hope they bring out more games like this in the future (or if anyone has any recommendations for similar games I'd love to hear them!)

[h1]💭 First Impressions:[/h1]
Spiritfarer is a game that at first glance can be mistakenly compared to Harvest Moon/Story of Seasons games, but in 2D. These similarities are merely superficial at best.

Something that has to be said before anything else: [i]this game oozes charm[/i]. The graphics are beautiful, every character has very fluid animations that are a joy to watch, for instance: Stella’s unamused face never fails to, ironically enough, amuse me. And when you combine everything with the alluring soundtrack, it makes for a soothing gameplay experience that doesn’t tire the player.

There is no combat or any sort of battle mechanics in this game. Spiritfarer is advertised as a relaxing experience and it is one through and through, aided by the fact there’s hardly any need to rush, and no way to get a “game over''.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2807423312

[h1]🎮 Controls:[/h1]
There are no complex commands or inputs in this game, everything is kept simple and the controls are very responsive, which helps in the platforming sections you have to do.

It might be also worth noting you can easily play this game (literally) with one hand using the keyboard.

The cat, Daffodil, that tags along with Stella can be controlled by a second player. Co-op is normally only local/splitscreen, but there is the Steam Remote Play option too.

[h1]🧭 Traveling and learning:[/h1]
One of the earliest things you’ll learn is how to sail across the immense sea presented before you. While your ship is en route to its destination you are free to do whatever you want: work on the resources on your ship, tend to the necessities of the ones on it, or nothing at all.

At night you won’t be able to sail or interact with the ones residing in it, you can keep working, or you can go to sleep until the next morning to quickly resume your journey.

During your travels you’ll also find new abilities for Stella. All of them will unlock more possibilities and maybe even allow you to visit areas you couldn’t previously reach in a way not unlike Metroidvanias.

[h1]🎒 Gathering…[/h1]
As mentioned previously, it’s easy to think this game is a 2D Farming Sim. While it does give you the option to grow your plants and vegetables and tend to animals, those are not your main options to earn glims (your currency) in your ship.

Speaking of which, your ship is essentially a floating town where you can build houses and other types of workshops to refine raw resources you’ll gather in the wild.

You can get resources by traveling across the seemingly endless sea and finding desert or populated islands or through mini-events unique to each “tenant” residing in your ship-town.

Logging, mining, fishing… All of those actions require more than just pressing and holding a button and even when it does it demands some attention to when you must release the action button or to the rhythm you must follow. Every action taken to get something feels meaningful, but it isn’t enough of a chore that will leave you mentally tired if you have to gather a lot of one or two specific resources.

The best thing? There’s no pesky stamina limitation here, you are free to get everything to your heart’s content.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2808063145

[h1]💎 ... and Refining:[/h1]
Most items, collected or bought, have to be refined in one of the many structures you must build. 

For some buildings the process is automatic, requiring you only to tune a machine and wait for it, but for many others it demands your personal attention. All these activities, again, are unique ranging from mindless button mashing to carefully timed actions and for tougher, higher graded materials said activities will be more difficult.

Mercifully, the penalty for messing up certain refining activities isn’t losing the resource entirely, but just getting less of the refined item.

Again, you can work as much as you want, restricted only by your resources (and patience), or lack thereof.

[h1]💮 Keeping the spirits up:[/h1]
You’ll meet many spirits that need your help and guidance with their troubles. Some of these spirits are more friendly than the others. Some are open and receptive, while others are more closed off and untrusting.

When these spirits accept your invitation, or invite themselves in, they all have their unique looks, living preferences, food tastes and how well they get along with other spirits all affect their mood.

The spirits’ mood is very important-- you were tasked with making their afterlife as comforting as possible after all. Thankfully you have access to their information, to what is causing their mood to change, for better or for worse, and while some are obvious, others might need you to be more attentive to them.

Food is another vital element in order to keep their moods in high-spirits (pun fully intended), and while some of the spirits have a healthy appetite, others are very finicky and picky about what they’ll accept and remembering their preferences is very important.

The more you do for the spirits, the more of their tales you’ll hear and know. And all of them, without exceptions, are more than meets the eye.

[h1]🌟 The spirits' mini-events:[/h1]
Each spirit aboard will teach Stella something and most of them will unlock some type of mini-event for you to help gather glims and/or a resource unique to said mini-event.

Many of these mini-events consist of you running and gathering things before they vanish but all of them have their unique flair, just like the spirits that teach you how to deal with them. The layout of your ship might influence (a lot) how well you’ll do in them and so will the abilities Stella can learn during her journey.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2805834510

[h1]📉 Some low points:[/h1]
There are a few things to note about the gameplay.

The biggest one is having all the waiting you’ll have to do, especially at early game where you won’t have a whole lot to do and especially with how slow your ship will sail. This can be exacerbated if you need to travel back and forth to gather different resources for an upgrade, to meet someone, or even to progress in the story.

Sometimes the game also gets pretty grindy, demanding you to get a lot of rare/difficult to find items in order to keep progressing.

Being forced to go back to the Shipyard, and there only one in the whole map, to upgrade your ship, even with the fast travel, can be a pretty big inconvenience since the materials you need to get for upgrades can be VERY far from it.

[h1]💬 Conclusion:[/h1]
I’ve refrained from mentioning the story since it's so easily spoiled and I feel it's best left as something for people to experience for themselves.

As for the game: it has a good variety in its gameplay, fluid animations, great music, a cast of memorable characters-- everything was all carefully tailored to be a game that deservedly earned its praise and merits.

The game starts off great and makes you feel emotionally invested in the characters, despite having a more casual and relaxed approach to gameplay. Overall, it has an enchanting art style, a thought provoking story, lovable and quirky characters, humorous interactions with NPCs, and a captivating soundtrack. All of this is unfortunately brought down developer's inability to trim the fat to make a more engaging game rather than a longer one. 

After about 15 hours, the game becomes a slog due to all the inventory management, fetch quests, repetitive mining actions, and mindless progress dependent "mini games". All of these things really take away from any emotional impact the story could have had by mid to late game. It would be really nice if developers would put more thought into the pacing of their games. Instead of padding them to make them longer, shorten them and focus on the level of engagement throughout. This is a frequent issue with story focused games, the gameplay is often an afterthought so in turn the story and emotional impact end up suffering as well.

I guess everything already has been said about this game anyway, I mean, without question, it’s a fantastic hand-painted mix of farming/crafting, exploration and story-telling, with some (manageable) platforming and minigames strewn in. So instead let’s just address the elephant in room I think, the content. Yeah, I admit, there definitely are some heavy topics in the game, but I don’t know, it actually didn’t feel that way for me, even though I’m normally a cringe-worthy overemotional person. No, instead, the game deals with all those issues in a very subtle way, all those stories are kind of cryptic and need to be deciphered, and you often just get a glimpse of the truth when you bring them to the Everdoor. It’s all a kind of great puzzle that slowly unravels over time. Add to this the light-hearted storytelling, the funny music, the weird characters and the engaging gameplay. So for me it wasn’t depressing at all (some characters aren’t even too sympathetic), instead it was a kind of philosophic journey sometimes, about what you leave behind, about life, feeling incomplete, about your goals or purpose, about joy, about friendship and family. You get the drift. Alright, I have to admit, in between it can get a bit melancholic, but in a good way in my opinion, and always with an optimistic undertone. Even the end was a great kind of emotional wrap-up for me (and yeah, I also didn’t actually like sending the passengers on their way, but it still felt inevitable, necessary and somehow at peace).

Enough said, outstanding game, with awesome value and a long playing time (I actually even spent over 80 hours in-game, but I really checked out everything, even replayed some bits). Just try it out, after all it’s not too expensive meanwhile in sales, and even is featured in Humble Choice at the moment.

I really wanted to like this game and tried playing through it three times. The writing is clever and the visuals are gorgeous, and from what I saw in a lot of positive reviews it's a good healing experience for dealing with loss. But each time I played, I found myself stopped after a few hours because gathering resources is tedious and frustrating.

The entire process feels like it's just wasting time: the basic tasks have repetitive animations that repeat each time, the more complex ones require very precise timing or else you get fewer resources and thus have to repeat tasks [i]more[/i], and some of them have outright fail conditions and your punishment is sitting there and waiting for your character to recover.

If this were the pacing for the whole game, it would make sense, but the developers also decided to break things up with platforming. You [i]have[/i] to do some very precise jumps and maneuvers for resource gathering [i]and[/i] plot reasons, or else the game will not move forward. This wouldn't be so bad if platforming didn't feel so slippery and the character consistently followed input directions. It feels like they couldn't decide what they wanted, so they mashed the two genres together and it just doesn't work.

Even if it didn't have those issues, I don't recommend this game because of an announcement they made in February (this was after I had initially purchased it, otherwise I wouldn't have even tried to play). The devs decided to raise the price in several places to address people buying outside their region to get the game as cheap as possible. I don't know if there's an ideal solution but raising the price by over 400% in Turkey and Argentina—especially taking into account that they bring up the earthquake in Turkey in the [i]same post this price-raise was announced[/i]—is straight up greedy. I cannot, in good conscience, recommend supporting their future projects either.

While no game is perfect, Spiritfarer is, at its core, everything I think I could want from the [i]concept[/i] of a game: a deep story, told artfully, able to be engaged at multiple levels; gameplay loops which feel organic and meaningful, but with a sort of lightness to them that keeps you from having to feel frantic or burdened with tedium; eclectic design which is at once soulful and unique, yet still entirely approachable; lively writing which truly brings characters to life as unique individuals, warts and all, completely avoiding even the whiff of them being two-dimensional tropes-on-legs; a thoughtful meshing of its elements which helps the game feel like a true gestalt, rather than in any way a discombobulated frankengame; and--one which few games really can reliably, if ever, accomplish--the ability to create a panoply, a full spectrum, of thought-provoking and emotional moments for the player.

People in other reviews warn you that you will cry. They are correct. You may even ugly-cry, possibly repeatedly. But it will be a good kind, a cathartic kind, an almost startlingly real kind. A kind that most video games can only hope they might ever evoke, if they even deign to try. Even now I mist up a bit in recollection, which is impressive, for a story told about imaginary anthropomorphic spirits of people I've never actually had in my physical life.

I encourage you to visit the game's website and/or check out the artbook, which is something I don't think I've said about any game before. There are layers and threads to the game which quite subtly underlie the game (but deftly, in a way that you don't feel an inexplicable hunch that you're missing them), yet when revealed for what they truly were (as both of the above may do for you in ways the game might not), can be seen in every corner of its grand tapestry. I cannot emphasize enough how much this short, simple, mostly-not-difficult game is a sleeper masterclass in storytelling.

Others have complained about the platformer elements of the game, and these complaints are valid: the combination of camera dynamics, control schema, ability functionality, and level designs can make some parts of the game's platforming frustratingly particular. I'm not sure if this was in some way meant to be metaphorical, however, knowing what I do now about the game's deeper themes. Still, I could've enjoyed the playing of the game more without those issues--but I hope these reservations do not deter a single soul from experiencing this unique gem, because they are naught more than scuff marks.

A certain amount of "grinding" may also be necessary for completion, depending on how you go about playing the game. However, you cannot mess up the game beyond repair (this was likely intentional), so at worst, you might have to take more time than would otherwise be necessary, secondary to choices you make--but it is always still salvageable. The game will never blockade you permanently from anything crucial; at the very worst, you might miss out on a few vignettes.

While you can also tarry as long as you'd like, doing this and that (again, also likely an intentional design choice, in retrospect), the "necessary" content of the game is also fairly short; my fairly thorough playthrough still clocked under 30 hours. Whether you could or would experience replay value is entirely up to you; some stories, after all, are worth experiencing more than once. You would be hard-pressed to find an unequivocally more artful story, told as a game, than this one.

With that in mind, I believe the value for the cost is certainly there--but even if you feel you should get the game on sale, do not miss out on experiencing it, one way or another. It is rare that I can say this about any game, but I absolutely can about Spiritfarer: I firmly believe it will enrich the lives of many, if not most, who play it.

One of the most sweet yet exploratory games I've played. I was looking for something like BOTW, and this is definitely a toned down version of that. I have VERY few cons but, I will add them for review's sake!

TLDR: beautiful, fun, keeps your attention. sometimes hard to tell what to do

PROS ~
- Beautiful art (character designs, landscapes, animations, etc etc etc)
- Immersive gameplay
- Addicting (although I do get distracted easily, so maybe on me lol!)
- Story is not linear, so you can choose to ignore it and do your own thing if you want, but the story IS amazing and I would highly recommend playing for that alone.
- Extremely well-fleshed out characters, extensive research and effort has been put into them!
- Really fun for BOTW-style "see thing on map and go find it, then get distracted and go somewhere else, and end up making a list of things to check out" moments, kept me entertained % of the time!

CONS ~
- SLIIIIIIIGHTLY repetitive at times, especially between character arcs, but the fishing mechanic and stops along the way such as events really minimize this, I just thought it was worth noting!
- Sometimes hard to tell what you are supposed to be doing, but could be a pro if you like to figure things out
- Will 100% make you cry like a baby after every character's arc is complete (no spoilers!)

All in all, I absolutely adore this game and find myself coming back to it very often, I don't believe it is very replayable but it has so much content that it isn't really an issue, especially if you aren't speedrunning it lol! A beautiful game that is more than worth the money!

One of the most charming games I have played. Fluid gameplay, sweet and emotional story, great audio. It was one hell of an enjoyable experience playing this, it has a bit of everything, platforming, harvesting, resource managing, building, cooking and crafting, all of them actually well done, so many micro systems in one place I thought it cannot work that well, but I was wrong. It knows when to hit the breaks on those systems and does not push them too much, like harvesting, is not to the complexity of something like Stardew Valley; you get seeds, build a garden, plant them and occasionally water them, and that is it. Also a small advice, keep the damn sheep in pens!

Of course I had to guide all the characters to the door, enjoyed all of their story and personality, heck even Bruce and Mickey. I do wish however we got more expanded story into some of the side characters, like Charon and Hades. 

Gameplay, well it revolves around platforming. You navigate to islands, unlock powerups to reach previous inaccessible areas on then, do some back and forward, kind of a metroidvenia style. But platforming is not the focus of the game, is passing through the story and getting involved in the characters, even so, the platforming would put some games that do focus on it to shame, its fluid and precise, also you get plenty powerups to make it so much fun to move around. 

It is accompanied by great audio with some nice OSTs, so what ca I say, it does a great job immersing you in the world. 
It does have some minute flaws however, like why the heck the devs used orange font on orange background in the boat’s navigation map, you have any idea how tricky is to sometimes see the coordinates…
Overall I fully recommend this even at full price which I do not often say.

P.S. fk tuna fishing without any powerups!

Hayatlarının sonlarına ulaşmış ruhları öbür dünyaya uğurlamadan önce pişmanlıklarından, yapmak istediklerinden arındırmak. Kısaca oyunu bu şekilde tanımlayabiliriz. Topladığınız ruhların görevlerini yapmak için çeşitli malzemeler topluyor, geminize istekleri üzerine kendi evini veya başka yapılar yapıyor ve bu şekilde oyunda ilerliyorsunuz. 

[h1] Oynanış [/h1]
Tek bir çizgi üzerinde ilerlememesi güzel olmuş. İstediğiniz göreve istediğiniz önceliği verebiliyorsunuz. Ağaç kesme, maden kazımı gibi özelliklerin yanında eventimsi malzeme toplamaları da var. Tüm bunların yanında özel yetenekler de açabiliyoruz. Bunlar da sonra çeşitli adalarda daha da ilerlememizi sağlıyor. Evet, anlayacağınız kimi zaman ilgili adada işimiz bitse bile spesifik yetenekleri açtıktan sonra geri döneceğimiz anlamına geliyor. Bu durumu çok aşırıya kaçırmadıkları için yerinde buldum. Her adada geçerli olan bir durum değil.

[b]Dış Görünüşü Özelleştirme[/b]
Dış görünüşünüzü kendinize göre ayarlayabiliyorsunuz fakat seçenekler çok da fazla değil. İlerleyen zamanlarda farklı çeşitler de açabiliyor olsanız da başlarda çoğunu kullanabiliyor olsak daha güzel olabilirdi. Bunun yanında açabildiğimiz her kostüm ve bahsi geçen kostümü nasıl açabileceğimize dair birkaç detay bulunsa daha güzel olurdu diye düşünüyorum. 

[h1]Geliştirilebilecek Kısımlar [/h1]
Şimdi de gelelim rahatsız olduğum kısımlara. Yapılacak şeyler çok iyi belirtilmediği için kimi zaman ya internete bakıp çözmeniz gerekiyor ki özellikle yemek yapma gibi mekanikler bu konuda biraz yormuştu beni. Buna ek olarak bazı madenlerin pişmesi gereksiz uzun sürüyordu.

[b]Müzikler[/b]
Genel olarak müzik mantığı beni çok çekemedi. Her bir adanın kendine özel müziği var ve geminize lounge inşa ettikten sonra oradan [strike]istediğiniz[/strike] ziyaret ettiğiniz adaların müziğini seçebiliyorsunuz fakat bu neredeyse hiçbir zaman uğraşmak istediğim bir şey olmamıştı. Bunun yanında tarlanızda gitar çalarak ilgili cropların büyüme hızını arttırabiliyorsunuz. Bundaki problem de sadece bir tane parça çalıyor olması. Oyunu bitirmemin üzerinden haftalar, hatta aylar geçmiş olmasına rağmen hala aklımda. Keşke olmasa.

[b]Yolcuları Takip Etme Zorluğu[/b]
Oyunun ortalarına doğru gemimdeki ruh sayısı bir noktada o kadar artmıştı ki durumlarını takip edemiyordum. Düzgün bakabildiğim tek yer ise Everdoor'du. Her ruhun kendine özel görevleri oluyor ve bunları bitirdiğinizde Everdoor ile uğurluyordunuz kendisini. Geri kalan ruhlar da tekneye inen merdivenin yakınlarında toplanıyordu. Bir tek bu şekilde herkes ile konuşup durumlarını takip ediyordum ki gerçekten de keyif aldığım bir durumdu bu. Buna adanan bir panel veya ruhları daha iyi görmemi sağlayacak bir özellik oyuna eklenebilirdi.

[h1]Sonuç[/h1]
Genel olarak keyif aldığım bir oyundu fakat sonlara doğru sıkmaya başlamıştım. O da en azından bütün ruhları sonrasına uğurlayayım hevesiydi. Oyun, size bütün ruhları göndermeden oyunu bitirme şansı tanıyor ki keşke o şansım olduğu ilk an bitirseydim diyorum şimdiki kendime. Tabii amacınız başarımları tamamlamaksa kolay gelsin. Oyunun koleksiyon kısmına adanmış spesifik bir ada var ve belli ki bayağı bir uğraş istiyor. Benim de ilgimi çekiyor fakat ekstra bir 10 saat daha uğraşmak istemiyorum.

I wish Steam had a middle of the road button, especially for games like this. Spiritfarer is a beautifully thought out game with a stunning art style, amazing music, and the gameplay as well as the base concept of the game are extremely solid as well. When Charon retires, for reasons that are never made clear, you act as the new ferryperson to carry the souls of the dead to their... final destination? to be reborn? I'll be perfectly honest, I made it about solidly halfway through this game and maybe more questions are answered as you continue to complete the game, but I grew so frustrated with the writing and the plot that I ended up not continuing. I played it through about halfway again with a friend of mine, so I can confirm the co-op option works well, but this friend ended up having the same frustrations as me and we just never finished. We saw several spirits off to their final destinations, and frequently at the end we would look at each other and go, "Were we supposed to feel something?" It was never clear who these people were, what their motivations were, why they were there - there were even misspellings and grammar inconsistencies, which took me in particular out of the game. I think there is a balance that needs to be struck when handling a plot like this (I spoiled myself by looking up a summary and theories as to what the game was about once I determined I probably wasn't finishing the game) and I think the game just unfortunately does not strike that balance between questions and answers. 
I'm still recommending it though, because to me this does not deserve a down rating. It is clear a lot of love and effort was poured into this game, and again, the art and music and gameplay loop are excellently done. It just falls flat on the story.

I had really high hopes for the game seeing all the overwhelmingly positive reviews but unfortunately, it appears my experience was not the norm. First things first, Spiritfarer is absolutely gorgeous. The character designs and environments were a visual treat and the music truly elevated the atmosphere of the game. However, despite all the good things about it, it falls short in two areas that affected my enjoyment of the game.

Firstly, in my 20+ hours of playtime, I have barely scrapped the surface of Stella's story, and from what I am seeing, we only get to see more of it towards the end of the game. Now, I have no issue with the rest of the cast and I recognise that Spiritfarer's approach to storytelling is focused around peeling the layers off their individual stories. However, the characters do not stay long enough for me to get fully emotionally invested in them. On the other hand, Stella is with you throughout the game and it is a missed opportunity not to reward the player with more insight on her as you progress.

Secondly, the game starts becoming a chore 20 hours in. Things start to get repetitive. Run to this island to find an NPC, go to this other island to collect a material. For a group of characters so integral to the themes of the game, it felt more like I was doing side quests for them. The method to advance their stories does not do justice to the messages they wished to convey. [spoiler] For example, Atul sending you on fetch requests asking for various food items and only once you deliver them, you get exposition on what that meant to him. Summer's storyline however, was outstanding - I really loved how her mini game was a representation of her struggles and more characters could have benefited from this approach. [/spoiler] 

Overall, I would give Spiritfarer a neutral review if I could because there were still standout moments that left an impact on me. It is just a bit of a shame that it was not the case throughout.

So let me precede this review by saying I did not entirely dislike the game. A neutral review would be more accurate. I absolutely loved the first hours, but the bad outweighted the good in the end and it ended up leaving a bad taste. 
This review does contain spoilers so be warned.

Good:
[list]
[*]Graphics and music are gorgeous
[*]First half of the game was sweet
[*]Platforming felt flowy and nice
[/list]
Bad: (explained below, contains spoilers so marked as such)[list]
[*]Frustrating characters in late-game
[*]Chores get repetitive after a while
[/list]

[hr][/hr]
[spoiler][u]Characters in late-game:[/u]
Not sure if it's just the way they were written or a personal bias on my part, but while the first chatacters felt well rounded and seemed to have a closer relationship with Stella, as the game goes on there are some that feel like nothing/generic, up to the point of being frustrating. Stanley and Buck are the only two I found salvable from the latter half of the game. 

Having progression tied to "releasing" spirits is nice at first (trying to drive the point that letting go is important) but in the end it just makes it hard to bond with the spirits. This, together with the previous point about the kind of characters you find late game, makes it hard to care at all about them. First departures were sentimental, but after a while any interaction with the characters feels like just another chore. I feel like, other than Buck and Stanley (precious mushroom child), the interacions get more generic as time goes on, save of those that are entirely just rudeness directed at your character (I get that it comes from your backstory but being rude cannot be your whole personality), which I honestly do not care for. 
Additionally, the NPCs/background spirits feel kind of empty. And, finally, there is almost no payoff for any of the tasks; either you —rarely— get a throwayay line that gives you a glimpse into the character or you release them. I understand that the objective of the game is to "let them go", but by the end I was unable to feel attachment to the chatacters, just going through their tasks to get them off the boat. Did not get to meet tha bat person because by that time, after Bruce+Mickey, Elena, and Jackie, I had already given up (don't @ me, I do not care). I am sure the bat person is lovely if you are patient enough to get there but by this point I had no more energy.

[u]Chores and travel[/u] 
As a note, I feel that this game should be considered more a collectathon than a management game, regardless of what tags say. I believe this is another factor to my frustration with the game. The missions and chores ended up feeling... well, like a chore. The travel and crafting/resource collection system, while fine at first, ends up just becoming annoying, just a non-stop clicking minigame + fetch quest for no pay-off. I feel like if the upgrade system was different (variation of the minigames/some automation, not just difference in output) it could be better, but it's hard to keep the player's attention when having to just repeat a task over and over again (just spam the button! Fun). The game is gorgeous and the design of the different areas is nice, but towards the end the map feels a bit same-y, and the simple dialogues make you give up (yes, I gave dating advice to a character, but other than that and the tour guide they all feel like nothing. Even after trying to talk to every spirit you run into they just feel, excuse the pun, soul-less) [/spoiler]

In short: this beautiful game immediately caught my attention, as the themes are really interesting and the exploration of grief as the basis for a game sounded really promising.
I appreciate what the game was going for, but I feel like it fell short and ended up being frustrating. I continued playing hoping it would have some of the spark from the first half, but I am afraid that is not going to happen. I was reticent to give it a negative review because I loved the first hours of it, but at this point the tedium has set in and I do not believe I will go back to complete the achievements. Overall I am sorry to give it a 5/10.

A beautiful and unique adventure through what it means to grieve and let loved ones go.            Game Quality: 10/10 - No bugs, lots of content, with simple enough mechanics that even younger audience members can enjoy. Guides online offer direction for achievements that give a greater challenge. Tons of hilarious NPC dialogue to enjoy between the gathering and mini games of building a ship to navigate the world. Beautiful, colourful artwork, wonderful character concepts and stunning scenery and music to bring a vibrant and varied collection of human experiences to life.                   Story: 10/10 - Some mature themes are explored in the story which may not be suitable for all ages (unfaithfulness, disease, mental illness, workers rights, mistreatment of the ill) however I think this game is an excellent tool for both the young (guided by an adult) and old to explore many reasons why life is not eternal, and why that can be OK. Spiritfarer is a religion-neutral story with it's own unique concepts of how the living move on, offering it's own beautiful ritual to say good-bye. The concept of doing tasks for  loved ones to help them accept their ultimate fate can offer solace and closure for those of us who did not get to say good-bye, while also giving us practice accepting the powerlessness of grieving.
