I had originally written a much angrier review for this game. that review was accidentally deleted, so I am here to write a very tired, very abridged version so that my message can still be sent out.I have played this game for 20 hours (some offline). I went in almost entirely blind and have not looked anything up, even as I write this review. I have not finished Spiritfarer, though I believe I have explored most of what it has to offer and do not intend on continuing. I bought it a month ago during the winter sale, played it obsessively for a weekend or two, telling myself it'd get better, but it never did. when I went on the reviews here to check, what few negative reviews I saw echoed (most of) my sentiments and even some of the positive ones stated that the game actually got worse the longer it went on. there were some surprising omissions coming from my pov, though, so I will highlight what I think other reviews are missing while quickly echoing some of their sentiments to keep things balanced.[h1]The Good[/h1]This game has a lot going for it on surface level. It also has some good going for it after that. All of that follows here:[list] [*][b]The game is very pretty.[/b] Nighttime especially looks amazing, as does the Eclipse area. The Everdoor is similarly striking. [*][b]Animations are smooth, as is performance.[/b] I haven't had any frame drops, bugs, anything. Very well-made. [*][b]The music that plays when you're saying goodbye to a passenger is actually very good.[/b] It made my hair stand on end and was a highlight throughout the whole thing.[/list][h1]The Bad[/h1]Minor irritants that drag the experience down quite a bit. Not death blows, but bleeding cuts.[list] [*][b]Shops are near-useless for most things.[/b] They're not good for selling- most of what you'll need to sell can only be sold at the Travelling Salesman. They're not good for buying- most of what you might need from them is scattered around the world in plentiful Crates and chests. You'll also want to save most of your Glims for ship upgrades or facilities since they're the focus of passenger requests and help with traversal, both of which are essential to the core gameplay and storyline. (Worth noting that some ingredients are shop-exclusive. This is never mentioned in-game, and yet remains essential to Atul's main quests. These are the only times going to a shop is worth it.) [*][b]NPC dialogue is mostly repetitive drivel, and very very long. The meta commentary is also not appreciated.[/b] I once remember being somewhere in the Japanese-inspired area in the southwest, talking to an NPC sitting on a cliff. He said something along the lines of "wow, this mountain looks really good, almost like it was drawn or something". I'm not certain that's the exact phrasing, but regardless- there are many instances of this throughout the game. These instances are also [i]very drawn out.[/i] That dialogue I just gave to you in a sentence was, if I remember correctly, drawn out for one or two confirmations. Multiple NPCs I've talked to have had me click through five to SEVEN bubbles of speech that say very very little, frequently only being there to portray the character's insecurities or uncertainties. That's all very well and good, but it should not be a frequent occurrence, and especially not amongst [b]optional, non-important characters[/b] whom you probably just engaged with out of a moment's curiosity. [*][b]The music is mostly bland at best and annoying at worst.[/b] I have only heard maybe six tracks in this entire game. Most themes are just variations on the main ship theme, most of which remain identical save for the weather changing small aspects. This is a running trend, and the entire OST seems susceptible to constant repetition. The music is also wholly unremarkable- I can't remember any of it, save for the swelling portion of the Everdoor's theme, and many common themes are very repetitive and irritating. I like the passengers' music but I've heard the flute and theremin and violin so many times that it's just grating.[/list][h1]The Ugly[/h1]This section will be a little angrier, apologies. It's aimed towards large flaws in the gameplay that drastically hurt my experience, and especially ones that I haven't seen in other negative reviews. [b]If you want more elaboration on why I am rating this game poorly, read other negative reviews. I don't want to echo their sentiments 1-to-1, or at all save for briefly, but they're all incredibly true.[/b] Let me just start with a quickfire recap of what I agree with that other reviews have expanded on far more:[olist] [*][b]The game is seemingly underbaked, with great care put into some areas and very little into others.[/b] The collection system show this off well. It's baffling how there's 100+ recipes and nearly 60+ fish, yet every other collection struggles to break 10 pieces. [*][b]The game is bloated. Very bloated.[/b] I was getting tired around six or seven hours in. The aforementioned collection system, while cute in concept, is over with quickly and gives mediocre rewards. Character customization is limited to recolors of your outfit and your cat. The cooking is convoluted for literally no reason. Etc. [*][b]The gameplay is [i]extremely[/i] tedious and stressful.[/b] I am not exaggerating when I say this game has made me more tired in three hours than my college work has in eight. You are constantly bouncing from place to place, watering plants (individually) or shearing sheep (individually, from different pens) or attending to complaining passengers. Minigames for resources must be done every single time you want even one piece of a resource and it leaves you no time to unwind. The Windmill and Foundry minigames should be classified as torture. It makes the gameplay [b]dreadful[/b] and is probably the main reason I cannot like Spiritfarer. [*][b]Character writing is haphazard and bad.[/b] One character's arc, relating to dementia, involved the character being perfectly lucid for 70% of her time onboard before rapidly deteriorating within the span of half a quest and then dying without calling you by name. This is one of the better-paced characters. Multiple others will espouse large parts of their backstory at the end of a fetch quest while saying nothing but canned dialogue for the rest of their time on board (90% of the time you spend with them). It makes getting attached to anyone an impossibility- even moreso when they're constantly complaining about hunger and asking you for food or reminding you of their quests that you can't complete yet. ([b][i]ATUL.[/i][/b])[/olist]As for my #1 personal complaint...[h1]This game's pacing is [i]terrible.[/i][/h1]I have repeatedly received requests for things that are much further in the game than I am. Requests for things I can only achieve via ziplining while I hardly have the double-jump. Requests for shop items hidden in towns that're locked behind rocks or ice that require expensive ship upgrades. [i]Constant[/i] pestering for things I don't even know about. I have also gone through almost all of my ship upgrades in the top two rows, but my bottom row (meant for traversal) is stuck on [b]the third upgrade[/b] because [i]I cannot find what I need in easily-accessible areas.[/i] Some characters I meet will stick around with me for several hours, while others are gone in the blink of an eye. I knew Gwen for two hours before sending her off, while I've had Atul annoying me for nearly eighteen now. This is excluding me putting off Gwen's death to do busywork. It baffles me how nobody else has mentioned this yet. Am I just playing the game wrong?I wanted to love Spiritfarer. I put in 20 hours to try and do as much. I don't even think it's a bad game. But it's hardly even good, when it had the potential to be excellent.

This is a "yes" that is really a "sort of."The first few hours of the game are interesting and fun. They have a lot to say about death and grief, about love and its ability to endure, and how having a friend on the other side can make all the difference. And then it becomes a grind. You're bouncing from island to island, often without instruction on what to do next, playing the same minigames over and over again with no way to fast travel or cut down on the chaff, of which there is a lot.Spiritfarer is comprised of a lot of minigames, actually. Every time you need to craft something, you play another one, often without a lot of instruction (or any at all) on how to make the best of it. Want to craft 50 linen cloth? Be prepared to create each individual cloth. Want to create quartz powder? You'll have to crush it yourself by repeatedly pressing "E" upward of a dozen times.And while the first spirits I met pulled at my heartstrings, the later ones were all insufferable. I just wanted them off my boat. Some of them (quite a few, actually) have almost the exact same stories, with very little to differentiate them from one another. Others are just awful, and while perhaps this is a statement on caregiver burnout and desensitization, I'm not sure it works in a game, at least not one like this.This game does have a lot of good qualities about it, but overall, I have a lot of mixed feelings about it, especially given the hype.

[h1]This game broke me. So. Many. Times…[/h1]

…and I’ve got a feeling it would definitely do it again if I were to replay it. It’s a bittersweet experience that pulls no punches in tugging at your heartstrings… and I absolutely loved it. I’ve been postponing this review for a while now, so I could look at the game more objectively, yet my opinion has not changed: It’s an absolute gem.

Everything about this game - the story, the sound design (which I will get to in a second), the art style, etc. – feels like a perfect composition to me. It evokes a feeling akin to childlike wonder, mixed with a sense of adventure, which perfectly fits the narrative of the game, as the story and the meaning behind this masterpiece are not so obvious from the start. I won’t go into the story much here though, because I believe it works its magic best when experienced blindly.

The art style is nothing short of beautiful. The design of the characters reflects their rich, varied personalities perfectly, the animations are cute and cartoonish yet very fluid and natural, the environments are absolutely stunning, and the visuals during some events, such as the meteor shower, are awe-inspiring.

The sound design, which I mentioned before, flows exceptionally well with the things happening on screen. It gives all the in-game events an extra push, greatly accentuating them. Yet the sound design is in perfect synergy with something else…

…with the soundtrack. The original soundtrack here is just something else. Composed by Maxime Lacoste-Lebuis, it elevates the already fantastic game to another level. From soft, fragile, reflection-inducing piano (At Night), through almost ethereal pieces (Guardians & Memories), all the way to massive, intense string-driven crescendos (The Swarm of Hades), they all fit this wonderful experience perfectly. I’m sure the game would not be the same without it.

If you’ve got a couple of evenings to spare, I would highly recommend checking it out. One disclaimer though. As wonderful as the game is, I found that there’s one point to be wary of. Spiritfarer is still a management game at its core, so it’s not entirely story-driven. This means that you’ll need to actually play quite a bit to progress the story, which I know has put some people off.

To finish off this review, I’ll just say that I will not forget this experience any time soon, if at all. I don’t think any game has made me feel what this game has. It’s truly an adventure to remember for a while. Many thanks to the Thunder Lotus team for such a masterpiece.

Additional review: I was very surprised by this game. When I saw the trailer, I thought it looked wonderful and unique. When I first tried it, I thought it was casual and boring, so I stopped. A few months later I tried again... and could not stop until I finish it, yet you know what? all of my first impressions were actually true!
Spirit Farer is indeed a wonderful game: have you seen how beautiful it looks? Everything in this game is gorgeous. The illustrations are sumptuous, the animation is smooth and colorful... All of this new graphic school in video games with Hades or Battle Chef Brigade is really pleasant to see.
The game is also unique: I never was into Undertale, although I recognize its impact on the world of game design. A game where you don't necessarily kill everything, where dialogues are different, where themes are mature and deep yet not gross or typical. That was unique when it came out, for sure. Now, Undertale for me was lackluster and just the spark for a whole new approach to game design, and made possible games like Spiritfarer. A game about death, about dying, about others dying but also yourself, dying. Made with lots of tact and tenderness for mankind. The game can be very touching from time to time, and ends up being very worked in its details, in its depth of narration and its meaning.
Finally, for the down side, my negative impressions were also true: the game IS completely casual. Sometimes it reminded me of tablet/smartphone games, there is NO difficulty in its gameplay, a child could play it, yet its design (menus, actions etc) are still for grown ups while being a bit clumsy/casual. Not a BAD thing, but not a great/attractive thing for a gamer like me.
And I said it was boring, sadly I stand by it: the game is packed of dialogues, unfortunately they are sometimes quite wordy and uninspired/uninteresting. Also, the gameplay itself is often very dry or bland (some actions require you to push a button... many times... why?). And despite the fact that the tone of the game is remarkably mature and sensitive, what you actually do in the game is very repetitive and that can be a deterrent for many gamers.

Now, if you just would like a formula: imagine the exploration of islands on an ocean like in Windwaker or Sea of Thieves - the mature approach and metaphysical theme of an Outer Wilds or Undertale - the relaxing and ecological gameplay of a Stardew Valley, with its Relationship features - the casualness of a Metroidvania-lite or for children. All of this is Spiritfarer. And I made sure to obtain all the achievements to show my respect to the devs (I rarely do that).

Overall is it a great game? yes, albeit a small one (maybe a 85% in my ranking system). Is it a masterpiece? Not at all, a 100 games at least are better than that. Will it be in my Top 100 of all times? I am not sure yet... So is it just an average game? I really don't think so, it is too unique and original for that. Spiritfarer is a game where death is approached in such a unique way, where your eyes sparkle from the unique, beautiful artwork, where your ears tingle from the delicate music (the Everdoor theme!), where your heart feels a bit heavy each time you recognize in its narration some things from your own life and experience... We all face death eventually, many, different times. Spiritfarer talks about that, so it might not be an amazing video game, but it is for sure a splendid work of art.

Resource management game with an emotional arc. 

You play a young girl (and her cat in co-op) ferrying departed souls to the afterlife on a boat. You hear about their lives and help them tie up loosed ends. You gather materials, invest resources and upgrade your boat. 

Most of the game play revolves around tending to the resource-generating rooms on your boat and keeping the soon-to-be departed guests happy and fed whilst listening to their stories and completing simple quest lines.

Very laid back, friction-free game. Played it co-op with my wife and we really enjoyed. Probably went on for a bit too long, but was a nice chill and emotional experience.

Just finished this game for the second time. The first time I played it, I was very stressed in life and it came at the perfect time to give me some relaxation. The incredible music is impossible to ignore, (MOST of) the characters are very endearing, and the gameplay is addictive as hell, to say the least. I love that it's also quite humorous, so even a game about death doesn't always have to be super heavy. Overall, I simply adored the game and was absolutely going around recommending it to my friends.

However, the second time, I played this game while grieving. It hit so different. I realized how every little detail in this game, every word each of the spirits say, has such deep, significant, individual meaning. I became more familiar with the fact that we all have our own struggles in life and sometimes things don't end happily for everyone, and that is okay in the end. I found some true peace in my loss through this game. I cannot express how unique Spiritfarer really is, and how much it means to me. Thank you so much for this masterpiece, Thunder Lotus Games. 10/10

This is SERIOUSLY the most beautiful game I've ever played, and I've played a lot. It instantly soared to my number one favourite game ever. No game has ever touched me the way Spiritfarer did. Every single screenshot could be framed and hanged on the wall. Every single dialogue is interesting, deep and meaningful. Every activity has a purpose and meaning. Together with the enchanting music, it is a perfect masterpiece of game design, artwork and storytelling. It is about death, inevitable part of life, about humanity, friendship, hard times in life and perserverance, about finding the meaning in life, about both individuality and community and what is worth living AND dying for. I have cried many times during the gameplay, even when I played for the second time. I have been amazed by the captivating stories and symphatised with the deep characters. I have tried to read between the lines of character dialogues and guess what could have happened to them "in reality". And even thought it might seem Spiritfarer is basically a tear-jerking visual novel, nothing could actually be farther away from reality!! The platform jumping parts, especially if you're a completionist and want to find all collectibles are really challenging and fun, the controls are super responsive and very fun. Building your ship is also fun by itself, and even though some activities might be a little bit tedious, like constant plant watering, woodcutting or working in the smithy, it has never annoyed me enough to lower my esteem about this game. A big thanks to everyone who worked on this game and made it possible, you have brought something unique and beautiful into this world!

The way this game has impacted my life is unlike any media I've ever consumed, unrestrained to just video games—there's not even a TV show or a book that made me reflect on myself the way this game does.

It's a very lighthearted and casual game: there are no failure conditions, it's filled with relaxing minigames, and the OST brings about a deep sense of serenity and wonder. It's the type of game you can just kick your feet up and play on a rainy day (not unlike something like Stardew Valley or Animal Crossing), which was very refreshing after having played multiple souls-likes in a row. The gameplay got a little repetitive and tedious towards the end as I was aiming for 100%. All I had left to do was [spoiler] a mid-to-late-game quest that was meant to be done over the course of 12 in-game days while you’re tying up other loose ends—whoops! [/spoiler] I will admit that idling the game on my second monitor while I did other things did break the immersion a fair bit, but it was worth it for the big ‘100%’ on my save file and it didn’t affect my overall opinion on the game at all.

All that aside, what the game lacks in mechanical difficulty, it certainly makes up for in *emotional* difficulty.

I'd heard about this game being hard-hitting since it came out, but I only got around to playing it this year. I was expecting to be moved, but I was in no way expecting to be as emotionally broken coming out of a play session as I was after bringing my first spirit to the Everdoor. Spritfarer not only makes you think about your mortality but in a way, it helps you come to terms with it. Stella's job is to help the spirits of her loved ones come to terms with their deaths so that they may move on, but she also helps [spoiler] herself and [/spoiler] the player do the same. I picked up Spiritfarer during a time where I was paranoid and convinced that my time was running out. On paper it sounds like a recipe for disaster, but I believe it only amplified the emotional impact of the story and my connection with each of the spirits—especially Summer, whose story resonated with me deeply. It touched on some of my deepest fears in such a realistic and heart-wrenching way, especially seeing as I saw many of my loved ones in the characters I've had to say goodbye to. Getting to know everyone and growing to appreciate their company always sets you up for a painful goodbye; It made me think about how much you really take your loved ones for granted. Atul, Alice and Beverly hit especially close to home. The latter two’s arcs being so similar and happening so close together that it struck me with an overwhelming sense of despair and hopelessness that there was nothing I could do to help. It’s the most gripping emotion I’ve felt playing a video game in years and I loved it.

The soundtrack adds so much to the story's impact—especially the minigame songs. The comet shower song in particular made me connect with Giovanni in a way I never expected. From the start, he was just kind of... there. I never paid much attention to him and was more invested in making Astrid happy, [spoiler] which is why I told her about his night excursions without a second thought. [/spoiler] The first time Giovanni came out during a meteor shower, I immediately felt my opinion of him shift. There's so much wonder and awe in the song, it reveals a side of him that I didn't know was there. I don't know how to explain it. I haven't activated a comet shower since he left, because I feel like it'd be wrong to see the stars fall without him there to marvel at them by my side.


It's incredibly rare that I give out 5-star ratings, even for games that I adore. That rating is reserved only for masterpieces, and games that mean too much to me to rate them anything else—games that shaped me as a person. Spiritfarer is both. 10/10.

TL;DR:
I enjoyed Spiritfarer's vibrant atmosphere, profound connections to the real world, and satisfying gameplay & story enough to forget a few small pain points along the way.

What I LOVED about this game:
+ Gave me a chance to think deeply about life and death without being pushy
+ Made me care about the characters a lot
+ The soundtrack and artwork are both gorgeous and contribute significantly to the game's atmosphere
+ Progressing through the game is done largely at your own pace, without being hand-hold-y or feeling rushed (it took me about 40 hours to reach the ending, and I was at over 80% completion by then)

What I felt "meh" about:
> While the platforming elements were solid at times, at other times they seemed unnecessary or even nuisance
> I really enjoyed giving the NPCs foods/drinks that they loved, but it was sometimes difficult to figure out what those actually were without looking it up

What I didn't like:
- A handful of slightly annoying gameplay elements, including gathering certain resources and having interactions locked out at certain times due to plot sequences
- On maybe 3 different occasions, a NPC or I got stuck in a glitch, and I had to save and re-load the game

I played it on Xbox Gamepass back when it was new, and then when the DLC came out I bought it on Steam so I could replay it whenever I wanted. I'm a cheapskate, so to pay for a game I had already played means a lot.

I gave myself time after finishing this one before writing this review.
I really have little to no words as to how this game made me feel throughout my playthrough. 
Not a single video game has made me cry. Not a single one.
This one made me cry like... 14 times? Maybe even up to 20 times? Idk.
I don't know why it had such a choke-hold on my emotions, but man. It did. 
Each of the characters that you meet in this game just feel so real. Each one is so relatable and real, and throughout the course of the game you get to know them and their stories so well - it feels like you're friends with them, and you've genuinely known them for years. It makes it all the more harder to progress the game. 

It is kind of poetic - thinking about it, I'm probably not ready to write this review. I can't quite get my thoughts together. I can't put into words how I feel about this game.
And, funnily enough, I don't think I was ready for this game. It took me by surprise. Maybe that's why I was so emotional playing through the game. But... I think I feel better, now. I think it made me feel better. It made me feel more at peace with things that were earlier a worry. 

Maybe, one day, when I'm ready, I'll come back to this game. And I'll write another review. For now, this review will stay as it is.

All in all, I highly, highly recommend this game. If I could give it two thumbs-ups, I would. 
Its a game that everyone should play before they die.

My four year-old asked next to me about almost every spirit brought to the Everdoor, and he was able to relate to it in the context of his dog dying. First of all: If you're expecting a fast-paced game with lots of building, customization and a more linear sense of progression, this game might simply not be for you. This isn't really a game that you can "get good" at, you simply have to let yourself be drawn in by the story and characters. 

Spiritfarer gently guides you through the various different stories of the spirits that you, as Stella, accompanied by her cat Daffodil, must eventually ferry to the afterlife. The graphics and music are beautiful and one can really tell that the developers have let a lot of love, thought and whimsy flow into this game. Some of the stories seem so incredibly personal, yet so relatable and moving.

To me, the beauty of this game lies in its handling of time as flux. There is no pressure to "speed-run" though quests, stories or minigames. You're ready when you're ready, right up to the very last moment. 
I love precisely those elements that other reviewers have criticized - the slow animations, the back and forth, the conversations, simply the non-linearity of it all. None of that was tedious for me in my playthrough - quite the opposite, in fact. I frequently looked forward to taking time off from my busy schedule to just...enjoy the precious moments Spiritfarer had to offer.

I won't say too much about the story (stories?) or characters, except that saying goodbye to spirits wasn't always easy and I spent many of my 54 ingame hours on the verge of tears...and sometimes even beyond. Grief, loss and forgiveness aren't the easiest themes to tackle but I think this game did an excellent job.

This is an appropriately slow-paced game about the inevitability of death. You get to become somewhat intimate with a small cast of characters as you play through the simulator-lite gameplay loop. Though I once or twice found myself getting a bit lost as to how best to proceed, I think the lulls between plot points or passenger departures were necessary. Clever usage of gameplay mechanics leads to some impressively heartbreaking moments.

Speaking of heartbreak, I have wept so much at this game; I really did feel like I got to know the cast of the ship just as their moment to pass on arrived. And when they are ready to move on, the compositions of Max LL composed just floored me. I wish I could properly articulate the simultaneous melancholy and relief I feel anytime 'Last Voyage' plays during the game. My heart aches thinking about saying goodbye to my first passenger.

The familiarity with and love for the subject matter, of death and letting go, is apparent in almost every element of Spiritfarer. And while not every player will have the same emotional experience with the game, it is an incredibly touching experience that had touched upon some incredibly relatable moments. It invites you to feel however you want, but I for one shed many tears playing Spiritfarer. And I loved it.

- - -

If there was ever a remaster or sequel, I would have loved to see the passengers mingle with each other more and for an accessibility option to change mash commands (e.g. selling, crushing) to a hold prompt.

While it does a lot of things right (most notably the art), the story in Spiritfarer is just so soul destroying (ironic) that I grew to dislike it.

Contrary to what the game might like to tell you, the real story of Spiritfarer is: "you are an errand girl". That sums up every character arc in the game. You find the character, sometimes pass a trial for them to deign to board your ship, then you satisfy their every demand, which they have a considerable amount of: feed me, build me a house, furnish my house, fulfill my life's calling for me, etc.. The earlier characters are at least friendly and thankful while you help them, but two of the later ones will just mock how much of a sucker you are while bossing you around (and I don't care that they probably have redemption arcs, I just want to kick them off my ship, preferrably in the middle of the ocean). Then after you've completed their story you send them on their way to the underworld. Which honestly is a pretty emotional affair, I have to admit I was sad for some time after the first character left (the next few were significantly less impactful), but that's not really due to the writing or the story; the art is pulling ALL the punches here.

And what a beautiful game this is. The drawn art is fine, nothing spectacular, but the particle effects certainly are. When the first eclipse occurred my jaw dropped.

I would give this game a 6.5/10.

But overall, this is going in my top 10 all-time favorite games, maybe even top 5. The gameplay loop of exploration and houseboat management is very well crafted. It reminds me a little of Raft, but more satisfying. 
And the characters and writing are fantastic. This game deals with some pretty heavy themes and it takes a skilled writer to deal with them properly, and they did it. Man, some of those moments are gut-wrenching.
Finally, the game is visually beautiful, too. A lovely art style and smooth, clean animations.
Overall, a clear recommendation. Probably keep some tissues on hand.

I have really mixed views on this game. 

Its universe, characters and story are really touching. And its ost, graphics and animations are awesome. I also like a lot the platformer aspect, which is well made and satisfying. 

However, even if at first the game is really pleasing to play, it quickly becomes tedious. The progress is very slow : long and repetitive mini games to collect and transform resources (fun the first time, but after that they become chores), beautiful but very long animations each time you do something like watering your crops, which is unnecessary, and too much back and forth in boat. Because of that, the game sadly lacks dynamism and isn't that pleasing to play after a while...

Moreover, the length of the game enforces it even more. I think it could have been a good game if it was shorter, but the slow gameplay during that much time kills it completely, and we are bored of it way before the end. 
This is even more sad because the story and the character are still touching, and we can't enjoy it well in the end. There's also a lot of content, but that we unlock after so many hours that it doesn't benefit the experience. 

I'm sure certain people will have a lot of fun anyway, but I will clearly not be able to finish the game.


(Ps : I guess the game wants us to appreciate each character, however Giovanni is just straight up a "Don Juan like" cheater that I can only despise, while I'm supposed to make him happy in the game :/)

I really really wanted to recommend this game - at the it has such a lovely premise and is so atmospheric!
 
Pros: The story is lovely, and it is quite a casual game which was what I was looking for. The graphics are beautiful, and the music soothing. The experience makes you feel just nice. I did not encounter any major bugs, it seemed polished. Each of the characters brought something different, and made me feel like they had their own lives and their own stories and somehow I wished to know more about them. 

Cons: The game went on for a lot longer than I expected - this perhaps is a good thing for some of you - the problem is the gameplay itself did not really evolve. The farming aspects were tedious when you have to repeat them over and over, all the little minigames for resource refining become just...boring and repetitive. There is no way to automate processes. Minor upgrades to the farming system are found in end game when farming is pretty much obsolete.  

There are also some odd resource roadblocks that perhaps were not that intuitive. I was stuck on a quest for the longest time because I did not realise I had to go back and talk to a specific NPC to debrief to progress the quest. Some essential passengers were found on islands I had forgotten from ages ago...

And lastly, I hate platformers unfortunately. Especially the ones where you could be one jump from the end, but then you can mis-time the jump or the platform disappears/moves randomly and you just fall back to the beginning. Platformers like that are in my opinion such an archaeic form of gameplay - they did well back in the 90s because they fit on a 1.3mb floppy disc and people did not mind repeating levels over and over again. I do not play games for platformers. I hate them. So the sheer number of platforming required almost made me quit the game. If you enjoy platformers then this might not be a problem for you. 

Honestly I didn't really want to give it a 'no' recommendation overall, but if I had to think about how cranky I got out of frustration from some of the quests I do think I have to give it an overall no for ME; but it may well be a good game for you if you don't mind the above things. Part of the problem may also have been that I played the game over the course of about a week or two (a few hours a day) when perhaps it is supposed to be more casual than that? So that the tedium does not seem such an issue?

This game has a nice concept, combining a resource-gathering sim (farming, crafting, managing residents) and a 2D platformer. The graphics and sound are great and the game has a nice, relaxing atmosphere. Unfortunately, what I went into hoping for a nice, short game quickly turned into a tedious grind. Everything in this game with regard to the resource management seems to be designed to be as tedious as possible. Want to make olive oil? Better smash the x button like 50 times. Want to make thread? Gotta play a timing mini-game for EVERY SINGLE ONE. Want to grind flour? Gotta put it in the mill and ADJUST THE WIND DIRECTION every time you move to a new location. Also, the time it takes to cook something is INSANELY variable. Some dishes cook in literally 2 seconds and others take like 10 minutes and it's ridiculous.

Also, many quests and areas are essentially gated-off because they require a particular item you can only get in a certain area or from a certain character. I was stuck for ages because the one item I needed was given by a resident who I had to GROW from a seed after sending off a certain number or residents and I only found out by checking the wiki.

Basically, this game would be great if it didn't seem designed to waste your time. There was NO NEED to make the resource management aspect of this game as tedious and grindy as it is. If you do still plan to check this game out, use the wiki so you don't lose your sanity.

Spiritfarer is the kind of game that is hard to be described because it doesn't really fit into any particular genre. Instead, I takes a lot of different elements - like platforming, building, crafting, resource management and a Metroidvania-like world, full of secrets and questlines - and melts them into its own thing. The ever-growing loop of activities and minigames not once felt boring to me during my 53-hour completionist playthrough because they all served their purpose, allowing me not only to expand the world but to progress through Spiritfarer's emotional and thought-provoking main storyline, as well. The pleasing color palette, amazing hand-drawn animation and ethereal music score wrap all this into an experience that will likely stay with you long after you've finished playing it.

In a game about accepting the flaws of a life lived and accepting death, Spiritfarer is a game best experienced rather than played. The gameplay is thin, consisting of chores, light platforming, and some exploration. The rest of the game, and the emotional pull of the game, is about the characters you meet and guide through their final time in existence. The tropes are all well worn and could easily leave you rolling your eyes, but the stories are so heartfelt and touching. The easy emotional pulls (whatever the equivalent of an emotional "jumpscare" is) are avoided and instead you are left with full characters telling rich stories.

If you are looking for a game that satisfies a desire to play, I'm not sure this game is for you. If you are looking for a game that respects the content and tells a good story then I highly recommend this game. It is simultaneously touching and emotionally devastating.

Very touching, emotional game, definitely not for everyone, but I enjoyed it. Great artwork and style. Somewhat of a "fetch-quest festival", but entertaining and absorbing.

Controls (on PC with an XBOX controller) were twitchy and sloppy, making plattorming frustratingly difficult (using ziplines, especially), but even with my diminished coordination due to brain damanage from a seriies of lacunar strokes, I managed most of it.

Really needed to be about 8 hours shorter.  I know getting used to your NPCs until you can be haunted by their absence is extremely important to the narrative of the game, but personally I felt it was stretched way too far.  After a while you notice the seams in the mechanics, you realize which resources are pointless and what can be min-maxed and gamification sets in.  Towards the end I was blowing past all of the narratively-important side-events, fast-traveling to every destination, and taking in some of the most important final story elements at a breakneck pace because I had lost patience with the gameplay.

But it really is a good, emotional story (consisting of several smaller stories of varying emotional impact) and it's worth experiencing for that alone.  And the gorgeous graphics and serene, surreal environment are easy to slip into.

For context, as of the moment of writing this review, a massive earthquake killed thousands in Syria and Turkey, and these developers showed their "empathy" by massively raising the price of the game in those countries.

They blame people who use VPNs to appear as if they live in these countries to get cheaper prices, but by increasing the price like this they're punishing the customers from these regions, who will now have to pay 5 times the original price.

All these developers who recently raised the prices had the choice to group together and contact Valve and request them to strengthen the system to avoid this loophole, but no, they chose the easy way and they betrayed their loyal customers and fans of the game.

You can try to complain and write your disapproval, of course, but the decision on the price was already made. However, remember that as a customer you have a choice, and you can always VOTE WITH YOUR WALLET.

In addition, this is just another example of something pretty evident that still a lot of people fail to see: if you see developers and game studios posting announcements about their alleged sympathy for affected regions in the world, it's always wise to assume it's a mere marketing strategy until proven otherwise, and beyond any doubt, so don't fall for that.

I don't think a lot of people will check this message, so thank you for the time you invested in reading these thoughts, and have a nice day.

Starts out strong, but overstays its welcome.  The demo is going to show you the best part of the game.  Recommended if you like grinding mini-games or if you really connect with what you see in the demo.   I had to really push myself to finish grinding to see the end of the game's main and free update stories.

What starts as a fun game exploring the world with friends while using charming crafting mini-games turns into a grocery checklist as I constantly collected more resources so I could unlock the next area to grind more resources in, but I couldn't get to all of the resources so I had to come back later with more shrine upgrades to grind the rest of the resources so I could keep progressing.  I wouldn't mind doing it a few times, but half the islands have stuff that asked me revisit them at least three times to collect everything.  And the crafting.  It was fun at first, but then it got very, very old several hundred crafted items later.  The saw and the smithy in particular made me groan every time I saw another thing which needed 60 more planks or 5 more metal/glass sheets.

There are also a couple, really poorly introduced systems which brought my progress to a screeching halt until I looked them up online or randomly stumbled across them. (Stanley had his door locked for most of the time I had him.  How am I supposed to know it's suddenly unlocked so I can get ectoplasm if there aren't any prompts?)

The story writing is pretty good, but it does get dark.  Very dark.  Lily's story near the end does a good job of tying most of the pieces together for those who want closure.  I only really felt a connection with a few of the characters, so it wasn't hard to say goodbye to most of them.  I was relieved when they had to go, because it meant less grinding for food that detracted from enjoying the story.  I did miss the hugs though.  Those were definitely the best part of having passengers. 

Ultimately, this game won me over with the hugs, the artwork, cute sounds and its creativity.  The hugs were easily the most rewarding part of this game, so much so that I was willing to put up with having my toes stepped on and my shins bashed by the revisiting and crafting systems.

To start off, I think this game is definitely solid and a step up from ThunderLotus' other games, such as sundered. The art is awesome, concept is neat and kinda depressing, and the gradual construction of your ship with lost spirits is really well done. For that, it's definitely a recommend. However, I think the balancing especially in the second half with resource management and completing certain quests is completely out of sync with the rest of the game. I didn't even finish the last character's quest line because it was simply far too tedious of a fetch quest. It goes from gathering a couple things to work towards the next upgrade to instead fishing for very specific things in very specific areas, only to unlock the ability to travel to all corners of the map yet again to recruit people for something. It kind of felt like the game stopped valuing my time at a certain point, but before that I think it's a great experience especially if you want something relaxing and simple yet fun.

Good the first few hours. Then... caused by a few things the emotional investment I felt towards the NPCs faded. Without that emotional component, the game is not really anything special anymore. Collecting and making stuff is more a chore than interesting, maybe made worse by the very long animations that can't be skipped for every little thing one does. But maybe the much more important factor for not enjoying "bonding" with the NPCs: while the first few NPC have their quirks and occasional interpersonal drama, it felt like something that is actually worth listening to and getting invested is worthwhile. Then joins that NPC that is basically a manipulative cheater including the obvious lying and overly dramatic apologies. Yes, please, so enjoyable to fetch various presents for that person so they can manipulate their "love interest" into forgiving them. At least that character was relatively quickly gone. But then an even more abstruse character appears: a violent criminal that boasts about how he did all kinds of cruel and violent stuff to impress some crime boss. He treats the player character with contempt. Offering the wrong kind of food results in outright threats. Why would I enjoy serving such a NPC instead of booting them off my ship? That character even has a major negative gameplay effect, as every other NPC receives a mood debuff because they feel bullied by that NPC.

There is no obvious way to remove those NPCs from what I can tell - it seems each NPC is mandatory to progress.

---

Overall, since I got the game for 6€ during a sale, I don't really regret buying it. The game was really enjoyable the first 6-12 hours and if I had stopped at that point (or maybe knew a way to skip those NPCs) my impression would have been much, much, *much* better.

Let me preface this by saying that I enjoyed myself for the most part. The art, the music, the story, and the characters were all fantastic and will definitely stick with me.

I played this game co-op with my girlfriend. Now, I've heard from her and others that the single-player experience is much better, but I was stuck with so many soft-locking or game-breaking bugs near the end that frustrated me to the point that I almost gave up right before finishing. Co-op is anything except a polished experience.

Onto the gameplay itself:
While I enjoy the core gameplay loop of gathering, upgrading, and building in the likes of things like Raft, I found this frankly arduous. The playforming was a nice addition, but even so something felt very... wrong... to me about the platforming physics. Why I mean by this is that momentum is seemingly arbitrarily maintained whenever jumping, and entirely dependent off of the surface from which exiting. 
I frankly could not stand the required micro-managing for Every. Single. Thing when it came to resources. The crops were the least egregious. I do not mind individually watering and harvesting, but the animations take far too long when trying to produce the items you need in lategame. Much of the game as a whole felt specifically constructed to waste as much time as it could on anything but the story or characters which, as I mentioned, were the main shining point. Every single resource had some sort of minigame attached. There is no way to automate them. If you wish to have a particular resource, especially if it needs some manufacturing, prepare for a heap of (from my perspective) time-wasting and pointless minigames. While you can increase the production from these minigames by double, eventually, it does not solve the problem at hand of being designed to waste time. 

Overall, I enjoyed this game. However, I cannot recommend it to anyone. This is the first occasion where I've felt the need to post a negative review on something that I enjoyed, mostly because I don't think it will hurt the overall review score that much. Keep this in mind before purchase, but if it does not sound like that big of a burden- please go for it! It's cute.

EDIT:
    I reviewed this game but I had something I wanted to add. I'm 82% through the game, and I wanted to address something. This game has a lot of heavy themes that might be triggering for some people. There are discussions/implications of suicide; mentions of war, cancer, and dementia. There's also discussions of injury and death (since that's what the game is about). If strong feelings of loss or grief might trigger you or cause you to spiral, please think carefully about playing this game. I don't consider these things to be bad - I think they add to the weight of the game. I have enjoyed how unflinching the game has been with its characters, and I understand experiencing all this will be healing for many of its players. But I don't want anyone to be caught off guard.
     All that said, the art and animation are astounding The music continues to sweep me off my feet every time I play, and the world-building is a delight. Both in spite of AND because of its heavy themes, this game has quickly become one of my favorites. If you think you're ready, I wholeheartedly invite you to download and play.

Visually awesome This is hands down one of the most aesthetically relaxing games I've had the pleasure of playing.
The art and the animation are beautifully done in my opinion which I find really charming. Good hand drawn animation is hard to do, but this animators nailed it here with everything from the expressions to the smallest gestures. Nailed it.

The gameplay is pretty fun and simple. 
It's just a lot of mini games that reward you for just about anything. There's little to no penalty. I like that. It's very stress-free in that regard. When you are not playing the mini games, you travel and platform around looking for materials; new abilities; and conversing with NPC's. It's pretty bare bones, but I am okay with that because it's got fun dialogue and good story elements. I think the pacing of the game is done well. If I ever felt stuck I would just explore and I would usually find what I needed to advance the story. I suggest this game if you are looking to just relax and if you're okay with getting a little emotional (or a lot of emotional).

The story is thought provoking.
Spoiler not spoiler, you deal with death the entire game. Something that can be difficult to understand is how the characters you meet passed away. Maybe it's just me (probably me), but some of the conflicts the characters go through are a little hard to understand as their conflicts are sometimes left a mystery that you'll have to piece together. Part of me also thinks that the ending isn't what was meant to be highlighted, but how the characters were feeling in there last moments alive. Food for thought while you play.

I had fun. I think more of these games should exist to give pause to games we might need breaks from so we can reset. It's also kind of nice when a game gives you not just an experience, but also leaves you with something to think about.

I'm sure there's a beautiful story in here, but unfortunately it's buried under the most tedious and uninspired gameplay ever.

The whole game is just a load of busywork, expressed through boring little minigames you've seen a thousand times before. You can fish. Which boils down to pressing the action key to cast your line, then waiting until something bites, before holding down the action key to reel it in. Once a certain character comes aboard, it gets a little bit more complicated: now you can catch bigger things, which means your line can snap. So now you have to release the action button when your line is about to break, letting it cool down for a brief instant, and hold it again to continue reeling in. Yawn-a-licious! But hey, there's also farming. Which involves standing in front of your plot, and using your action key to plant something (it lets you select what), using the same action key to water it (which must be done daily, for every individual plot), and again to harvest after a couple of days. Don't like that? Well, there's the music minigame. Hit the specified controller keys at the correct moment to play a melody. Cutting down trees: move the stick left and right to move the saw. Cooking: toss something in the oven and wait for the timer to run out, then take it out of the oven. Mining: hold the action key to "charge up" your swing, then let go before you inexplicably drop your pickaxe. And so on, and so forth.

On top of that, you need to keep your passengers happy. Some have certain demands, which you need to fulfill. They also each have their personal preferences regarding food. Satisfying their demands and dietary preferences increases their happiness, which apparently (although I'm probably not at that stage yet) makes them help out on the boat with all the menial tasks. The problem is, in order to see their mood, you need to interact with them and select the "mood" option. They don't have different animations depending on their mental state, nor do they have handy icons floating overhead so you can quickly see which passengers require attention. Unless it's for scripted events. And they don't do anything by themselves; you have to cook for them, you have to provide them with whatever makes them happy, they're just along for the ride but don't expect them to carry their own weight or anything.

All of this results in a load of busywork, and you're frantically running from left to right to react to all the different timers running out or gathering resources. This leaves you very little time to actually interact with your passengers in a meaningful way. Which, to me, seemed the whole point of this game prior to purchase, going by the marketing materials. But then, if you're looking for meaningful interactions, you're not gonna find it in this game anyway, as the characters don't really have much to say. Nor do you, for that matter. There is no dialogue in this game, just monologue where the characters apparently reveal their story. And their preferences, and the "tutorials", and whatever else the game wants you to know about. You can't steer the conversations, you can't react to what they tell you, you're just there to listen.

I truly don't understand all the raving reviews, or the "overwhelmingly positive" rating this game gets. This is Farmville levels of gaming "fun". I can't believe none of the people who gave this a glowing review have ever played an actual game before, so what am I missing?

On the cautiously positive side: the drawing and animation style is beautiful and charming, I'll give them that. Although, like all the rest, it's also very repetitive. I mean, how many times can that deer be genuinely surprised that you hug her before she simply hugs you back without getting startled every... single... time??? Would it have killed them to create, I don't know, *two* hug animations for that character? But still, it's beautifully drawn, and the game oozes visual charm. Too bad it doesn't have the gameplay to back it up.

Pros of this game:
1. Beautiful artwork. It's so beautiful I bought an artbook. The everdoor, Stella,characters, island designs, even Hades - it took devs a lot of time to design. Well done.
2. Beautiful music. I didn't buy the soundtrack DLC tho (I don't listen to music via Steam)
3. Beautiful main protagonist. In the artbook developers said that they went through lots of iterations with Stella and Daffodil, and I can see why. If I ever to see Stella cosplay, I will know it immediately.
4. Awesome characters. Each one so unique I can still name them all by names and their favorite dishes, and do remember some of their stories.
5. Theme. Coping with dying is very hard for many people, and it will for sure help someone who faced losses in their lives.
6. Gameplay. Managing ship was very cool idea and it was very well implemented. After I finished the game with all achievements I loaded an autosave with few spirits (Gustav and Atul namely because they help other spirits be happy) left so I can prepare for new characters coming this year (they should be free btw but I will buy them if they don't). So I will still spend time in-game to farm some more items, even tho the game is complete.

The game is not without it's flaws tho:
0. It takes a LOT of time to get you going. First 10-15 hours I was thinking "I lack everything and I need everything".
1. The amount of things you should do in this game can be overwhelming. Travel, manage boat, fish, talk to spirits, hug spirits, find recipes, cook for spirits/quests, craft materials, grow plants/seeds, water plants/seeds, gather fruits from trees, mine ores, gather berries, milk cows, shear sheep, buy/sell materials, wander islands, play dozen of mini-games (for materials). I am sure I forgot something! You are going to enjoy this game when you are either casual gamer and take your time, or when you will be able to hold everything in your head.
2. Imagine you have an unskippable character animation, during which you don't control anything (no menu, no character movement, not even opening inventory). Now imagine this animation takes 5 seconds to complete. Not that harsh right? Now imagine that you will see hundreds of these animations during your playthrough. Here is the list of things that will take your time when they probably shouldn't:

Sleeping. The game has day-night cycle and when you go to sleep everything fades out, after few seconds everything fades in, Stella stretches, and you are good to go.
Failing at mining. To mine an ore, you need to hold a button. If you hold too much - Stella will fail to hit ore, and an animation will play for 2 seconds when Stella can try again.
Spirits. All spirits in game have their favorite food, food they are fine with, and food they hate. If you accidentally give them food they hate - they will play the same dialog, over and over again, explaining that they don't like it. It contains multiple sentences, so it will take you multiple presses to get through (sometimes up to 4). I missed sometimes and you just go "argh" and click through the dialog.

3. Farming. The amount of farming is not comparable to Diablo III for example, but you will farm a LOT. Honestly, without Steam guides I probably won't hit 100% achievements (or it'd probably took me twice as much time). After 10 hours of farming I almost gave up, but then switched priorities and started working on quests (which, believe or not, also wanted me to farm something)

4. There are small bugs (that don't influence gameplay, like animation glitch), there are some visual bugs (if you start mining ore from one of the sisters backs before she is fully out of water - Stella's animation jumps), and there is one bug that drove me crazy - during a mini-game with Golden dragon game didn't show me the next part of the screen (and I can't time my jumps). Otherwise, no crashes, wasn't stuck anywhere, no items missing.

Overall, I'd go with this game again, honestly.

This is a beautiful game.  It examines our connections to the lives that intersect our own, explores our own responsibility to one another, and takes the player through the full experience of death and dying.  Stella is a relatable character with a heart of gold, and she cares so much for the spirits under her care that even the harsher personalities feel loved.

The characters themselves are colorful, memorable, and distinct.  Each has their own personality, their own struggles, and their own likes and dislikes.

I warn you, if you have a heart, this game will make you cry - cleansing tears like a scouring rain after a long drought.

Many people may mistake this game for a sad one, but it isn't really.  It's a beautiful story arc about acceptance, and about finding meaning in the fate we all share.

I loved this game from start to finish. The farming sim aspect sometimes felt tedious, but that's my only real complaint. The story was very emotionally compelling while also maintaining a cute sense of humour. Some character stories were quite lengthy and heartwarming while others were surprisingly short and/or tragic, which I think is a good reflection of the long and short relationships we will encounter in our own lives. 

I really liked the art style, too. The game definitely achieved the "cozy" look and feel that was advertised. The music was lovely and added to this effect. 

I can tell that the developers and artists really cared about this game, and it shows in every aspect.

I enjoyed this game so much that I even watched their Escapist documentary about it on YouTube. 

Overall, I found it to be a very pleasant, emotional, and satisfying experience that left me considering death in my own life in the past, present, and future.

I highly recommend this game for those who enjoy a comfortable farming sim ride through several interesting little stories. Fair warning though, you will probably cry several times.

What a gorgeous, gorgeous game. The writing and characters is where it really shines. Each spirit is quite distinct and memorable, and sending them through the Everdoor is a different experience for each. They represent a lot of the different ways people confront death. For the most part, I found them compelling characters, even the ones who aren't nice to be around. I actually appreciate that they're not all likable people. You come to understand why they are the way they are. There will probably be one or two you won't be sorry to say goodbye to, but their stories will probably stick with you. There was only one character I found too saccharine and overwritten, but I'm probably in the minority.

Gameplay is cozy and relaxing in the sense that you can't really fail at doing tasks. It's a slow-paced game, but in a good way. It takes time to get from one place to another, so you have time to do tasks around the boat, talk to the spirits, fish, and so on. You tend to get access to resources approximately when you need them. The resources are generally not super scarce, and each island shows you exactly what's there so you never have to remember. 

My one big criticism is that, especially toward mid-game, it falls into the trap that a lot of games do--you have to have this thing to build that thing, then that thing to make another thing, and you need that thing to upgrade your boat, which you need to help a spirit or get where you need to go. Or you need to get a certain number of obols or spirit flowers to get certain upgrades, which you can't because acquiring those things is dependent upon other things. There are certain time or event gates as well that can prevent you from accomplishing anything until those things happen.  Again, this is a slow game, which isn't a bad thing, but you sometimes end up being in a holding pattern, unsure what to do or waiting on something to happen. It could have been balanced a little better so there doesn't need to be a lull.

That doesn't detract from any of the positives, though, particularly in the storytelling. I've done so much emotional damage to myself playing this game, and it's truly been wonderful.

Spiritfarer is a beautiful game, and I was captivated from the very beginning. I love how the lives of each individual character play into the world and the events. It was heartwarming and emotional to meet each spirit and really get to know them and understand the ties that connect them to Stella; from their favourite foods and hobbies to their fears and perceived failures in life and how she helps them navigate their final days and discover the meaning in it all. As the game progresses you see clearly how Stella impacted them, both in life and as she guides them to the Everdoor. Stella is such a kind and compassionate person, truly leading by example in what it means to love unconditionally and accept people for who they are, without judgement. I think Spiritfarer is the kind of game that gives you a lot to think about and reflect on, with a story that is deep and full of meaning, while simultaneously providing the elements of a cozy management game that are so appealing. I have nothing but good things to say about this game, take the leap and join Stella and Daffodil on your own journey. 


**ACHIEVEMENT HUNTING**
For those of you who want to 100% Spiritfarer: There is a point when you must make a choice with Astrid’s storyline, to tell her the truth or keep a secret. There is an achievement for both, and I chose truth in the first playthrough earning me the Loose Lips achievement. If you want both, you can start a second save and play until you get to this point again, and then choose to keep it a secret, thus earning the Tight Lips achievement. 

Alternatively, I have seen posts saying you can save before making the decision, choose one option and when the achievement pops, quit, and redo the selection to make the opposite choice and earn both in the same playthrough. I did not remember to try this, which resulted in a second save file speed running until I achieved Tight Lips.

Spiritfarer is a game that everyone needs at a certain point in their lives. It's a game I purchased a year ago, at least, and only picked it up and played recently, in the days following the one year mark after my best friend died. It is a story of grief, acceptance, and making peace with the life you've lived, even if it wasn't the one you wanted. It's about letting go, even if it hurts. And it does hurt. Letting go is the hardest thing to do, because we are clingy creatures by nature. Spiritfarer illustrates this and so much more in such a beautiful way.

This game will make you feel things. It will make you cry. And if you've experienced loss, it just might even help you, even if it's just a little. It definitely helped me.

And my god did it make me cry.

10/10 would recommend to anyone, plus a box of tissues or three.

Spiritfarer is the perfect blend of coziness and melancholy.

You play as Stella, a young girl tasked with escorting recently deceased spirits to their final goodbye, making them feel comfortable and finishing up any remaining tasks they have. The gameplay involves fetch quests, crafting, base building, and cooking/fishing minigames. 

The real appeal of Spiritfarer is in it's character interactions and themes. Every spirit you encounter is memorable and distinct, from the lovable and huggable Atul, to the pretentious and opulent Gustav.  You will grow to appreciate and care for these characters, and saying goodbye to them at the end of it all is akin to the final goodbye to an old friend.

Spiritfarer is an emotional and touching game on an intimate level that few ever truly reach. Its easy going and laid-back yet still addicting and encouraging to play. The music is somber, the artstyle is adorable, and the story is the epitome of "bittersweet". Plus you get a cute cat companion!

I'd describe it as a side-scrolling stardew valley-esque game about dying.

You have your boat - which you can build structures on.  The boat can (and must) be upgraded - some upgrades make it bigger, some make it faster, some unlock new areas of the map.

You get spirits, which need to be fed, hugged, and pampered, and all have side-quests that need to be accomplished to move them along to their final rest.  The spirits are finite, and each have their own personalities/needs.  This is the stuff that moves the plot along.

Then there are the islands.  You can move the boat around the map and visit islands and explore (that's how you find the spirits).  Your character also gets a few upgrades throughout the plot, which allows for further exploration - such as the ability to double-jump or zipline.

Crafting is easy mode in this game - for the most part, resources double when processed (after some upgrades).  One linen fiber becomes 2-3 linen thread spool.  One linen thread spool becomes 2-3 linen sheets.  That's a refreshing grind reduction.

If I were to have one complaint about this game, it's that you can't get rid of livestock.  I made the mistake of collecting all the sheep (because I saw the achievement and went "meh why not").  Then I had to feed them.  Every.  Day.  Don't be like me.  You only need one.

I had a fun time with this game until the end game content.

First off its art direction was spot on beautiful. Very creative characters and art direction. I also really liked the music. The game play was simple and addictive with a hotel management element of building on your ship and making your guests happy.

Story was good especially after looking at lore afterwards on this game, the sad thing about this is that I just did not feel emotionally attached to many characters in this game and I have my reasons why.

So here comes the bad. First off the game itself became way too tedious to complete anything and a lot was expected from the player. I have a completionist attitude and I told myself, I could fully 100% complete this game. In the end it required a lot of attentive grinding and doing things in the perfect order to fully complete this game and honestly for a story driven game like this it did not work for me.

Instead of me just enjoying the story of the game I was stressing out trying to accomplish every quest in every nook and cranny and I was also trying to make this horrible dog spirit (cant even remember her name, HAPPY) to just find out that you had to have had another spirit on the boat to even accomplish that.

I also had an issue with the pacing where it felt kind of empty where you would just be wandering forever to just find out there is a spirit you can now get to on an island that you happen to pass by. I don't mind exploring but after the hours I put into it, I soon found it kind of tedious.

All in all I can understand its my own fault for not doing the order of spirits correctly, my ineptitude to find the next island to go to, and my own fault for not getting into the story. But being honest on my opinion in the end I was stressed and irritated when it should have been heart touching and meaningful. I think with better guidance and pacing with this game, it probably could have been a masterpiece.

I still recommend this game if you like story and hotel management vibes. (I disappointed myself with Expecting more heavy story drive like "To the Moon" and "Finding Paradise")

Normally, I don´t interact much here on Steam, but after playing it, I feel the urge to express my love for this incredible game, which thrilled me through all kinds of emotions. Spiritfarer is, at it´s core and heart, a humane game and experience, which peacefully deals with the matters of death and regret. Whatsmore, Spiritfarer tries heartfully to show the beauty of death, trapping you in a story full of love, friendship and mystery. 
The game takes you through an emotional and adventurous journey, finding spirits, helping them, building your boat, collecting resources, exploring this rich world with Stella. Additionally, what also fascinated me were the smallest details in animations, either when Stella collected the plants or when she grabbed the food from the oven for example, to all the hugs we give to each spirit. 
The main topics and the richness of details is not the only thing which deserve to get attention, but also the emotional and compelling songs of MAX LL. The OST makes you always emotional and at peace, and Max should always be proud of himself for making an incredible album. 
In the end, I heartfully appreciate to all the people who made this game, its not just a game, but its a human work of art, bringining out all kinds of emotions. Not only that, but Spiritfarer also manages to create a beautiful human experience through the story puzzle of Stella, which brings you to a shock once you find out the truth about her and the game. 
Finally, this game deserves every piece of love it offers. It is a game about death, loss and grief, but it´s also about love, friendships and forgiveness. Please, give all the love to this game and the people who made it, it deserves it!

My feelings towards Spiritfarer can be summed in a single anecdote.
After handling a bunch of requests for many characters, I was already sick of watching Stella’s animations for getting food out of the oven and watering plants, tired of the moments I had nothing to do besides fishing while on my way to places. Honestly, I was not having the best time and was ready to call it a day.
Then in my usual routine, I gave Alice, the grandma of the group, a nice apple pie. For some reason, her earnest reaction as she ate it gave a little smile satisfaction.
Next thing I knew, it was 3 am.

Spiritfarer is half a simple but prolonged management game which respectfully uses emotional attachment to create a layer of engagement seldom seen.

It honestly does get very tedious to get progress, as beautiful the animation is and enjoyable most of the cast is to interact with, there is no guarantee you’ll enjoy all of it.
And for a game clearly aimed at young audiences, it certainly could use some more helpful guidance to avoid any occasional confusion.
But I cracked a genuine smile at a hedgehog eating her dinner in glee after grinding the fruit, preparing it and serving.

If that doesn't tell you the strength in effectively building a bond with the characters and communicating its themes with maturity and subtlety, I don't know what to tell you.
It’s a great experience that makes the voyage mean something, despite taking its sweet time.

This is a cozy game, but you have to put the work and time into it. I love cozy games and this takes the cake for expressive, interactive, and longevity out of a lot of games that I've played. I wanted to play the game because I heard it was emotional and that the souls/characters that you bond with will pull your heartstrings and those are all so true. Even Giovanni (who is a jerk) I felt empathy for the first time towards him when I was sending him off at the end. It's also nice that they add new characters to pick up every couple of months, so the journey doesn't end after 8 arcs.

The one thing that I wasn't expecting because none of the reviews or things that I read explained how much of a GRIND GAME this is. You have to mine, harvest, and collect so many items which is what you're doing 85% of the time. Of course, you're getting those items to progress the plot and to send the souls off, but it's a lot! I do appreciate that the plot builds on top of each other and you aren't doing things randomly, but yeah so much grinding. It's also a bit of strategy to plan which stops you have to make and where they are in relation to the map and what items you need or what tasks can be completed along the way.

Overall this is a fantastic game and the storytelling, plot, and graphics are PHENOMENAL. If you like cozy games you will LOVE this! If you're tired of grind games like Animal Crossing and Stardew then you might want to hold off starting this. I've played for almost 40 hours and I'm not even 45% completed with the game. It's one of those games that's deceptively extensive, but the game-play is still amazing.

I'm not a completionist by any means, but I'm determined to explore ever aspect of this game, and hope to play it again with a new perspective. 

Similarly, I knew this game would make me cry, but I didn't expect it to allow me to confront a lot of fears I have about life through cute animal characters and colorful lights. The concept of death and the manner of dying is difficult to talk about, not to mention creating a game around it. I could just be an overly sensitive person, but I'm going to keep this in my heart for a long, long while.

No game has made me think so much about my mortality and what could happen to those around me once I pass as much as this one has. 10/10, highly recommend, just please take mental health breaks when needed. Maybe have someone around you can talk to, just in case.

This is a very emotional game. If you don't like crying, this probably isn't for you. If you have experienced grief or loss in your life, chances are one of the characters is going to resonate with you. It is a beautiful story with a bittersweet twist. I am glad I played it, and I think this one will stick with me for a long time.

As for game play - 
If you are upset about getting quests that you can't do - That is because you aren't ready for that quest. It isn't a broken game, you are meant to travel around and do things. You will eventually unlock the areas you are trying to get to. So the game is not broken - it is pushing you to do the other tasks you have, and explore. Talk to people. All of the people. 

If you are upset about running around - That is what the game is. Travel around, collect items, complete tasks, help people. You are going to circle the map dozens of times. Travel becomes faster as you progress. It is, by it's very nature, a fetch quest game. You are told as such when it starts. If you don't like those kinds of games, this isn't for you.

It will take time to beat. Sit back, relax, and enjoy the story as it unfolds.

Spiritfarer came to me when I needed it most. I was just about to get married, and my mother-in-law-to-be was on the tail end of her battle with stage 4 cancer. I myself had severe death anxiety at the time, too. If you’ve played this, you’ll know which character was the hardest for us. 

This game rides a delicate balance of being a phenomenally cozy game, while also touching on the ever touchy subject of grief in the most comforting way possible. When it’s time for a character to go, you try with all your might to avoid it, but there’s a certain point where you know in your heart that it needs to be done. 

The more this game sits with me, the more in love with it I become. I find comfort in the thought that Spiritfarer will be there waiting for me when I need it most. 

I anxiously await for when my wife is ready to play again, but I’m giving her all the time she needs.

Over 40 hours at completion. Very chill game that you can play at your leisure.

Story: about how different people face death? Clutching for control in their last moments, or gracefully letting go while still in full possession of their wits... It was riveting, at times touching, and at others sobering.

Music: every zone and character has their own theme. Each of these themes support their character's story quite well. My personal favourite is Astrid's and Dahlia's. A lot of effort went into the sound design and it can be clearly felt. My only complaint is the troll option to turn off the music at the bus stops... (spoiler it doesn't work the way you would imagine.)

Art: a 2D sidescroller, but oh so gorgeous. I'm not sure how thematic the art for each zone was considering they're linked to real life places like Japan, but independent of references, the art was very easy on the eyes. Hated the hat, though, but oh well.

Gameplay: certain parts of the progression were awkward. I knew I was missing components for upgrades to progress, but could not find the components. Eventually I went online and figured that I had forgotten to talk to one of my boat inhabitants... When most of the quest cues are given by a big exclamation mark, the lack of cues on some of them is unexpected and a huge hindrance. If we ignore that, then the game progression is pretty decently paced. It starts out a little slow, but you need to figure your way around anyway. Eventually you find that there is not a moment during which you run out of things to do, but you can also choose not to do anything and still somewhat progress. That's a nice balance which hugely contributes to the relaxed atmosphere. While most mechanics are well designed, the one thing that annoys me is not being able to quickly select a large amount of one item. You have to press the key 50 times for 50 linen.

Overall: thoroughly enjoyed the game. Breathtaking art and music, an emotional story that helps you better understand yourself and the people around you, and decent mechanics.
