Do you like farming, management, story-heavy platforming with a pinch of [strike]tetris[/strike] building stacking?

Unless you are extremely against some of these, I believe Spiritfarer is a good game, for you! A game that you can take your time to connect with it's own residents, improving your character, while getting curious about your surroundings. After you pass your initial confusion, the game will slowly pull you in by making you do some semi-repetitive tasks (ok some are pretty repetitive) that will make you learn more and more about the characters, connect to them, make them happy, sometimes sad, but for you, it will definitely be sad. I have been pretty stoic these days, and while some of the initial ones that made me feel slightly sad, I did not feel like it was going to be that bad. Closer to the ending though... It was like someone was squeezing my heart.

Now putting the story element aside (which should be the determining factor of why you should get this) I will nit-pick at smaller things. 

I have a tendency to farm and and nit-pick when I am playing casual games sometimes. Spriritfarer was one of those. There were sometimes that felt like things were:

1: A little too repetitive. In some cases, I felt like they did not get accurately level with where you were supposed to be. 
2: A bit lost. Whenever I was sure at the correct time and place to upgrade something, I wasn't I had to go back and trace what I had to do. Sometimes these felt a bit tedious. 

Last problem is achievements. There are 2 achievements in the game that I personally did not like:
1: An achievement which makes you choose an option. Each option has it's own achievement and you have to play the game OVER from the start to be able to actually get both.
2: An achievement for making the residents happy. While there are some residents that are hard to deal with, you can't do anything about the residents that you already were done with. You'd also have to start over to get to that particular resident and make them happy. This is particularly annoying if your resident is a late game character (which mine was)

And no manual saving. You can copy your current states save files somewhere else and load them. But you can't do it in game. Frustrating.

BUT, I will say that this game is still worth it. These are extreme nitpicks. The game flow, the characters, stories feel good and has a good flow regardless, the art and atmosphere, music is great. The characters that were added in the update is AMAZING. It is very lovely. 

Good luck! With your feelings I mean.

Spiritfarer is a really wholesome game about caring for your spiritual animal friends, helping them with their final requests before they pass on to the afterlife. It’s a bit like Animal Crossing Terraria, both games I enjoy and also Stardew Valley (which I’m yet to play). You follow a cute little story, you build your own boat and you get to place your building and houses wherever you like with an upgrade system. Exploring a map filled with many different places to visit and new characters to meet along the way!

As someone who likes wholesome games and a cute cartoon style, this game is perfect for me! I was nervous about controls, it looked like there was a lot to learn, but surprisingly, the controls were really easy to pick up!

I bought this game to help me cope with the process of grieving, I didn’t know a couple of months after buying it I would lose my pet rabbit. I was absolutely heartbroken, I grew up with him through my teenage years and to lose him; I felt so lost and lonely. I knew what I had to do, I picked up this game and started to play; games are distracting for me so it took my mind off while I was caring for my spiritual friends, and when it was time to say goodbye to my first character, I sobbed on stream! Playing the game has been an absolute comfort for me! I have yet to finish the game as well, I can’t wait to see what else is in store.

Of course, grief affects everyone in different ways, for me, I even get sad over fictional characters passing (I’m very attached to fiction XD) so every time a character departs, I’m shedding a tear or bawling my tears into a pillow, but I’m grateful the game makes me feel, it’s nice and also comforting to let it out!

This game may not be for everyone, but if you’re someone like me who thinks too much about losing someone, this game might be nice to play when you’re feeling down or just need some comfort in your life!

Thank you for reading! Happy sailing! ⭐

I struggled for a long time deciding whether I would recommend this game. There is a lot of good to be found here. The OST is amazing. The art is great and there's some beautiful animation. I like the characters  and while there is definitely some resource grind, I haven't found it a huge problem. But there are huge glaring weaknesses that weigh this game down and even worse, the weaknesses are in what should be this game's strongest points.

In the game, you play as Stella, a young girl who takes over the role of Spiritfarer from Charon. Your job is to find lost spirits and fulfil their last requests before taking them to the Everdoor to move on. The game is billed as a management game, but the premise suggests this should really be a character-based game. However, after completing two of the characters' stories, I understand why it isn't advertised that way. As I said before, I like the characters, but their stories are without doubt the weakest part of Spiritfarer.

Part of my issue with this game may be the expectations I had. When Charon told me I would be fulfilling last requests, I expected I would be helping spirits with unfinished business, helping them reach peace with themselves before passing on. Instead my experience has been the opposite. The troubled spirit gets on the boat, gives you some quests and vague information about their backstory, then goes through the Everdoor just as troubled if not even more troubled than before. It's sad. It's unfulfilling and I get that's how life is sometimes, but it sucks - especially since I liked those characters - and saps your motivation to continue. I've actually [i]stopped[/i] progressing the quest of my favourite character because I feel like he isn't going to get a fulfilling ending either.

A large part of why these character stories feel so incomplete is the storytelling. [b]MINOR SPOILERS AHEAD[/b]. This probably won't come as a surprise, but Stella personally knows some of the spirits she encounters. This [i]should[/i] give their stories more emotional nuance. It actually wrecks them in a way. You see, Stella and the spirit know each other already and they speak as such [b]without any understanding that the PLAYER does not.[/b]  Key parts of their stories are referred to only in vague references or are left unexplained. It is so easy to misinterpret what's going on, especially since there is no option to review old dialogue. For example, I could not tell whether [spoiler]Gwen[/spoiler] was a friend of Stella who referred to her parents as 'Mum' and 'Dad', or whether she was literally Stella's sister. In fact, I came out with the wrong conclusion and only learnt otherwise from information I found outside of the game. Likewise, there is literally no hint in the game that the dragon Summer refers to is [spoiler]the cancer she is dying from.[/spoiler] You feel stupid or like you made a wrong decision somewhere when you reach the end of these vague stories and you don't know basic facts like what is the character so bothered by or who they are to Stella.

I started this game primed to like it. I [i]wanted[/i] to like it. I really, really did. Maybe I'll still finish this game to see where it goes, but my enthusiasm for it is gone.

It's difficult for me to write an honest review of this because the game is so charming and pleasant... but it ultimately doesn't make up for the shortcomings.  It's also hard to start because there are so many ideas slapped on to the game.  Is it a base management sim?  Is it a story-driven RPG?  Is it an oldschool adventure game?  Is it a tight platformer with Metroidvania flair?

The answer is yes to all of those and unfortunately, because it is juggling so many balls, it winds up doing nothing well.  I could (and am itching to) pick each of those apart, but ultimately I don't think it would have mattered how many ideas were tacked on IF the core gameplay loop was enjoyable and the game accomplished what it sets out to do.

The basic loop for this game is to pick up a lost soul, upgrade your ship to accommodate their needs, do fetch quests to complete their quest line, then carry them to the gate to send them to the afterlife.  Doing so will usually unlock the ability to process newer materials, build new base buildings, and upgrade your ship.  That allows you to explore more areas to find more passengers to repeat the loop.

It plays fine.  But it is boring.  There aren't a lot of DECISIONS that result in novel gameplay.  The progress through the game is linear.  "Complete" 3 passengers to unlock a boat upgrade to find new materials and new passengers to "complete" 5 passengers to repeat.  There's not a real impact on who you pick up, how you treat them, what you do/don't build, how/where you place it... it's busy work.  There's no critical choice and there's not threat of failure.  There are simply no stakes.

I understand that a lot of big, loved, successful "base management" games follow this same general outline... but it is a mindless, boring loop that the genre desperately needs novel innovation to feel engaging.  I THINK that the answer this game has for the issue is "stack 100 systems on top of it" (like mentioned earlier) and that the story & feels would make up for it.

The IDEA of the story is great.  You inherit the grim reaper's job--herding lost souls from purgatory to the beyond.  Having you help each soul confront their death and helping you confront death along with them.  The setting is pretty interesting as well... drawing on Greek mythology and taking place in a mysterious unnamed in-between world (Acheron?).  In execution, though, everything is so nebulous that nothing connects with you.

Aside from the handful of spirits you ferry to the other side, every NPC in the game is just an identical robed entity, indistinguishable from any other.  Even though you are intended to interact with these carbon copy NPCs, they wind up having little to no personality, are completely forgettable, and leave you with the feeling you get similar to being alone in a crowded room.

I genuinely lost steam trying to sum this up, but the named NPCs you find just nail you with walls of dialogue that have vague references to people and places you have no connection to.  They give you one of two types of quests, either craft something for them, or fetch something for them.  There's not much more to it and eventually you take them to the "everdoor" and send them on their way.

It's supposed to choke you up and make you feel a connection to the characters but with how obtuse and vague everything is, you really don't connect with much.

Unfortunately for all the praise this game has received, almost every aspect of the game you can compliment winds up falling flat over time or is under-utilized culminating in a hollow ending that leaves you with nothing.

This game is not for everyone, but if you've watched the trailers and you're here reading reviews I suspect you'll love it.

Good:
+ Amazing visuals and audio. It's a cartoon-styled game so don't expect 4k gaming, but you'll get some artful scenery and beautiful moments. The music for each area and character are quite fitting.

+ The overarching story reveals itself as the game progresses and you meet more characters. Each character fits into the overall narrative nicely. The characters are also unique in different ways. They behave slightly differently with regards to the game mechanics, especially towards the end.

+ There are small details that make the game more memorable. These details include subtle background cues, changes in scenery, funny dialogs, and much more.

+ The travel system in the game is pretty well designed, making the world feel vast but not tedious. The game nudges you in a sensible direction and the progression flows well.

+ The resource management is balanced and not too grindy. The game gives you ways to get certain resources more quickly if you need to.

+ The collection aspect of the game, particularly the cooking, can be pretty fun.

Neutral Suggestions:
- More customization for ship building would be amazing, such as color scheme and a handful of alternate building layouts to choose from. One or two of the oddly shaped buildings irked me. The position that the ladder generates on the building can be less than ideal too. The layout and ladder position is mostly cosmetic but can actually affect gameplay when you're trying to jump around your ship during an event.

- Animations for certain actions like failing mining would be better if it were skippable.

[h1]Spiritfarer: Farewell Edition Review[/h1]

[i]**Spoiler free**[/i]

[u]Quick Review:[/u] Beautiful. Sweet. Special. A must play. I might summarize it as a tonic for the soul. Even though the pacing can be a bit dragged out at times, I still say that the theme and artistic quality outshines any shortcomings. I cannot recommend Spiritfarer enough.

Once in a while you play a game that is more than just a game. Spiritfarer is that life experience. It has a profound and powerful message to tell. I have never played a game like it. Easily the best game I played in 2022. It’s a shining example of a game transcending it’s medium to speak to you as a human being.


[u]Gameplay:[/u] Spiritfarer is a much more robust game than I anticipated. Due to the art style and topic of focus, I thought it would be a short but poignant story. I was maybe expecting a few hours of gameplay. Turns out I was very wrong.

It’s much more of a cozy management game than I anticipated. It’s also got an open world element with exploration, base customization, upgrades, side quests, and mini games. I completed the main story in about 30 hours, but put in about 44 hours to see all the content. You get all the DLC in the Farewell Edition.

The gameplay revolves around taking care of spirits on your boat as you help them tie up their loose ends in their life. You’ll have to monitor their mood, feed them food they enjoy, improve their houses, and complete their requests. This will lead you around an open map as you uncover new islands to explore and find resources. You’ll need resources to construct new buildings and improvements.

The management side of things comes from keeping all of your workstations producing the required items. It could be cooking food, fishing, growing plants, smelting, etc. A lot of these workstations use mini games to produce anything, turning these into activities rather than just a collecting spree. If you complete the mini games perfectly, you get more efficient resources. But if you can’t get the timing right, don’t worry -- You still get a base amount of resources. I think this is a very accessible and friendly gameplay solution to keep the spirit of this game wholesome.

While the depth of content was a welcome surprise, I do think it comes at a slight cost. Due to the open nature of the gameplay, the focus of the story loses a bit of steam. It also doesn’t help that, often, the story progression is halted by a missing resource you don’t know where to find. My advise is to look up where to find missing items on the forums. Usually, I stay away from that so as not to spoil anything, but I think it’s worth it in this case to keep the experience moving forward.


[u]User Interface:[/u] The User Interface was a standard and useful experience that blended with the art style well. Menus stuck to the Everlight color scheme, and interactive objects light up with a helpful silhouette. Key bindings are all configurable. When I first stared the game, there were some visual bugs with the UI; for some reason the game thought I had an Xbox controller plugged in. It eventually sorted itself out.


[u]Atmosphere:[/u] Masterful! The theme, art, music, sound, animation, all of it! Inspiring quality!

The colorful 2D art style is very charming. But what really sells the quality is the animation. The game looks more like a 2D animated cartoon or anime rather than a video game. There is real care for the frames of movement that are a joy to behold. The posing is also very strong. Every character has a unique design and personality, and they are all punctuated by strong poses. Beautiful work!

The sound design is pretty good too. Even though the game is a 2D experience, the sounds seem to really support the game as an expressive world. From seagulls chirping, to the boat cutting through water, to plucking vegetables, everything feels appropriately expressive. Strong sound design!

The music is on another level! I already bought the soundtrack. I cannot convey enough how much the music adds to the beauty of this game. The moving and atmospheric pieces really add to the theme. But the quirkier pieces also add an individuality, not only to each character, but to the game as a whole. Fantastic music!

Theme: The theme is about palliative care, and if my review has not made it clear already, it is handled with a quality and sensitivity that is inspiring.

Inevitably, the spirits you care for will eventually be ready to pass on. And this can be sad, because each spirit feels like a true individual.

The first time someone in my care passed away, I felt the loss. It really felt like this spirit had left. I felt like someone I knew was gone. If you’ve ever experienced loss in your life, you may be reminded of that time. I thought of my grandmother who passed away, and experienced a little bit of that loss anew. And I’m grateful for that reminder because it’s a healthy sadness. It’s a sadness that comes from love. This game handles this topic beautifully, and I think could even be used to help process this rarely discussed topic.

And perhaps that’s this game’s greatest strength of all: its theme about letting go of those you love, and giving you a space to explore those feelings with such care. At least in America, death and loss are not things we really process as a community. It’s almost a taboo subject no one wants to hear about. This game is an invitation to think about it a little, and to gain a little more comfort in dealing with those issues.

I can only speak as someone who has experienced loss, but I imagine having gone through some deepens the experience the game offers.

This is the kind of game you’ll take with you after you’ve finished it because it leaves an impact. I’ll remember it as that reserved space that so eloquently nurtures that pang in your heart as you let someone go, and the meaningful privilege of helping them pass on from this life.


[u]Conclusion:[/u] Beautiful. Sweet. Masterful. And deeply Human. A must play. The best game I played in 2022. It’s a privilege to recommend Spiritfarer.

[h1] Befriending Death and Giving Them a Warm Embrace.  [/h1]

Oh where do I begin with this game... I loved this game so much I could not put it down, there's so many things to love.

I found Spiritfarer to be such a wonderful and unique experience encompassing various genres. It's a story-driven platformer with resource management qualities akin to Animal Crossing and Stardew Valley. The game also harbors exploration of the sea filling up a large map that brought back memories of Zelda: Breath Of The Wild.

The game has gorgeous art, an amazing soundtrack and has captivating story that truly draws you in.

In this game you play as Stella a girl who has taken the mantle of Spiritfarer for Charon, the ferryman for Hades known for his popular depictions in Greek Mythology. 

Given the story, you are explore and to collect the spirits of the dead, learning their life stories and helping them pass on.

In your journey you'll find yourself crafting, fishing, gardening, and cooking as you upgrade your ship and travel across the various islands in the afterlife. You will also helping those you come across in various ways to come to terms with themselves in this purgatorial world.

It's funny how the game has such a way of getting you attached to various buildings and stations. Stations that allow you to progress, feed others and upgrade your ship. 

As stories are told from various spirits of past, you'll obtain the schematics to these buildings in relation to former memories. For that moment of a young woman in the war who was a forger will provide you with a foundry and with your association with it... It will not just be any foundry for it will be HER foundry. 

It's bittersweet that the spirits that provide you with the duty to create these stations will eventually pass on. The buildings remain and your memories of them will remain along with their quarters, the ship becoming more full but leaving fond memories of these individuals but also leaving an empty shell of their presence.

What I love about Spiritfarer is it's positive outlook on death. Most games will have you avoid death, it's a negative thing. It's often seen as a mark of failure or a reminder of you are not quite ready for the challenges ahead. 

On the other hand, Spiiritfarer uses death as an objective, its the defining goal in what you'll be striving for. It's a game with a romanticized view of death in which I found to be quite unique and not something we really see in media today. And it truly communicates the positive aspects of death. 

It does so in it's world, it's characters and it's wonderfully crafted story that will leave you breath-taken. 

Spiritfarer is in essence a chance to give the concept of death a warm embrace, to accept it as necessary and essential to the overall process of existence.

Thank you for reading, I hope you find this game touches you as it did with me.

For starters, I've had to look up guides frequently because while there are prompts in the game, the game can sometimes assume you're further along than you actually are and not be helpful (like I was getting instructions to go places I physically could not go, since I did not have a rockbreaker yet). I also recently got stuck in a situation where I had to quit the game and restart it because I did not have an ability (the bounce ability) that the game expected me to have yet, but I also was allowed to access this location (I'd appreciate if things were clearer, like maybe have the thing you've done for one of the mines - I forget what it's called but it has a character stop the player and check for abilities under the guise of 'employing you' - done for everywhere that you need an ability to navigate the place, or have onscreen text tell the player that they need an ability before navigating as a reminder).

I absolutely enjoy the game as an alternative to me playing Stardew Valley all the time, but doing certain things in the game can also feel annoying at times (like I am genuinely not invested in any of the characters despite playing this game for over 10 hours, I honestly don't care about the side quests, and the mechanic for feeding your guests is annoying - like I dislike how the majority of them are extremely picky eaters and refuse to eat the same thing twice because I constantly will forget what I last fed them).

It’s always nice to have a fishing mechanic in a game that’s not only interesting but also important to the actual gameplay. There are a few quests that require you to fish something up (typically to cook), but it’s generally not specific in the type of fish you need for recipes and fishing itself isn’t too hard.

It does take a bit to get used to how the mechanics actually work (so you don’t break your line) but once you get the hang of it, it’s a pretty nice way to pass the time when sailing around the map. None of the fish are exceptionally hard to catch, just somewhat tedious as keeping your line from breaking takes time and patience more than skill.

Expectation: memorable characters with magnified personalities telling sentimental stories.
Reality: a slice of life game which is peaceful, soothing, and laid-back.

The narrative of this game can be basically summarized as 'normal' and nothing more: normal people doing normal events resulting in normal consequences and eventually dies in a normal way. The start is very slow and it doesn't really speed up later on. Is it a good game? I honestly don't know. However, it is indeed a breath of fresh air when almost all popular games emphasis on epic journey.

Gameplay-wise, every system is pretty solid and has some depth to it. There is this minor bug which make your character stuck while doing certain tasks and it can get really annoying overtime.

For 10 bucks, it is a decent chill game to play with the partner of your choice.

This game is a tender work of art. Yes I did cry several times. It was warm, fuzzy, geniune, heart-touching, and dealt with some dark/mature themes like death in a comfortingly real and honest way, something I've almost never experienced in a video game. I actually thought about my own death with a warm feeling of love, nostalgia and gratitude for all my life has brought me. I felt cleansed and at peace afterwards. This game was truly beautiful and moving and it was an experience I'll never forget.

Make sure you like management style games however, as there's a LOT of resource/inventory/economy stuff going on to make everything work!
The open world format was awesome, with some light Metroidvania mechanics guarding progression into mid- and late-game areas.  I really enjoyed the dynamism and sense of adventure / unpredictability the open world format provided.
The characters, dialogue were top-notch. I truly got attached to some of the characters. The sound design is excellent; I have to shout out the ambient music which is absolutely FLAWLESS and added perfectly to the ambiance.
Overall a very charming game, Studio-Ghibli-esque vibes, resource management in an open world setting with heart-warming story and very kind way of dealing with heavy subject matter, leaving you feel somehow healed.
I'll never forget the experience!

On the surface this is a relaxing, cute, exploration, collecting, and building game. The mechanical side is so well put together and balanced that, that would probably have been enough to make it a good game. 
But it goes so much deeper, the empathy and skill in which it deals with the tricky subjects around end of life grabbed me and caused me to actually care about the lives of the characters I met. And then you have to let them go, while memories of them are left behind. 
And as the end draws near... I wouldn't describe myself as emotional, but there was a point when I was gripped with an "I don't want to go, I have things I still want to do" moment. And in the final scene I had tears in my eyes.
Thank you, for such a well crafted experience.

Growing up, I feel that when I was in my teenage years I came across a few games that influenced me throughout my life. As an adult that type of thing didn't happen nowhere near as much. With that said, Spiritfarer has been THE MOST IMPACTFUL GAME OF MY LIFE. 

   Almost everyone has had some sort of death in their family at some point. I'm no different. My father passed away very suddenly and unexpectedly over a decade prior to me playing this game. I never fully processed that event or came to terms with it. Upon finishing this game, I actually feel I have now processed that event; and furthermore I feel at peace with it. 

   This game is not without flaws. It's characters are full of flaws in many ways. I've read reviews where people complain about how a few characters are unlikeable. I feel that's the point. None of us are perfect, and I think this game thoughtfully reflected that. 

   I enjoyed the gameplay, the story, the characters, and the total experience like I never have in a video game before. At times I cried, other times I was upset or angry. It drew emotions out of me that needed release, as I'm typically a person who does not get upset. 

   When I finished the story (no spoilers) at first I felt surprised and angry, but after a few moments of reflection, I actually agreed with how things happened. I thought it was a mirror of life, and how it sometimes ends. 

   As of this writing, Spiritfarer is my favorite game of all time, and one of the best overall experiences I have ever had. 

   When my time comes, I hope that someone is there to bring me to the Everdoor.

[h1] Good game, just not for me. [/h1]
Writing this review truly tears me apart. Spirit farer is without a doubt, a incredible, high quality game. It is notorious the amount of time and passion the team from Thunder Lotus put into this game. The various and particular animations to every characters; the well though out character design; the sauve, calm and beutifully structured sound track; and, of course, the heart warming story it is trying to tell.
If you're interested in Spiritfarer because of it's story and presentation, you're bound to have a great time. But if you're looking after a game that is always trying to one up on its game mechanics, this game is not it. My biggest, if not only, problem with spiritfarer is the repetetive activities you do durout the day. Your daily activities boils down to mini games, that most of the time requires [b] no skill whatsoever [/b]. While playing through the game, i would 99% of the time find myself doing simple enought tasks that ask you to press a button over and over again. You are always in constant movement, mini games here and there, collect (or farm) a certain item to do this and that, or travell to a specific place to advance the plot. My expirence with Spiritfarer was not the smoothest. [b] Regardless the presence of some small bumps in the road, your dound to a great ride. [/b]

Ignoring all of its technical merits for a moment, Spiritfarer is one of those rare experiences that had a heavy personal impact on me. While playing the game I was in an abusive relationship and, subsequently, recovering from an abusive relationship. During this difficult time Spiritfarer allowed me to escape to a world where I was able to love and help people, even though I knew they were storybook characters made of code. The game's rich thematic topics and intricate cast occupied my mind constantly, giving me a new perspective on the problems I was facing in reality and stimulating reflection on what I could do to solve them (and, what I could not). 

Even more importantly, Spiritfarer helped me find myself again at a time when forces in my life were causing me to lose hope I ever would. I realized that I'm a Stella, and that like Stella I had to be the person I wanted to be, and find or create the love around me, regardless of bleak circumstances or what others would have me be. Like Stella, I can't fix everyone's problems, but I can guide them on their journey and give them the help they need. And I can remember them. 

That out of the way, Spiritfarer is the kind of beautiful tapestry I've come to expect from the lesser known muses of the gaming world. It has gorgeous hand-drawn art and animations, an orchestral OST with many cinematic motifs, and a lovingly-crafted story full of fresh ideas and sophisticated commentary. Often gameplay is the most difficult thing to maintain balance with when focusing on a narrative, but Spiritfarer has just enough bells and whistles to tinker with to feel like a game rather than a book- most of the time. There is a slight lack of polish in some areas, as a few major bugs slipped through through and required workarounds during my playthrough. A few visual glitches caused minor animation issues, and certain interfaces like the construction screen felt clunky to configure at times. None of these weighed enough to seriously upset me. 

Spiritfarer is fantastic, a truly lifechanging work of art.

Spiritfarer is story-rich game about guiding spirits [spoiler](and eventually yourself)[/spoiler] to the afterlife. In order to do this, you complete small tasks for them throughout different islands until their time is done. 

Emotionally? I am destroyed. Every spirit has a personality that I grew fond of. Seeing each of their departures made me realize how little time people have. It's a reality everyone has to face, and this game does it wonderfully. Some spirits may rub you the wrong way, but it still stings a bit when you have to let them go. While the ending is a bit simple, the emotional aspect to it really hit me hard (I was in tears).

For the gameplay, the tasks are quite simple. You gather resources in order to expand and upgrade your boat in order to fit/build more facilities and discover new regions. It gets a bit tedious at times, but collecting items is what I personally enjoy. The game also offers rewards for discovering all there is (recipes, fish, material, and gems) in the form of outfits that you can personalize your character and other small rewards. 

The artwork is also stunning. I can tell the team behind this game really put their hearts into it. <3 

Overall, I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a good story-filled game. There's not much action (aside from the small minigames that are played to earn resources), but there is a lot to discover. I believe I got this game when it was on-sale and got hours of content :) I put about 40 hours into finishing the game 100% (with a bit more in order to finish off the achievements), and my time was well-spent.

This game is a sweet but sobering story that focuses on end-of-life reflection, whether it be a fulfilled acceptance of one's life journey or bitter regrets of what could have been. It's definitely something that will hang in my mind for years to come, as the subject matter had a strong impact on me. Those who have experienced the death of someone dear to them may have a similar response.

In general, the characters are very charming, with fleshed-out motivations and philosophies. An aspect that I really liked was that there was a lot of moral and ethical variety in these characters - this emphasises that we are all equal in death, and that a 'bad' person's choices don't just exist in a vacuum. 

[spoiler]A negative is that the endgame content got quite tedious. After most of the characters were taken to the Everdoor, the ship felt empty and resource management became tedious as you worked towards accomplishing those last missions to 100% the game, obtain Achievements or get that last passenger to the point where they were ready to leave. I also think some characters that were introduced in the DLC felt rushed; Beverly is a good example.[/spoiler]

I'm not great at platformers or really action-intensive games, so I was a bit worried given Spiritfarer's videos. But honestly? It's not bad, and a LOT easier on a controller. You don't feel penalized for trying stuff over and over again other than wasted time.

But what keeps me coming back are three things: the story, the graphics, and the music. 

The characters are all lively and engaging (even if I'd like to punch one of them sometimes), the story moves me to tears every time you take someone to the Everdoor. It's a beautiful analogy for loss and letting go, which is something I'm finding I very much needed.

The graphics are lovingly rendered, colorful, and vibrant. Everything has a consistent style and theme, and the natural elements are quite compelling. My only complaint is the flashing that occurs sometimes, such as when opening a crate, which is quite uncomfortable for me, even at low contrast. It'd be nice to be able to turn off flashing effects for sensitive eyes. As it is, I can't recommend this game to friends with epilepsy.

The music is incredible, with really distinctive themes for each character and location that add to the experience in every way. My only complaint is Alex, the seal, who has an incredibly annoying theme and calls you a bully if you ask him to turn it off. It would be fine if you could just turn off the honking, because the rest of the theme is fun!

All in all, if you're debating about this game, go for it! It's got its share of high energy and chill experiences, but you can pick and choose what pace you take (for the most part). Definitely check out the dev's Discord as well, they're helpful and friendly!

From a purely gameplay perspective, this is a simple quest game. This is a positive, my ADHD brain frickin' LOVES having tasks and lists to check off once I've completed them. You can complete the tasks whenever you want, there's no time limit, and you could honestly just spend the whole day traveling around accomplishing none of the quests and still be at ease. The mechanics aren't overly difficult, but not boring or lackluster. 
The game wants you to take things slow, but it won't drag. Stacking up on resources usually winds up in quests zooming right by if you end up already having all the materials you need lmao. 
It has a goal it's clearly driving you to, but there are plenty of instances where your actions have consequences. Not massive ones, but the choice to follow orders directly or even lie to characters is a choice that can slightly shift perspectives and give depth.

From an emotional perspective, you're just gonna be staring at the wall processing after playing this game. It's beautifully real, not pulling any punches and fully bearing and admitting the tragedies and joys that can be found in life, and the horrible ways in which it can end. How you sometimes don't always get that happy ending you were waiting for. Sometimes, you're at peace when you go. But, most of the time, there will still be hang-ups, or regrets, or something bittersweet that will linger. 
Even the ones who are ready to go will have something hovering over their heads, an acceptance not because they'd done everything they needed to do, but because there was nothing else they feasibly could change anymore. Sometimes, they don't even get that, and they just give up. 

You're not guiding perfect people, or making them become good. Some will reach their end and not be any better. Some might be worse than when they started. This doesn't mean you failed, because any change, regardless how small or in what way, was still change. You were still there for them. 

That's the part that I love most about this game. The characters themselves just feel real. It was the more flawed ones, the less excusable actions, that I liked the most, just because they gave such interesting insights, some varied change. 

This is a game about life, grief, and moving on. I cannot recommend it more than to those who have ever experienced any kind of loss. It's a tragically honest telling about how life will never be perfect, but it won't always be bad, either. 

Spiritfarer tells you this: you will die with something holding you back. A regret for something you should've done, for something you never did, or something lost you will never regain, material or mental, or a hope for something that would never happen, never to change how you wanted it to. Even by living life to its fullest, these things will happen, and there's nothing you can do about it. It doesn't mean you shouldn't try, or should live in fear, it only means that it's something you must learn to accept. It's hard, but it's the truth, and even death won't save you from it. 

That's alright, though. That's what it means to be a person, to make mistakes that some may never be able to fix. You'll still have lived, no matter how small you think your life was, and that's the most extraordinary part. 

You lived. 

Isn't that incredible?

Spiritfarer is one of the most meaningful experiences I had in my entire gaming history, although the game itself is not without some minor flaws. I could say a lot about it, but I'll concentrate my review into a list of bullet points for easier reading.
-------------------
[h1]What will you leave behind?[/h1]

[b]+ STORY and CHARACTERS:[/b] Easily the biggest praise I can give this game. Don't let the "artsy" vibe fool you. The game touches upon some really serious topics like [spoiler]suicide, abuse, dealing with disability and terminal illness[/spoiler]. Spiritfarer is one of the most genuine, honest and relatable games I could ever recommend to anyone. Even though the world feels magical and unrealistic, the characters themselves are very believable in how they speak, how they express themselves, what kind of problems they have, how they react to those problems and ultimately... how they die. Spiritfarer in essence is a game about dealing with the inevitable. I don't think I can recall another game that absolutely trampled me emotionally as much as Spiritfarer. You will find characters that you can relate to, you will find characters that you adore and also hate, some of them will be very real to you, some of them will come off as bizarre and you'll struggle to understand them. What Spiritfarer tries to teach us is that... life is ultimately a game we cannot "win". We all have to say goodbye at some point. It's a destiny none of us can escape. Spiritfarer simply presents some of the many real life stories ([i]that are most likely happening to others right now in the real world as I write this[/i]), often violent, sad and unfair, and then leaves us alone with the aftermath. Whatever we do with that knowledge moving forward is on us.

[b]+ARTSTYLE:[/b] The game features beautiful hand-drawn graphics. The animations are absolutely phenomenal. I played two previous games by Thunder Lotus, Jotun and Sundered and the quality of the art got even better than in those two games. Although that's where my first criticism comes into play, more on that in another paragraph.

[b]+MUSIC:[/b] Another homerun composed by Max LL. Every track is really memorable, emotional, technically impeccable. Some of the tracks are so good that I'm listening to them outside of the game and some of them (along with the corresponding scenes) left a very intense scar in my psyche to the point that I feel my throat tightening up because they remind me of a certain NPC or an event.
-------------------
Now for the criticisms:
[b]-SLOW PACE:[/b] Hold on, don't get the wrong idea. The gameplay of Spiritfarer is like... 95% great if you enjoy relaxing sim games. I enjoyed it almost all the way through. It consists of several minigames that you will repeat throughout the majority of the entire playthrough, discovering new locations, upgrading your boat which is kinda like a big hotel, a farm and a workshop, all in one. Spiritfarer is a game that likes to proceed with things slowly. Personally, I really enjoy when a game gives me time to process my thoughts and emotions. But I did start to feel a bit bored with the routine after... idk... 50 hours of gameplay? The last 10 hours of my playthrough felt a bit dry simply because I was running out of content but I still had some things to do, the quests just pop up after a few in-game days sometimes so it left me with almost nothing to do. It's not a big issue but it was noticeable enough to be worth mentioning. If you're impatient, you might struggle with this one.

[b]-SELF INDULGENCE (?):[/b] I mentioned artstyle and the animations being great. They really are. However, they really take their time whenever you do an action, like taking food out of the oven, pulling out crops etc. It didn't bother me that much, but again, I can see some people being annoyed by that. When you do the same action multiple times and you always have to wait until Stella (The main protagnist) prepares herself to cut down a tree etc. it can become a bit tiring. Look Thunder Lotus, we know your animators are skilled, we get it. XD
-------------------
I think that's mostly what I wanted to write. If something else comes to mind, I will add it. All things considered, Spiritfarer is absolutely the best game made by Thunder Lotus so far and it's an experience you open up to when you need a fresh perspective on life and the world. It's very similar to Celeste in that sense. Thank you Thunder Lotus. ❤

There's a persona for everyone to resonate with, from a sweet grandmother type to a cheating/pathological liar type. Each character moves on in a different way and has something to say that is all their own.

A side warning; do not progress quickly in the game. Enjoy it or the ending will really break the "feel" of the game. I rushed through and got to a specific point where I learned what the main character was (Stella) is physically going through. At first, we're led to believe this is some sort of fantasy based scenario but the sudden twist at the end makes it completely destroy that scenario.

The beginning of the game is super strong, beautiful game play, wonderful characters, lovely imagery, compelling story. 

The idea is that you are taking the souls of friends and family to the Everdoor after helping them complete their unfinished business. 

The characters in early game are lovely, however you never really do get the chance to complete the unfinished business, as soon as you start getting into the depths of what is haunting them they ask to go to the Everdoor. This happens throughout the whole game, the business never really does get finished and just as you're starting to get somewhere it's over. They all want to bail just as things get hard, it's very frustrating. 

The later game characters are less likeable than the early game characters, they are rude, bully others onboard, have no real depth of story until you're already on the boat to the Everdoor, or otherwise kind of suck. 

None of the characters feel as though they were fully fleshed out, it feels as though they went with quantity over quality and the characters are worse for it. 

As the story progresses and you gather materials and currency you can upgrade the boat and travel to different areas of the map. In the beginning again this was wonderful, however by the time I unlocked the last parts of the map I was stuck with the unlikeable characters and it felt as though the game was dragging on. 

I originally enjoyed the slow paced game play, but found myself in late game with nothing much to do and no characters that were worth hanging around for. 

The game gets so close but misses the mark. I really wish they had given the characters all a more fleshed out story (actually allowing them to finish their business, not bail as soon as it gets hard), allowed you to unlock areas of the map sooner so that you're not left with nobody on the boat and finally unlocking last parts of the map, and made it so that even in late game there is story worth sticking around for. [spoiler] Stella had already asked to go to the Everdoor before I had even gotten the last crew member or finished all of the islands, the last crew member being a nurse who is cruel to a psychiatric patient and who gets mad at you when you feed people good quality food. Not really sure what I was expecting, but this game's got a whole lot of charm. Reminiscent of Animal Crossing, Stardew Valley and the like, it's a chill game to just play and relax. In a world that's whimsical at times and sad at others, you meet many strangers, trade with merchants, and occasionally make some friends along the way. It all sounds simple but eventually becomes a poetic reflection of life and the journey we all take: spending time with others, growing close, learning their likes/dislikes, working out each others personalities, quirks, charms and flaws; growing closer, dependent even, but ultimately letting go. 

As such, this game is a sobering reminder that happiness does not exist without hardship; loss cannot truly be experienced without first having loved. If anything can be taken from this, it’s that what we care about most is most often taken for granted. And that will be the last of my clichè-ridden rambling, but it just sort of hits differently when a game this simple on the surface holds themes as deep as life and death. Gotta admit, some tears were shed.

When I bought the game i thought.... cute, a game with an underlying deep meaning masked as a chill managerial  game.

I start playing and to be honest a thing instantly puts me off, you must play as a brown queer, there's no way around and OK, I tough there must have been some plot ramification for it as for any game that doesn't let you chose the gender or style of your character...you know, industry stadndard.....

So I just embark in my journey in this overwhelming positively reviewed game and wow, first few hours are very nice, the world is beautiful the game mechanics seem solid and looks like I'm in for a treat.

But then, I keep playing and just a few more hours in and the game becomes incredibly repetitive. The task are boring and fundamentally you spend most of your time fishing and watering plants.... wow amazing but, meh, I'm here for the deep ramifications of the plot and the amazing story everyone talks about in the comments so lets ignore that in the and as any gamer i wasted time in worst games...

Problem is, you keep playing and there's no real big underlying plot, just a few interesting analysis of how certain stereotypical characters live in a way before facing all their regrets only when is too late and they are at the end of their lifes. You have the ultra hippi with father issues, the posh girl with father issues, the guy that focus on himself and now miss his family, the old lady that misses her husband and her kids, the lady with a swindler husband that loves gossip but she has a good heart and a few other classic stereotypes.

Still, this doesn't mean necessarily that the character are uninteresting but... the game does just that, paint the classic picture of your average stereotypical personalities and make them face their regrets together with you, Stella, at the death door. And atleast you'd expect something big happening when you finally ferry them to the other world but.... no, you listen to them blabbing a little more about their regreats, hug them, and off you go get a reeward so now you can improve your ship and move forward.

And so you go on and on on this loop, cutting trees, smelting iron doing some work at the loom cutting wood and fishing, over and over and over while you wait your boat to reach destination. Here you'll have some meaningless talks with the locals before finding the "not so hidden" quest or whatever the current quest target is and after you exhaus some more banal talk off you go again and again and again.

Lets leave aside that the game has an underling political agenda which (and I say it as an European) is obviously an American left wing one, but lets forget that as, in the end is the developer world so whatever.... But even on these themes the game is very banal and almost a caricature of itself failing in delivering a meaningful reason for why this is happening and just some banal common places.

So, after a few hours of this loop when I was succumbing to the boredom I started to wonder.... how come this game is reviewed so positively?

Well its very simple, remember the part of the queer character? thats why, this game has been made to become a beacon of LGBT gaming, if you google a bit you'll see how famous it is on LGBT blogs and subreddit driving the reviews to the moon. And this is it, the game isn t that good, yes the developers did a great work on the look and sound of it, totally agree, but the rest? Is mediocre at best and its so obnoxious that in a game about inclusivity and acceptance, they fail right at the start by imposing you who you will be, no matter that it has LITERALLY 0 relevance for the plot,its just a choice to attract a certain niche, just a marketing tool.

I have really nothing against LGBT nor brown people but this game is just using these niches to gain followers and relevance in the gaming world, this game as a game is boring with incredibly old and badly tough mechanics (water 3 fields of grains than tell me this game is fun) complete lack of QOL and very basic storytelling which in theory focuses on you building a relationship with friends that then you have to let go.... but the truth is that letting them go is the best part so they stop annoy you with daily chores of food and hugs in exchange to just a few line of background.

Once the incredibly well made visual and soundtrack becomes old (approx 5 h in) you ll be left with a boring game that fails in delivering anything meaningful, the game is supposed to last something like 20h/30h, hours that you'll spend doing menial tasks for barely characterized character and while wondering: 

Why the hell I'm a human queer in an animal world?

Mysteries of modern day gaming.

Before buying this game I decided to play the demo. I didn't quite understand how I feel about the game[play] since the demo was short but it looked nice so I decided to give Spiritfater a try.

When after playing a couple of hours I got a strong desire to refund the game I started to think that maybe there's something wrong with me — after all it has 95% positive reviews.

I'm not going to say that it's a bad game, especially considering how long I played it, but I played enough to get bored and negative reviews prove that I would get even more bored later. Repetitive gameplay/activities with lots of same long animations you get tired of, long travels on boat from point A to point C, sometimes going to some point B to get resources for crafting (from other reviews I got that going to "B" points will be even more of a problem later when you'll have to grind a lot). Feed each passenger (bruh, go eat yourself), hug them but like once a day (huge dislike for that 😤) and don't forget to talk to them if you don't want to miss pieces of story. And remember to water crops on your farm. Live, die, repeat.

Also, I didn't see much story in this game. Maybe because I didn't play long enough, maybe because the game doesn't really have the story. 

Some people call this game meditative. Well, if meditative is a synonym for "boring", then it was definitely meditative for me. 

The game has nice music and appealing visuals, but that's not enough for me, even with a huge discount. Give Spiritfarer a try but keep in mind that even though a game has a lot of positive reviews, that doesn't mean that it is for everyone including you.

I'm going to say that I'm really enjoying it once I got past the apparent soft-lock. 

What follows is an explanation of what I think the soft lock is and why it's happening to new players. 

This game has three major problems that culminate in the soft lock: a lack of direction, no tutorial on one critical interface, and a double jump that is WAY too tight. 

This is intended to be an open world game, which is awesome. But any kind of serious progression is locked behind getting a small handful of spirits to join your crew. The open world aspect just obfuscates this fact and leaves you sailing endlessly, lost and confused with your crew of one lone frog after you release the first three other low hanging ~~fruit~~spirits. At least he's easy to keep happy. 

Now, there are two other spirits at this point that are stupidly easy to find (and one of them is a twofer after you finish her first quest), and apparently there was a third you could fish out of the water at three spirits, but that got patched out to requiring four spirits to be released before you could get him. 

So of the two spirits a new player can actually pursue at this point:

The first requires you to fetch a quest item from the obligatory "you collected stuff, have a prize" character. Great. So you pull up a menu that lets you see your collection, how many items you have, and what the prize is. And you'll likely see that you are one or more short of getting the full collection and you will conclude that you have to go find the last item. (It's an end game item too.) At this point most players will move on to the other spirit and mark this one down as "come back later."

I spent at least five hours on this idea because the menu for the collections is badly designed. Collections have multiple reward levels for reaching milestones. This isn't readily obvious to a new player who has never seen a menu arranged remotely like this in the game. The progression bar is at the bottom, and the first collection that pops up only has a milestone for one item, and a milestone for a complete set. A lot of users are going to miss that and fail to make a connect that there are multiple rewards. 

Then there's the fact that the game doesn't automatically give you the rewards. It makes you ask for each and every one of them. There's no reason to do this. There's no Inventory cap. There's no reason I do not want my rewards instantly. The flow should be: Open menu, dialogue pop-up "oh. You have 10 X. Here's your picture, get out of my hair." Or there should be-at the very least-a big, flashing animation of the key command that will get me my stuff. It's an excessively busy menu, and the command for the primary function is just buried in a mass of  "that part of the menu doesn't look important" busyness. I found more than one person on the internet who got confused by this menu and concluded that they couldn't get to the character.

The second character falls prey to the problem with the double jump: it's visually too short. To obtain this spirit you have to go talk to a second character at the top of the map. They're only reachable by double jumping onto some cargo containers. But if you're like most platform players you're generally moving while jumping. You jump at a diagonal. And the double jump adds a truly pathetic amount of air to your diagonal jump. It doesn't even come close to reaching the top of those cargo containers.

So, again, a lot of players will conclude that there must be another way up. And, indeed, at the far and of the area is a bounce platform. Clearly, that's the way up and I need to go find the bounce skill. All the player needs to do is double jump vertically from a standing start, with moderately good timing, so that Stella can do the climb up animation. 

I'm sure the devs are extremely proud of that climb up animation because most double jumps wind up employing it. A climb up animation means that you barely made the jump with no room to spare. It shouldn't be constantly encountered on the ship! If I were Stella I'd start building things shorter! If double jump was long enough that from a diagonal jump the player could comfortably land on top of the cargo container, this would have been a non-issue. Does it really matter that Stella's double jump goes ten pixels higher? So a small handful of really crazy players will get a packet of seeds or a blueprint they can't use early on. It would save tremendously on broken controllers. This was bad level design, guys. 

And the third character, that would have saved a clueless player's bacon is just no longer accessible because reasons?

All of this leads to a horrible confluence of new players feeling soft locked because they don't have the experience to know how and why they're mistaken. 

I'm really enjoying the game. These are actually minor quibbles on their own that I managed to get past because I was stubborn enough to dig for answers. A lot of players aren't going to be inclined to do so.

One-of-a-kind narrative experience you won't get in any other piece of media. Spiritfarer is a long journey with a huge assortment of fantastically written stories, told with the help of insanely beautiful artwork and music. There are discussions of death, grief, regret, love, family, friendship, art, mental health, illness, and many more, all with important messages. These stories can be funny, sad, happy, warm, infuriating, make you feel conflicted, but the game is ultimately hopeful at its core.

As a video game it combines elements of life sim, quest-based adventure, and platforming, with all 3 executed competently. There's a lot of systems in place, and the attention to detail to make them work together and make sense in the game world is impressive, though the game does struggle with balance towards the end of its 40-ish hours.

[b]Update (Finished the game.)[/b]

Spiritfarer has been far one of the best emotional experiences I've had when it comes to games. There are very few games that can get me to care about the characters I'm interacting with. This, however, was an exception.

It took me ~32 hours to play from start to finish, doing the main story (and the free updates that were given). There are points where I feel things were very poorly paced, and things were a bit tedious, but I'd say I enjoyed the overall experience.

[b]TL:DR[/b]

If you want an emotionally touching game, and don't mind pacing issues or some busywork, I'd highly recommend you play this. The experience was worth it for me, but this might not be the case for everyone.

Hello People,
I doubt you need my review on an overwhelmingly positive game, but I'm going to type one anyway.
Pros
-Story, its so amazingly well written and told through the game play. You really grow to love the characters, if you are an emotional person like me, you'll get teary eyed. I struggle with death and while no, this game is not the cure for that, it makes you realize the process to life. There's something so soul filling about treasuring moments with these characters.
-Music, omg i would be lying if i didn't say this sound track has made it onto a lot of my playlists. Its just really good, found it on spotify, like if the trailers arent convincing you, go look up the sound track.
-Gameplay, smooth and clean animations
-Designs, everything from the world to the boat to the characters is so good, the look and feel of the game is whimsical without being overly silly, nothing feels lacking and all fits into this world.
-split screen, im putting it here because why not. The fact this game even lets you bring a friend along is hilarious to me, and yes i have done it, its fun but totally not necessary. Your player two, who plays as the cat which is cute AF, is there to help with the gathering and chores of the game. flipping wholesome i gotta say. 

Cons (theres not much here)
-i feel like this might fall under gameplay, but it says "stress free" on some trailers, you cant have resource management and not have stress... between gathering, cooking, growing, taking care of the spirits, upgrading you boat, and ect, you can get overwhelmed. There is no real "failure" in the game. If you don't stay on top of these things, you'll just burn a dish here and there, or take a little longer on some quests, which can be fine depending on the type of player you are. I don't think this is something the devs can ever change or "fix", because limiting players to much can lead to an awful experience for the players. You as a player just have to pace yourself, and not think of every burnt dish as a "failure". 

Overall this game is a 10/10 for me, but i feel like you have to be the type of player that enjoys these types of games. 
recommending this to someone whos only played FPS's or heavy action forward games, would be like recommending a slice of life show to someone who only watching Marvel super hero movies.... its just not for everyone, and thats ok. we live in a fantastic world, were being different and liking different things is ok. 
Have a wonderful day!

I came into this game blind and I did not have any high expectations. I simply wanted a comfy management game with a heartfelt story and characters. After playing for 23 hours I am at the point of pulling my hair out with how frustrating this game is.

The management aspect is mediocre at best, due to the game arbitrarily selecting the wrong plot for you to interact with or the UI being clunky and changing suddenly for a few stations for no good reason. The game also has a problem with very frustrating animations for harvesting resources. It boils down to either animations that take way longer than they need to or unnecessary timing events to get a perfect hit even though it gives you little benefit and is basically frame-perfect to pull off.

The platforming is absolutely terrible with all of your jumping abilities being on the same button, which sounds great, until you realize they conflict with each other and make certain sections far too annoying for their own good. The zipline ability is also very picky on when it decides to work which results in you falling long distances and having to start an area over again.

The characters are a problem in that I do not get to learn much about some of them before they go. Some spend a long time with you and you get lots of little conversations while others show up and then leave within a very short time and before you get to know anything about them. Even then, some characters get good worthy send-offs while others just sort of decide to leave. One character doesn't even get a send-off and it happens so jarringly I thought my game bugged out.

The writing feels bizarre and haphazard. Every character you meet feels out of place and none of it meshes well. And I do not feel like the concept of death is being handled with any real severity.

The music is pleasant and relaxing to listen to. The art style is also very well done and the animations for all the characters are fun and colorful. I have no criticisms in this regard.

I do not want to dislike this game and maybe it just isn't for me. But I have played for 23 hours according to steam and I have not felt the slightest spark of enthusiasm for it past the initial thirty minutes.

I found myself skipping through dialogue on a bunch of the characters. I really didn't like the way they talked. Some were too flowery others were just annoying to listen to. 

Your hitbox is narrower than it looks like. When you move forward you extend your leg out. After you have stopped moving for a second or two you bring your leg back in. This stance is shows how skinny your hitbox actually is. My leg phased through platforms multiple times and it pissed me off because I didn't realize this.
But even so, I shouldn't have to consider this when I'm moving around.
On the other hand, the player character has remarkably fluid animation. I found myself moving her around just to see her move. Making her duck rhythmically to Francis' Theme is great! 

Jumping up onto a platform is harder than it should be sometimes. Your entire sprite may be above the platform but that doesn't mean that you will land on it. Sometimes you have to hold the up button to actually stay on the platform (or you could double jump where available). Thankfully, if you are higher above the platform, you don't have this problem. It is super annoying when you have to redo a jump that you clearly should have landed.

Also, some platforms have railings which block you from jumping up onto them in that spot. You have to go to the part of the platform without the railing. I'm not sure if this is fixable but you would have to make the the railings somehow look more like something to pay attention to rather than background information.

One cool thing you can do in the game is hold down and jump to fall through any platform on your way down. Unfortunately, holding down and jump on a ladder causes you to spaz out because you keep grabbing on to the ladder. You have to let go of the down button. Also, the camera has trouble keeping up with you when you fall far. However, the game lets you move around just fine when you're off camera. Another cool thing about this is that you can't jump through your dingy. This lets enables you to hold down and jump for as long as you need and longer.

If you build a building directly above another building then the lower building will have a ladder to its roof. Sometimes ladders get in your way. Moving around fast on your boat comes in handy when you are doing challenges. Having the option to put ladders where you want would have been great. I remember one building that was so small that you could just jump on top of it but there was also a ladder on top of it. Climbing a ladder is slower that jumping so I would never use that ladder unless it coincidentally connected to another ladder. Also, the game makes you put this building on the deck of the ship (so that ladder is mandatory).

Also, the shapes of the buildings on your ship don't line up well. You will have gaps and you can't get rid of old houses (but you can move them). Gaps can make ladders extend downward.

Starting on a zipline is inconsistent. You start by holding the up button but the game may not recognize that you're trying to start. I've held the up button before and went right through 2 lines and ended up climbing a ladder instead. It is the only inconsistent part of the controls. The previous bad parts of the controls are just unintuitive at times. I could theoretically get used to unintuitive controls but inconsistent controls are another issue.

Fast travel requires you to first go to random spots in the ocean. These spots are represented by bus stations. The bus stations should be on the islands not in the middle of nowhere.

Imagine this, you're in an island town but you want to go across the map to another town.
So you get in your boat so that you travel to an bus station out of town in the ocean - not on any island - in the ocean.
When you get to the station there will be a dude waiting towards the middle of your ship. 
You have to talk to the dude there tell him where you want to go.
He will pull a map up for you so that you can select another station (in the ocean) to go to.
When you're at your destination station you have to go to the back of the ship to pull up the map again so that you can set your real destination.

Also, any sloped roof on the buildings you build will not connect to any other adjacent sloped roof. Let's say you line two sloped roofs up slanting down. Then you go slide on the higher roof expecting to continue sliding onto the second roof. Well, after you finish sliding off the first slope you will fall through an invisible gap between the two roofs. Also, peaked roofs have this invisible gap but you are unlikely to jump in such a small area on top of the roof.

I had heard several people praise how Spiritfarer handles death and how they held it as a quintessential 'cozy' game. On top of this, I thought the metroidvania aspect of the game seemed neat so I was keen to check this out.

I hit a barrier fairly early on and I can see this happening with a lot of players - some of the resource grinding that is required to progress through the various quests the game offers can be a bit overwhelming at first and I found it easy to become confused by where to find resources. It took a couple of times looking up guides but I persevered and after I while, once I got the structure of the game and how progression is handled, this aspect got a lot easier and eventually started being something I actually appreciated a lot about the game.

After the first few hours, I started to really immerse myself into the underlying narrative of the stories, as well as the strength of the overall gameplay loop the game presents and it became clear to me why Spiritfarer is a game that is so highly praised. As I went on, the variety of the characters and the issues they face hit with me more, and I only grew to love the game more as I reached my last few spirits. 

When I reached the end, I had realised what an adventure this journey had been and how much I appreciate what Thunder Lotus have achieved. The characters, the stories and the adventures will stay with me long past the time the credits rolled.

Let's start from the beginning. No words can contain all the emotions and my feelings towards this game. But the most important thing - [b] This game is may not be for you if you are currently going through a hard time emotionally or just really emotionally sensitive [/b]. It's obvious that the game's plot is all about death, but how the characters are portraited and their stories can mess you up (in the meaning that this can get too personal for you). 
But leaving that aside the game is beautiful and has a wonderful key message. Every character is very unique - has their favourite dish, house, story, mannerism and how they react to you or help you. You will have a character that you love or hate and you will cry when they leave because it's too easy to become quickly attached to them. But that's what's the game is about.
Besides playing the role of the Charon you will grow vegetables, fruits, trees, mine various ores and smelt them, build houses and other things. You can also fish and upgrade the ship and all of the buildings. After some time it can get repetitive but there is a variety of all things and also, there are collections - if you will discover an exact amount of certain things you will be awarded for it (fishes, dishes, crystals, ores etc). But also it's fun in the terms of dishes to discover what will you cook if you combine certain things ;))
In the terms of the graphics, I can't fault anything. You can see how much work was put into the creation of this game and I appreciate all the time the developers and other creators of this game put into making it. 
The gameplay is really easy and you should have no problems with playing it. Besides playing as the protagonist Stella (or as Daffodil too if you play in the multiplayer) you will get to navigate the ship and it's really easy. It's very useful that the game itself reminds you or gives you tips if it detects that you forget how to use some functions. And the thing that I discovered in the long run - if you won't be able to get some materials for some time the game will change them for something that you have already or something that will be easier to get. Also, the map that you will uncover throughout the game is really big and every location is very unique and fun to explore. It's worthy to mention that after the game came out the creators still updated it with a new content - characters and locations.
One thing that is a small peeve for me is if you want to get all achievements you have to spoiler the game for yourself a bit and get to know how to get them because if you don't get them from the beginning you will have to play through the whole game again to get them all.
Also, it moved me that most of the characters are based on the family or friends of the creators. It's a beautiful thing that these people will always remain in this game and we get to know their history.
 I feel that I should write more, but my mind is empty. All in all, you should give this game a chance because it's definitely worth the money for the characters and the story. It's relaxing and calming, sometimes the characters can lift up your mood c;
Personally I already finished the game (I only have a few tasks to finish it all), but I can truthfully say I fell in love with this game and I wish I could forget my first run and play through it again just to discover everything one more time.
(If there are any language mistakes please forgive me English is not my first language. Thank you for taking your time and reading this review. Have a nice day or night and if you will decide to play this game then have a great time playing it :)))

I just bought this game today, and have been playing it for around four hours. The first thing that struck me was the absolutely gorgeous soundtrack.. at every turn, beautiful, haunting melodies are waiting for you. The game itself is so far from what I normally play - but I have heard so many rave reviews that I just had to try it. The art style is almost whimsical, Daffodil the cat is adorable, and the game itself plays pretty brightly and sort of Disney-like. 

   Then my first spirit passenger, Gwen, told me it was time for her to go, that she was ready. A sudden sense of dread filled me, but as the Spiritfarer, it was my job to see her off. So, I took her to the Everdoor, and as I rowed her to the door, she said a lot of things that were shockingly deep and very real to me, this character who as a living human, was very broken and had a lot of regrets in a life that was obviously cut short by a sudden illness before she had time to make things right. With a final hug, she ascended and her constellation was traced in the stars. "That's really neat" I thought, figuring that was it, time to go back to the ship. Nope.

   What came next was a trip through Stella's memories, her happiest times in life, and at each stop I played the guitar to reveal the next memory and it was just so haunting and beautiful and overwhelming - I just can't even put into words what an experience this game is. It's an experience disguised as a slightly whimsical game, but when you experience these moments in the game, it all hits home really hard.

   This is some of the most brilliant game design I have ever seen, and I am honestly dreading sending off my next passenger. It evoked for me a lot of all too familiar emotions of saying goodbye to someone you love forever. Absolutely incredible game and I'm glad I finally got around to trying it.
