Like others, I really, really wanted to enjoy this game. The visuals are absolutely stunning, the animations are charming and the design of the world and the characters are beautiful. And the first few hours of the game are definitely enjoyable. BUT that sadly changes quite quickly as there is more and more added to the game as it continues. 

Like others have said before me, after a certain time the game devolves into a boring grind of staying atop all the tasks on the boat that is basically your homebase. Be it from watering plants, cooking meals for your spirit passengers, looming, feeding and caring for animals, smelting, cutting wood, readjusting the windmill, smithing etc. Things you have to do in an endless daily loop until you manage to progress further in the story and the worldmap. - And then more busywork gets added to it. 

I stuck with it for quite a while as my ingame hours can attest, because as everybody else, I've read the raving reviews about the deep story, the great characters and the emotional ride this game supposedly delivers. But eventually, I just gave up trying to find it. Because I found the game severly lacking in those areas, especially compared with all the constant busywork I had to do. For me, all that running around, staying on top of things, just wasn't worth it for the very few snippets of short dialogue bursts that give a glimpse into the lives and personalities of those characters that accompany on the boat. 
The first spirit passenger you meet, Gwen, is a very good example of this. She is supposedly a good friend of the main character, Stella and serves as an introduction to most of the game mechanics. And she also usually is the first spirit that wishes to depart. And I honestly was so confused about her abrupt departure that I googled whether I had missed some story-elements of hers accidentally. But... I didn't. Ultimately, you just don't get a lot of interactions or backstory to any of the characters. I'm not saying there is no backstory, because there is, but it just felt severly lacking for me. And this continues with all the other characters as well. There is a supposed familiarity between Stella and all her passengers, but I could never really feel it. Apart from a couple of lines of dialogue after certain quests that you do for them - which are just fetch-quests, basically - and a longer dialogue as you ferry them to their departure from the world, they don't do much. Just walk around the boat, tell you they are hungry, repeating the same lines over and over at you. 

And personally, I just feel this is not enough. It would be enough in a different game. A game where you would be ferrying around random characters, and you are never meant to really connect with them. A game that very clearly focuses more on the management aspect instead of the story aspect. But in this case this was just a baffling choice. I really expected a lot more, especially after the game had received such glowing reviews especially in this aspect. 
But I just can't confirm these reviews. The characters and the story ultimately are extremely shallow and feel half-baked or like a first draft. They could have done so much more here. More dialogue, more interactions, not only between the passengers and Stella but also between the passengers themselves. And instead they could have cut back on sooo many of those management-aspects that just bog the game down to a boring grind. 

And Stella herself is just not an interesting or compelling protagonist in my opinion. The choice to make her completely silent and almost robot-like in her lack of reactions, emotions and general behaviour just feels strange. Either you have a protagonist that serves as a stand-in for the player or you have a fully realized protagonist with their own personality and view of the world. You can't have it both ways. But how am I expected to feel pain, grief, anger, frustration etc. if the person I'm playing constantly smiles through every situation with the occasional frown or concern as the only things to break up the monotony? How should I miss a character that suddenly disappears, if Stella doesn't and just goes straight back to managing the ship with almost no acknowledgement of such a traumatic event? 

When even the departures of the passengers become one more task to tick off your list than maybe you've done something wrong in your game-design. 


Like I said, I really, really wanted to enjoy Spiritfarer, but ultimately it just really left me disappointed. If you expect rich, deep characters and relationships that really make you feel for those characters, as well as a well-written story, then I'm afraid you won't find it here. If you want a management game with lots of busywork and things to do set in a world with beautiful visuals, cute characters and lovely music, then Spiritfarer is a good fit for you. But I wouldn't expect much more from it.

Gameplay is hit or miss. If it wasn't for the story elements I wouldn't have played. Lots of crafting/cooking, lots of boating to different islands to complete tasks, lots of talking to your passengers to find out if they're hungry yet, lots of planting and watering. I like a lot of base building / survival crafting games but this was a bit bland for me.

I found some of the design decisions to be frustrating  -- why can't I tell when people are hungry or ready for a hug just by looking at them? Why are the recipes and the cooking options in different menus? Why are the crop management animations so long?

Some elements seemed unfinished. For instance, there's no animation when you [spoiler]feed a cow or sheep[/spoiler], and it's not clear whether you NEED to [spoiler]feed the ones on your boat, or how often[/spoiler]. The upgrades on some buildings seem like an afterthought. Some don't come with any obvious visual improvements either.

Overall, I'm not angry that I played, but I wouldn't do it again.

A neutral rather than negative review:

Good story and interesting, although uneven (and you need to be quite patient with some of them) characters, weakened by a grindy and, especially towards the end, boring, repetitive, and quite shallow gameplay. As stated by others, the first hours are the hook and probably the best part of the game. It can become somewhat of a chore towards the end, which is something you do NOT want in a game like this, with such a strong theme. 

The game clearly needs some QOL improvements (a better recipes book, a better way to track your quests and the materials you need, skippable text, one-click way to sell stacks of items, search function for ingredients or places, etc) and I'm not sure it's possible to combine this type of grindy gameplay with the emotional story the game wanted to tell. For me, they clashed together. I do like the crafting part, and building, and cooking but there's actually no reason to make most of that stuff except because you have to if you want to continue the main story. By that I mean that you character doesn't need to sleep or eat, there are no actual threats, and I suspect there's actually no way to lose the game. So what, at first, I thought were survival-like elements are, to some extend, just mandatory repetitive minigames.

Still, it's a good game, and I understand why it has been so well-received by many, but the flaws are there and should be pointed out.

Spiritfarer has managed to capture the essence of those moments a lot of us refuse to talk about and of the people we love who aren't with us anymore. I'm writing this review as I'm almost at the end of this journey, but I'm not really certain if I want it to end yet. I know I can just go back to my last save or just replay it all over again, which I probably would get around to eventually just to reminisce and that's the fun in that, that I'm still able to go back into those moments, because in reality you can't do that anymore and I'm at a point where I'm too stubborn to let it go for now.

It has been a memorable journey that has touched on something I wasn't so sure I was okay with yet and I'm not sure I'll ever be and that's fine. I've realized that no matter how you prepare yourself, you will never be ready for when or how they say goodbye to you, and some you aren't even able to say goodbye to properly, or even at all and that's just how it is, [spoiler](Uncle Atul WHY?!)[/spoiler] and that's not okay but also is at the same time because life just happens and is happening to you and to them.

Each of their words have stuck with me and will continue to, they each had different views of life and different feelings at the end of it, some I agree with, some I really don't more than I thought I would, yet know for a fact how real those scenarios are. So a bit of everyone's experience has been mine to share in the real world. It's been bittersweet, but I've loved every bit of it and I can never recommend this game enough. I just wish I could've picked it up sooner, but I couldn't pick this up as I knew what it was about, but now that I have I can genuinely say that, that person would have enjoyed playing this game with me if he were still here and he would have loved every bit of it because he tried to love that Dragon like Summer did despite the pain and fear and I'm proud of him for that.

The characters are BY FAR the best part of the game. They are colorful, huggable, and engaging. However, the storyline of this game is locked behind a few tedious issues!

The gameplay is honestly pretty terrible. I would classify this game as a collectathon where you run around and collect items that you then use to upgrade your ship and the houses for your spirits. However, where this game fails is the engagement of that process. The entire game is several variations of 'run around and press or hold x'. There is a *miniscule* amount of platforming that is not an enjoyable experience for me. Overall it becomes a tedious, annoying, and boring experience. There are some timing minigames (more press and hold x) that can be fun, but its incredibly repetitive.

The funny thing is I love the game Kingdom which is another variation of 'run around and press or hold x', but for some reason, that game is MUCH more engaging for me.

This game is a SLOW BURN, which is NOT a bad thing, but when the slow burn feels tedious... its less enjoyable overall.

For having so many items in the game, the inventory management is pretty terrible. There is no organization for your inventory besides the built in subsections of STUFF. So many games have even a basic form of inventory management, but for all the collecting you do in this game (feels like Minecraft or Terraria sometimes) this doesn't feel great.

The ship management side of the game is pretty awesome, but having come other base management games like Terraria, Minecraft, XCom, or even Kingdom, it doesn't hit the right spot for me. There's customization for sure, but not freedom or creativity. You can only rearrange the different pieces of your little floating village.

Again, the spirits are the best part of the game for sure. Sometimes they can be really annoying though! You can only hug them every so often, and they only need food like 0.8 times a day. For someone like me, I like to put a lot of effort into my relationships, so when the spirits go "Sorry I'm not feeling a hug rn," or "You already fed me," it kinda hurts IRL!

6/10

Spiritfarer is indeed a work of art in its own right. The atmosphere from the get go reels you in and makes you curious about exploring the world within. The art style and animations, especially for Stella (MC) are so so cute and whimsical, yet behind the superb animation lies a story of death and the memories shared along the way.

The gameplay is simple enough and a quick pick up and the story moves along at a decent pace.
The one thing I absolutely dislike is the repetitive tasks you must accomplish just to progress the story of each character and the ship. I cannot recommend this game for anyone who dislikes tedious and constant back and forth task fetching which, unfortunately in this game, is tied to the quests of the characters you must help to progress the main story. Some characters help you with tasks but their level of help is next to none other than the occasional free resource. I wish you could assign characters tasks so that you could get a move on with the exploration of the map and many islands that, in their own right, are worlds of their own.

I tried rushing through as much of the questline as possible but there's a time where you just snag on waiting for resources, stockpiling glims for upgrades, going back and forth between islands for resources, chests, upgrades, shops. I'm only 20 hours in and I cannot keep my eyes glued to this game just to play minigame after minigame for one little upgrade or building to the ship. It takes too damn long! 

I don't discredit the level of effort that went into this game. It really shows character in a lot of nuanced ways. However, I cannot even finish this game because it takes and hour's worth of game time doing daily tasks to get new dialogue or new characters on board your ship.

It's no easy feat to turn a resource management game about death into a cozy, story filled journey that you want to play repeatedly - but they did it, and it is truly a comfort game for me.

Even if you know how it ends, there's nothing to stop you from becoming a puddle of satisfied, bittersweet tears. Just play the game.

Update:

Initially I wanted to write a separate review for this but Steam wouldn't let me so I just added onto my old review. I replayed the entire game for a second time almost two years later but I want to primarily focus on the new content here.

I really want to applaud the team how organic the new content updates fits in with the original game. Usually with content updates they don't add anything substantial or meaningful to the story but with this one it's quite to the contrary and the new charcters and story elements elevated the experience for me even more.

It's also interesting bc I already praised the studio for their multidimensional characters in my first review but I feel like the new characters (especially Jackie) feel even more mature in the sense of how believable their characters and motivations are.

Same goes for the nameless spirits on the Overbrook hospital island. I do wonder in what way the pandemic influenced the writing but there are some really strong statements about the state of the healthcare industry and the inherent value of care work in here. And the new updates added a lot of context around Stella's life and personality as well. All in all I really like the new addtions and the QOL changes too (thank god for navigating in the dark). And it was all for free which is really amazing to me. 

Also I didn't mention it in my first review but I think the score is really good and it really makes a big difference in the experience I think. I'm impressed with the composer's (Max LL) versatility with style, genre, instrumentation etc. I'm surprised he isn't more well-known by now. My personal favorites include the music of the Furogawa region, Giovanni's and Astrid's themes, Last Voyage and, strangely enough, the Overbrook theme ([spoiler]I like the duality of it that matches the story[/spoiler]). And the final track over the credits always gets me.

There is much more I'd like to say but I think that's enough for the purpose of a review. I don't want to get into my personal experience with the game too much (though I must say I got teary-eyed when I sent off [spoiler]Giovanni[/spoiler] and [spoiler]Elena[/spoiler] two characters I didn't appreciate much in my first playthrough- two years can make quite the difference huh). Thank you, Thunderlotus Games, for making such an amazing game!


Original review:

So Spiritfarer...huh. What can I say? As you can tell from my time spent inside the game I liked this game. A lot. So much in fact I looked for every little last bit of content: upgrades, hidden chests, side quests, collections, achievements, I've got them all. When I finally finished the game, I cried. For the entire duration of the credits.

I just love this game. Of course it's got its flaws: some minor bugs, the game can be pretty darn grindy and if you have to perform the same tasks over and over, even tiring.  Everything else though is just- it's just so wonderful. It reminds me a lot of Ghibli films, as if you were playing a Ghibli character. The artstyle is absolutely beautiful (which was the reason I initially bought the game). The world building is much more elaborate than I expected which makes the game all the more enjoyable. Make sure you talk to all of the NPCs because a lot of them have something interesting/funny/thoughtful to say and I think a lot of people will miss that.

What I also noticed was that the developers didn't shy away from difficult topics and multi-layered personalities. How the characters were shaped by their life stories. They've got their flaws and burdens and grievances. Those things are what make them feel like real people.

All in all this game was everything it needed to be and so much more. I was very happy to hear Thunderlotus is working on additional content for the game, so keep an eye out for that. Anyone who's reading this I hope you have as much of a great time with this game as I had.

[h1][b]An Absolutely Well Made Game All Around![/b][/h1]
[hr][/hr]
I really didn't know what to expect when I started playing Spiritfarer.  Sure the reviews are good and the art-style is nicely done, but wow, was I in for a surprise!

You start out as this young girl named Stella, along with her little sidekick cat Daffodil, being tasked with this strange thing called the SpiritFarer.  I'll be honest, it was sort of overwhelming at first, not knowing exactly what a Spiritfarer is and all.  To find these (animal) characters scattered across the seas and to bring them on-board your ship so that you can send them into their afterlife.  It all sounds pretty straight-forward.  However, it is far from it.  Most require objectives that need to be met first before proceeding through the Everdoor.  It's all a mystery on what's going to happen next.

As you're progressing through the game, you'll find out that many of these characters have certain likes and dislikes.  They're affected by other characters around them, by their living situations, and by their food consumption.  Many factors make a difference in how each character acts while on-board your ship.  Some may play music if they are so inclined and satisfied enough.  Others may bring you fish, wood, or treasures they find along the way.  Half the battle is finding out what each individual likes and doesn't like.  It's not a requirement (at least I don't think it is), however if they are satisfied, it helps with your journies and makes for a pleasant experience.

There are many things that I can say as to the reasons why Spiritfarer is such a great game.  From the artwork, to the music, even the base building is quite enjoyable.  However if I was to choose one out of them all it would be Stanley.  I'm not going to ruin it by telling you all how you meet Stanley, but just know that I was caught completely off-guard by his first appearance.  It made me laugh and I'm sure you will too.  But, meeting Stanley for the first time aside, I really enjoyed his enthusiasm and personality.  Stanley made the game quite interesting.

That being said, all of the characters have different personalities and there is bound to be one which you enjoy or can relate to on one level or another.  Be forewarned however, even though this looks like it could be a childs game, it is not.  It is more really made for us adults that are still a child at heart.  Some vulgar language is used and some provocative scenarios are talked about.  I actually think that they could of made the game just as good with leaving those bits out all together.  Not that I mind, but to be family friendly for all to enjoy would have been a fairly easy task for them considering that there is not much of this language or scenes that take place.  I can see why it is kept as well however, considering that the various personalities do and act quite differently, and I'm sure they were wanting to touch on several IRL scenarios which could happen in order to relate.  All in all, it's not a complaint, however just something to mention so that others are made aware of it.
[hr][/hr]
[h1][b]Breakdown[/b][/h1]
[quote]
[h3]Content:  10/10[/h3]
There is enough content to keep one busy for quite some time.  I played for a little over 70 hours, however I had to run a second one partially through in order to get the last achievement.  (Sealed Lips and Loose Lips) You can only choose one.  There may be a way to revert the save file in order to get it with one play-through, but it only takes a couple hours to get to if you know what to do.
[h3]Animations:  10/10[/h3]
It's aspiring to see animations as good as they pulled off here.  From the water reflections to the character movements, all of it was something to behold.  I particularly enjoyed watching Stella and Daffodil's animations.  The few cut-scenes were right on par.
[h3]Graphics/Artwork/Illustrations:  10/10[/h3]
The art-style is simplistic.  There were no corners cut to deliver an above average product.
[h3]Gameplay:  9/10[/h3]
The gameplay is fun, interesting, and overall a pleasant experience.  There is one caveat to this however. 
 Sometimes you have to send characters through the Everdoor in order to progress further into the game.  This, even though being the basis of the game, should not be a hindrance to progression.  I believe some more thought in this area could have benefited the overall player experience.
[h3]Controls:  10/10[/h3]
I used a PS4 controller most of the time and the game recognizes quick swap, so you can swap between k/m or other controllers quite easily without having to restart.  All of the controls are pretty straight forward.
[h3]Reliability:  10/10[/h3]
No complaints here.  The game ran smooth and never crashed or did anything odd.
[h3]User Interface:  9/10[/h3]
Even though the UI is very intuitive for the most part, there are a couple of things that definitely would have helped throughout the experience.  One is the boat "improving/editing".  Takes a while to move the in-game cursor to the specific buildings.  Another is a tracker to track your quests and where you need to go.  Also possibly highlighting NPCs who have quests for you.  None of these are game breaking, but with a little more effort and thought into them, it would have really helped the overall experience.
[h3]Music And Sounds:  10/10[/h3]
The music and sounds are one of the best things about Spiritfarer.  The character sounds, the town sounds, even the different event sounds were all just amazing.  If there is one area where Spiritfarer stands above all the rest, it is in their music and sounds.  Also, the song that is played when you complete the game is absolutely fantastic! (I've got to find that song)
[h3]Originality/Story:  10/10[/h3]
No doubt that the story in Spiritfarer is by far one of the most unique storylines that you'll ever come across.  The fact that each character has their own story is a story all in itself.  I believe they tried really hard in order to connect with each person on an individual basis, which is, in my opinion, very difficult to pull off in the short amount of time that someone spends in your game.  Excellent job on this.  Kudos.
[h3]Community Vibe:  10/10[/h3]
The community absolutely loves Spiritfarer!  Go check out some of the reviews and the community posts for yourself.  I'm sure many are looking to see Spiritfarer 2!  (you better be making a 2 lol)

[h1]Total Score:  98/100[/h1]
[/quote]
[hr][/hr]
[h1][b]Conclusion[/b][/h1]

All in all, Spiritfarer is a very well thought out game that is intended for the child in all of our hearts.  [b]There are many things that I can say about Spiritfarer, the gameplay is unique, the storyline is unlike any other, etc, etc, but to simplify it into just one word, Spiritfarer is simply "beautiful"![/b]  The storytelling, the artwork, the sounds, everything about it is "beautiful"!  I had an excellent time playing and I look forward to a Spiritfarer 2 someday.  (you better make a 2, lol)  Maybe some guy named Asher and his dog Gio?  haha.

It's important to know what you're getting into with this game. It's essentially a very relaxed colectathon/light crafting game that you will have a slog through if you're in this for the mechanics.

The good:

What this game shines in is the setting, characters and the emotional impact this game has. It's a game about death, acceptance of it, inevitability of it and all the various faces of it. It's a very cathartic experience and sometimes it might hit too close to home to be comfortable. And yet, I actually love this game.

The visuals are lovely as well.

On the 'bad' side of things: honestly, some of the characters don't leave the same impact. I won't go into spoilers but while I understand not every character has to be likeable, that fact did dampen my spirits after letting go of the characters I had a great affection for.

It's also quite a chore to play at times. This really isn't a game I played for gameplay, as it can get very grueling/sloggish.

Overall I don't really bother giving it any arbitrary score - it's a game worth playing with excellent music and gorgeous art.

For me, this game is a 10/10. That "For me" bit is a huge asterisk to be aware of when setting your expectations for this game. This game essentially tells a series of short stories, and your enjoyment is going to stem from how much you engage with each of the stories. I myself was about to give the game an 8/10, like literally as I was writing this review. Then, I went online, Googled some stuff about two of the spirits, cried for like 5-10 minutes, and decided the game is a 10/10. So your mileage may vary with this game.

Let's start with the positives. In Spiritfarer, you play as Stella, whose job is to guide spirits into the afterlife. As part of this job, you're going to meet various spirits with different personalities, needs, wants, etc… You have to make sure the spirits are fed, their desires are met, and try to make them happy however you can. One way to do this is to literally "hug" the spirits. This is such a small thing, but holy shit does it do wonders to make you attached to the characters. I can't think of another game I've played in YEARS where you can simply hug people. 

Typically, each spirit is going to have an "issue". Another game tried to tell a story about a character with an "issue": Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice. A big criticism I had for Hellblade is that it was difficult to get attached to the main character, Senua, because there was pretty much nothing to her except for her "issue".  Was Senua a good person? Did she have hopes and dreams? What was Senua's personality like? I don't know the answers to any of these questions, so it was very difficult to get attached to her. Spiritfarer does not make this mistake. The "issues" that the spirits have are not the only thing about them. They have distinct personalities, you learn what they're afraid of, what their dreams are, etc… This makes it very easy to get attached to the characters. 

In addition to learning about the spirits, you also have to say goodbye to them by leading them to a place called the "Everdoor" (essentially the afterlife). Whenever you do this, there will be a scene that plays with the Spirit's last words. Even if I didn't really care for the spirit, I teared up/cried for every single one of these farewell scenes. The developers really know how to make relatively small things be tear-jerking moments (e.g. hugging, saying goodbye, etc..). Especially the last farewell scene where the credits roll and a song starts playing. T_T T_T T_T

As I mentioned earlier, by playing Spiritfarer you're going to be experiencing a series of short stories, the stories being the lives of the Spirits you encounter. How much you get out of the game depends on how invested you get into each story. Personally, I got invested in 6/14 of the stories, and I REALLY got invested in 2 of the stories, which is why I feel the game is a 10/10.

Having said the above, therein lies a weakness of sorts. Since your enjoyment depends on how much you get invested in the characters, if someone doesn't get invested in any story, they might not enjoy the game at all. It's totally based on a person's life experiences. I feel the game could've benefited from a central lesson being told that connected each short story together. I was hoping for an overarching lesson about life or death or something. Some of my all-time favorite games are Nier Automata, Bioshock Infinite, and Bioshock 1 since they all try to show a lesson that can be appreciated regardless of your life experiences. A small criticism for Spiritfarer, which is an otherwise phenomenal game. 

SPOILERS BELOW

Reading online, there kind of is a "main" story connecting all the short stories. Basically, in the beginning of the game you're given an explanation that it's your job to help spirits deal with any unfinished business so that they can move onto the afterlife. However, YOU'RE the one with unfinished business (i.e. Stella). You were a nurse and there were multiple patients/people you wished you could've done more for. The spirits that you see are the people that you're trying to help. However, nothing changes in the end. How the characters die in real life is how they die in this spirit world. You never get to say goodbye to your uncle Atul. Alice still forgets about you. Stanley, a kid, still dies. Etc… There are multiple lessons here. You can't change the past. Death is inevitable. Accept your death. However, just because these lessons exist with the main character, that doesn't mean the lessons connect with all the other short stories. Stella's story is simply another side story to experience, unconnected with the others. She had lessons related to her unfinished business, while other characters had stories related to their unfinished business. The short story about Stella is one of those stories that didn't impact me that much. 

SPOILERS OVER

In regards to the gameplay, Spiritfarer is basically a farming game with some light platforming/exploration thrown in. You take your boat and travel from destination to destination, uncovering islands which in turn hold various resources, spirits, quests, etc… Your boat can only travel during the day, so you basically want to travel during the day and do various farming activities at night. The game does a good job of encouraging exploration since in order to progress further, you'll need specific resources/abilities, so you always wants to find the next island instead of just staying in one place and farming for resources (since no one island contains all the resources you need). I am not exactly a fan of either farming sims or pure platformers, so the gameplay was just "Ok" for me. Nothing special. I will say though that I feel the gameplay could've been paced better, as it didn't really keep up with the story. I basically got the currency I needed to buy everything I wanted by like the 15 to 20 hour mark, but there was still like 10 - 15 hours of the game left! So by the mid-late game, I felt like I was just doing a bunch of fetch quests without the gameplay evolving much.

Overall, I am really happy I got to experience Spiritfarer. I am also really happy I spent time looking at other people's interpretation of the stories as it really helped me appreciate the story a lot more. Spiritfarer falls into the category of "Play it before you die" for me as it really left an impact on me. Definitely a game to play if you just feel like crying :P

What an honestly very beautiful game. I went into this game knowing nothing of it at all, and left with a beautiful message about grief. In short, the game is about Stella (our main character) that is tasked to be a spiritfarer of the afterlife who fulfills requests from spirits of all places until they are ready enough to let go of themselves. Right off the bat, soundtrack and visuals are amazing, they really help guide you to feel what this game wants to you feel. 

But what in my opinion makes this game one of the best game I've ever played this year is definitely the characters. The characters all have such a unique story to tell, all related to grief, and how they handle it. Yet, in a way, the story only revolves around grief and nothing more. For every spirit you guide in this game, there's no guarantee of a happy ending, every spirit's journey in this game is not about making up for the things they've wronged, more so about coming in terms with what they have faced. 

All people grieve, and this game did very well to get the point across as you see halfway through the gameplay that not all of the spirits you guide are kindhearted and you'll find some of them to be a pain in the ass. The stories, interactions, and just about everything about the characters in this game are extraordinarily well written and it also helps to know that the characters are based on true stories faced by relatives of the developers. 

Delving into the game you will gradually realize clearer than ever that the game is made with passion. As heavy as the topic is however, the game somehow manages to create this line of state for the story where it perfectly mixes afterlife metaphors and real life "what really happened" conversations when delivering the stories to the players. And for me, it fits perfectly well with what the game is trying to get through, story wise. For me, it shows that the game doesn't want you to focus too much on the detailed issues of the characters, rather it wants you to understand how they face it. 

Now going through the bad things, one of the main apparent issue me and I would guess other people face in this game is the explorations. Somehow they don't provide any forms of map when setting anchor to an island, and some of the islands in this game are so hard to roam through, with every NPC looking basically the same, you won't know who to interact with to progress through quest without brute forcing your way into talking to all of them. Although, it's not at all game breaking as majority of the time the main quests will not involve talking to the NPCs. 

The second issue I've faced with this game is, as you might've guessed, the gameplay. As does probably almost all of lengthy indie games, they can't provide variously complex gameplays. You'll find yourself less interested playing the same mini game, repeating basically the same stuff, as time went by. But somehow I only found myself not wanting to be bothered at all by the gameplay only after nearing the end of the story, so again, I think this game did well enough to keep the gameplay interesting compared to other lenghty, story driven, indie games.

Overall, it's definitely a 10.5/10 for me, though I can see well the issues this game has, I'm forced to look away as the stories told in this game are some of the most well written stories I've encountered in a game this year.

However I found it difficult to return to the game after a break due to the very brief non-descriptive nature of the quest log. I also found myself soft-locked or having to turn to google for a couple of solutions to problems (not being able to get a particular resource for a quest and not realising a certain passenger was ready to pass on) - maybe additional tooltips or hints would be useful.

These flaws are minor and do not subtract from the overall value of the game. The story is endearing and the soft colouring and vibrant characters make for a unique, emotional and relaxing game well worth your money.

Spiritfarer is essentially a game about coping with death. On the surface, it's a cute little management game but when you go a little deeper it is in fact very somber at times.

The gameplay mostly takes place on your boat, which you will upgrade multiple times through the course of the game, and on various island scattered throughout the sea. There are clear progression systems in place which makes exploring fairly linear at first, which is a good thing in my opinion. The game feels really huge at the start, so limiting access to certain areas makes it easier to figure out what your current objective is. You never really run out of things to do while you're on your way to certain islands, as you can cook food, water your crops, shear your sheep etc.
The art style and the music goes really well together, and it allows for some emotional moments in the story.

The game is great, and definitely worth full price. Just try to keep track of the time while playing because it's kinda crazy how addicting it is.

Soon after becoming the new Spiritfarer, I ran into my childhood friend who recognized me immediately. She eagerly joined my boat as a passenger. She helped guide me through my first paces as a Spiritfarer, and I felt like we went on an adventure as even more spirits joined the boat. I built her a house and decorated it, and she in turn would help around the boat by spinning threads and buying supplies for me. She would encourage me to collect bright jellies whenever we wandered into a patch of them, despite her fears of them. I would cook her meals, going out of my way to cook foods that I knew she would enjoy. And as we traveled, she was always there to lend advice, or simply her voice. I felt like I really bonded with her.

And then she was gone. Her house remained, sitting empty. She was no longer present for the bright jelly events, nobody was spinning threads at the loom anymore, and i wouldn't see her out in the city shopping for supplies. She wasn't there as i welcomed more passengers aboard the ship. All that was left was a flower to remember her by.  For the rest of the game, there is a tangible hole left behind where she once was, and it only gets bigger as you say goodbye to your other passengers one by one throughout your journey.

This game is beautiful. I don't want to say goodbye.

I really wanted to like this game, and in the first 7or so hours I really did. Then as the hours passed it gradually lost its magic, and in the last 5 hours it simply felt tedious and tiring, like a very long homework which never ends. 

My main problem was that even though the marketing line said "cozy management" it was not cozy at all. It was actually very heavy on that front... 

- In the game you have to build always another and another building which is necessary to process the materials to finish quests (and build even more building). And this would be ok, since it is a management game, but every new building is a new minigame, and some are actually interesting (in the first 100 times you do it), but they become so boring, also later in the game some of them are just mindless clicking and a huge waste of time. 
- The resources are the same, some are simple, like chopping trees, but many of the resources are tied to quite long mini games and the first ones are interesting (at the first couple of times), but the rest is just copies of the previous ones with different design and "story"
- And both the building and the resources could be ok, if with some building or character upgrade you could get the resource without the minigame. The special resources would still work if you could get them without minigames after you did them once (like why do you have to fight the dragons again and again? After the first fight they could simply give you the resource like that huge turtle). Or the building could be managed by the characters on the ship, or you could give them tasks, but they are doing literally nothing...
- Playing with Stella feels like being an errandgirl, the spirits are constantly pestering you, because they are hungry, they want attention, they want different food, they want you to hurry with their quest. Also because you cannot travel at night and you cannot even check the freaking map during the night (In such games I always plan the following day at night checking the quest/resource locations on the map) you are in constant rush to reach the next island/resource in daylight then run up and down the ship to process the materials at night for the quests. It is stressful. 
- The first couple of characters are loveable and cute, but as they leave the ship and the new spirits come, oh my god, they are annoying as hell (like Giovanni and that A*hole hummingbird...)

Sorry for the rant. I still think that the game has huge potential, but it was wasted on the tedious gameplay

There is an exchange in Moby-Dick where a sailor asks the protagonist why they want to join a whaling ship. "To see the world" is essentially the response. The sailor directs him to the vast, featureless expanse of the ocean at the end of the dock and asks the protagonist if they've seen enough of the world yet. This game was very reminiscent of that scene.

Where this game tries to shine is in the interactions between the main character and the spirits that they are ferrying to the afterlife, but for me these interactions were at at best shallow and at worst annoying. Unlike other social games the NPCs do not interact with each other in any meaningful way. There are idle animations of them talking to each other, but you cannot eavesdrop, and outside of quest-specific observations they don't tell you how they feel about the other characters. In fact, other that to tell them they're hungry or to start a mini-game, the spirits don't seem to interact with the protagonist outside of quest-specific interactions. Additionally, the protagonist is apparently mute, so most of these conversations are one sided, with the spirits talking *at* the protagonist rather than *to* them. Coupled these one-sided conversations with the fact that the vast majority of interactions with the spirits are them asking/demanding something of me made me feel like a maligned service industry worker who just wanted these spirits off my ship (Except Atul, Atul's cool). I found myself trying to rush through character's quests because, in addition to getting them off my boat faster, that's the only way you learn about them and maybe humanize them. But even that was unsatisfying, as you never really learn enough about them to make them feel real. As a specific example ***MINOR SPOILER*** there is a character that talks about a "dragon" that harried them in their life. Naturally I assumed this meant they'd had a heroin addiction. Later it's clarified that this is a euphemism for some mental issue they and their father had had in life and never conquered, but you never find out what it is a euphemism for. Is it anxiety? Greed? Hubris? Guilt? Addiction to heroin? All are possible interpretations by the end of their story. And they do that sort of thing for every character I played through ****MINOR SPOILER OVER**** They hint at depths for these spirits, but never let you dive into them.

Exploration is, exceptionally flat. Locations are filled with literally faceless NPCs, none of them felt distinct or memorable, and past collecting resources and quest-specific tasks there was no real reason to go to any of them. The artwork for the ship upgrades were beautiful, until I ran out of space and had to start stacking them, at which point they looked like a bunch of blocky shipping containers. I found the artwork for everything was beautiful, and I found a lot of the initial interactions with the few non-faceless NPCs quite enjoyable (particularly Albert) but for a game that takes place on an ocean, almost every aspect felt extremely shallow. The fact that everyone is dead and it NEVER comes up is also extremely jarring and opens up a a whole can of worms (like what about the fish you're eating? Are they already dead? Can they die again? Are they still 'alive' when you eat them because they also need to be passed through the Everdoor to truly move on?) but I don't have time to get into that. 

All in all, it's not a challenging game, it isn't trying to be and it shouldn't have to be, but it needs to have something, and I couldn't find anything that I can say was worth the time.

The game mechanics for Spiritfarer are very simple, very repetitive and very satisfying, until about the end game. You go around in your boat to different islands, meeting new people and - in some cases - having those people join you on your ship. During your travels you will fish, mine, plant, grow and harvest crops, cook food, spin various types of thread and cloth, make ingots, etc - all with the purpose of creating or upgrading new buildings on your ship and keeping your residents fed with the food they want to eat.

It's very calming in that way, though I have to say that by probably the middle of the game (15 hours for me) I was done with the gameplay loop, as that sort of activity doesn't seem to hold my interest (but that's just me). However, that said, even though I was done with it about 15 hours in - I spent another 15 hours to finish the game.....and the main reason why is because the story hooked me enough that I wanted to see it through, as they did a really good job with it.

早早入了Spiritfarer，因为不错的画风、对配乐以及类似的作品题材比较感兴趣，但不得不说断续玩了快9个小时还是不太能get到好玩的地方，可能有我个人原因吧但没法提起玩下去的兴趣，所以想来想去最后还是不给recommended了。

游戏的画面是最早吸引我的地方，旅行的元素同样会让我觉得与大家共同构建家园然后再给人家送走独具一格，就是游戏的玩法属实不太能接受。整个游戏的大概流程就是从接人上船、给人跑腿、把他送走，同样有一个目标系统随时提醒你还有什么没做，我也可以在船上种种菜搞搞养成，给自己升升级，这其实也都没啥，玩法上也中规中矩。

我不太能接受我在有一个这样的养成模式下游戏[u][b]节奏很乱[/b][/u]，比如我去浇水要等动画、我去炼矿的时候甚至要自己跑腿一遍遍地控制熔炉温度。这些动画或者小细节会给我一种明显在放慢游戏节奏的感觉，但是一堆灵魂和objectives还催着我规划今天去哪明天去哪的，把资源安排得紧凑合理，结果就很膈应。

[u][b]游戏的引导[/b][/u]感觉做的很模糊，比如Atul中间想吃pork、或者Summer想要一些宝石、或者破冰扩图，游戏虽然给了很多目标但任务引导上我没感觉出比较合理的逻辑，这导致我卡了好多任务在任务栏里甚至有的不知道怎么做，还花了很多时间在地图里面瞎跑找资源，干很多重复的寻找。

剧情上，除了我个人还挺喜欢Atul的，但像Gwen、Summer以及后面的Astrid、Alice等故事感觉还是比较松散，确实讲了很多，但我依然觉得云里雾里的，更像是一个散文（？）

即便如此，Spiritfarer的画面和[u][b]配乐、音效[/b][/u]确实要吹，比较印象深刻的是在Thunder harvest里面打雷的音效结合Atul的曲子很令人享受。采雷的时候雷声给我一种很干脆利落而不是低沉的感觉，搭配上Atul吹的欢快，会让我觉得自己更多是在没有顾虑的撒欢而不是单纯的采集材料完成任务。

原声里面的Spiritfarer本曲也很喜欢，感兴趣可以去听一下，其实游戏里很多地方的曲子都是主题的变奏（比如你在地里对草弹琴的那个曲子）


[h1]总结[/h1]
精美手绘、顶级配乐，但是迷惑在种田模式里享受生活同时却催我完成任务，也没有找到奇怪的资源在哪里，本体剧情更像是一个艺术品吧。
也许把一些中规中矩的养成元素去掉，老老实实做一个艺术品反而会让我享受很多。

I had high expectations heading into this game, and it left me disappointed. What a player is promised is a game where we help spirits of the deceased get to the afterlife, which assumes the player will learn their stories get attached to said spirits throughout the game, with some management mechanics, such as building houses and cooking for them.

However, as I've been playing, it looked like some of those very spirits we were supposed to empathize with were deliberately created to make you roll your eyes every time they start talking. The amount of cliche daddy issues illustrated in the game is far beyond healthy, [spoiler] making me not feel bad when as I brought them to the Everdoor. [/spoiler] While the game definitely offers a great variety of characters, some of them are utterly ridiculous [spoiler] , such as a ton of unskippable riddle-heavy statements from an apparently schizophrenic bat. In all that circus, even grumpy Bruce and Mickey seem like alright characters. [/spoiler] That being said, despite being marked as emotional and story rich, the most I was able to feel while playing this game is a feeling [b] remotely resembling mild sadness. [/b]

Now for the management part. It feels like the game was constantly made hold the player hostage, by making them wait for [b] everything [/b] to happen. Want to progress in a spirit's quest? Wait a few days for them to do something first (in one particular case it took a spirit 6 in-game days to allow you to progress). Want a specific resource that only appears in 2 locations on the entire map? Well, make sure to sail there first on your turtle of a ship. Oh, also, you can't go anywhere at night, so how about we spend some more time on nothing! You will also be encountering such issues as not having enough space on your ship to have all stations and houses that you need, which of course will drain even more of your time

There is not much to say in regards of animation and soundtrack, these are really good, and I could say this is where the developers put the most efforts, unfortunately

To sum it all up, we have a game that takes about 15-20 hours to complete, and looking back you won't be able to answer what took you so long. The good moments are too few and far between to call it a good game, with huge emphasis on wasting time and making you like unlikeable characters (in all fairness, there were good ones, too). With that said, I can't say it's an awful game, but it's definitely not enough to call it good, and my biggest regret is not playing it, but rather playing it for as long as I have. Not for me, 4/10

I had no idea what to expect when I purchased Spiritfarer but it delivered way past what I could've imagined. 

THE GOOD

First of all, this game just looks stunning! Everything is so beautifully animated, from locations to character movements. Character design is especially impressive, with each character looking like they came straight from Studio Ghibli movie. It was just a joy to look at the whole time and its what drew my attention to the game in the first place. Sound design and soundtrack compliment the visuals perfectly and together they create this very relaxing and magical atmosphere. 
When it comes to gameplay, Spiritfarer tries to be many things and it actually pulls it off. Game revolves around you sailing your ship around an open world archipelago discovering new locations and finding spirits to join your crew. You must build housing for your new friends and cook them food to keep their spirits up but in order to do so you must build various resource-production buildings and engage in side activities like fishing and all sorts of minigames. So its an exploration/resource management hybrid at first glance but then you come to a new island and you have to engage in some platforming to explore its secrets and later in the game, in order to gain access to new areas, you must upgrade your ship and unlock new abilities making Spiritfarer also a sort of metroidvania. It seems like a lot but each part of the game is done in just the right amount so it all works well together. Controls are very simple and there is no combat at all yet the game is far from boring.
But the heart of Spiritfarer are its story and characters and..my eyes were very wet a few times. Without spoiling anything..no matter how fantastical it looks on the outside, on the inside its an incredibly human story that most of us can relate to. Its about life and death, about family and friendship and ultimately about leting go. Your job is to find these spirits, care for them and then eventually let them go. And its hard to let them go because each of them is expertly written and some of them will probably remind you of someone you know or knew..or loved. Its a beautiful story worthy of praise.

THE BAD

As much as I want to say that Spiritfarer is perfect..its not. It does have some problems or, better said, fluff without which it would have been a tighter experience. Biggest offender are these minigames called events ingame. There is a lot of them but the problem is they are all the same event reskined multiple times. They all revolve around you jumping around your ship collecting various shiny objects that can be turned in less common materials for crafting. These materials imo are just a time sink because there is plenty of other materials that are more than enough. These events are fun and interesting the first few times you play them but my guess is that everyone skips them afterwards. 
The other thing is grinding. While it never got so bad that it made me quit the game, the more I played the more boring crafting and hunting down materials became. I always grow bored really fast with resource management games because they are too grindy or needlesly complex (looking at you Graveyard Keeper!) but it wasnt so bad here. Noticable..but not too bad.
And..backtracking. There is a lot of it. You will be returning to same locations over and over again following quests. Its not bad while you have stuff to do on your ship but once your buildings are upgraded and you're stocked with materials it becomes really annoying. There is a fast travel system though...its not perfect but it did help.

VERDICT

With all that negative stuff said..I do love this game. There is zero replayability here but that is kinda the point. Its a game about letting go and once you seen and done everything its time to let go and move on. 
I think a few less minigames and a bit less crafting would help Spiritfarer a lot. It took me a bit over 40 hours to complete it and I feel if it was 30 hours long it would be perfect. Removing fluff and focusing on story more would make this a perfect game. Still..I enjoyed my time spent in this wonderful world and it did make me quite emotional a few times and games that can do that are rare and I always fondly remember them. And I'm really interested in whatever Thunder Lotus has next in store for us.

This is another one of those games where I wish there was a maybe option. It is a genuinely nice experience so far but it's such a slow burn and depending on who you are as a person that can be either a good thing or a bad thing. This game is clearly meant to be an emotional experience as you help characters in the final moments of their lives and lead them towards their end. It's kind of hard to gauge how long you can expect this game to be because I have yet to finish it despite nearly having 25 hours as of writing this but for the longest time the game was telling me I was at 20% around hour 20~22 and then suddenly just jumped 30% after an hour or two of rapid progression because of the way this game is paced. 

There are resources locked behind certain things or upgrades that essentially require you to just play out the game until you can get them and then suddenly gain access to a whole new tier of stuff. This is pretty typical all things considered but it kind of comes off as frustrating in this game since you kinda just twiddle your thumbs once you've done everything in the current tier and are just constantly sailing around while farming resources going from point A to point B, C, D, etc doing your quests. Sometimes you're asked for things you won't get for another hour or two. A great example is Atul who asks for porkchops really early on and despite getting that quest within the first hour of the game I didn't even have access or know where to get them until like 6 hours later. Even then processing resources takes a long time to do. 

My biggest issue with this game by far is the severe lack of quality of life aspects. I feel like the moment I load up my file I immediately remember all the things that sour the experience. Things like being unable to uproot a tree from the orchard so you're forced to dismantle the entire building and then replant the seeds which are relatively expensive/rare and since they produce indefinitely you're not typically going to buy a stock of them since you only need one. Or because of an achievement to collect all the sheep in the game you can't actually get rid of them once they're on your ship despite being worthless the moment you no longer need wool. The constant need to be sailing all over the map that takes so many steps to do anything but at night you lose the ability to sail so you're just dead in the water but if you sleep you miss out on upkeep time but then at the same time doing so means you're just spending minutes that add up to hours just running around watering plants, checking the windmill, cooking food, etc. The night time was clearly intended to force the player to handle these tasks that all pile up but at the same time it would be nice to make some progress towards the next destination while doing so. 

Additionally, boy howdy, the animations of this game are both a blessing and a curse. It's nicely animated and the characters are nice and diverse (specifically the key characters, all the other spirits being the exact same don't really count here) but god do the animations hang on for far too long. People who don't like waiting are bound to be frustrated by how long these animations play out. Caught a fish? Stella will just do one fist pump and hang it there for like 5 seconds before you can fish again, effectively making canceling fishing and starting again miles faster. Watering plants takes 2 or 3 seconds which isn't a lot but it adds up when you've got 3 fields per building and like 4 buildings making that task alone take a minute or so every single time you need to do it which is multiple times a day if you're really keeping up on it. Mining wants you to release the action key as late into the animation as you can but if you go too long the lgiht overloads and stella just sits there shielding her face for like 5 seconds before making a move towards recovering. It's all just agonizingly slow paced and so many things could be sped up to make it less of a pain to deal with. 

It's a beautifully made game but the core gameplay is so slow for no real reason other than to pad your play time and if you don't resonate with the characters then there really isn't much for the experience after that. The game tries to force you to take it slow which can make it very frustrating to play at times when you're just trying to advance the plot. I don't think I'd say its worth 30 usd but maybe if you grab it on a sale it could be something worth giving a try.

Wish I could recommend it, I genuinely had fun with it for a while (my wife and I cooped through the whole game together), but by the half way point we were both trying to finish it as fast as possible. The gameplay is decent, I like the house boat idea, but a game like this hangs on whether the story is good, and this is where it fails.

 The characters bar two are miserable to be around, which is a shame because they are the centrepiece of the game, and you are stuck with them for so long. Most of their storylines end with them randomly doing something grossly out of character and then asking you to take them to the afterlife. The writers also clearly have a deeply nihilistic outlook on life which affects the characters attitudes towards their deaths in a way that blunts potential for thought provoking moments (I think only the character Jackie had something interesting to say when commenting on his imminent death), I also was not a fan of the late game twist, even though I saw it coming from a mile away, since it was the narrative equivalent of "it's all a dream". Also ran into a few bugs, especially in coop ( random disconnected of the second controller that require the game to be quit, second player freezing in place until the first player does something, NPCs getting lost when their AI demanded they be in two places at once). As much as I got some good play time out of the game, I recommend that you save yourself the frustration and play a different game.

To the developers, you have talent, art and gameplay were a solid base, but you need to put your writers on less challenging material, even religion and philosophy struggle to make good commentary on death, it probably wasn't the best topic to tackle if you weren't prepared for it. Also be less verbose, I'm pretty sure I encountered random unimportant NPCs with more dialog than this entire review.

A very flawed gem. 
Spiritfarer is unique in theme and story, it tugs at your hearstrings in a way that many games will never even attempt to. Everything in that regard is special, flawed, far from perfect, but it is certainly an experience that you might need, even if you don't think you do..

But the rest of the game is a grind, a sequence of chores and tedious minigames that you have to repeat ad nauseam. You have one upgrade that doubles the output of any of the... 6-7 different crafting stations, and that's it. No automation, no ability to skip doing the same minigame for the 30000th time. Go here, go there, get this, get this back, make this, make that, repeat another million times. 

It far outstays its welcome, and it is a tragedy because there are clear glimpses of genius here and there. 
But that's what it is - glimpses, and nothing more.

Spiritfarer might be THE game that succeeds in combining all the cozy with all the feelings. It is your chance to feel like you're participating in a big-budget animated blockbuster with the heart of a Studio Ghibli film. The core of this game includes awe-inspiring animations, a management aspect that keeps you busy without stress, a heartfelt story, and you'll ugly cry at least once. Spiritfarer is a thing of beauty, but it comes with a few caveats.

- As Stella (the Spiritfarer) becomes closer with the spirits under her care, having them say the five things repeatedly makes interactions a chore.
- There were many points where I had zero quests in my log and no clue what I was supposed to do next, which sucked before you gained functions that allowed faster travel.
- The fetch quests started to drag as you headed towards the end of the base game.
- I also found that having the DLC content right there made figuring out where the base game ends difficult.

Even with the issues I mentioned, I'd still highly recommend the game as it was a delight to play and exceptional overall. *Disclaimer: I'm not quite finished with the base game. See below*

[b]You might like Spiritfarer if:[/b] You enjoy cozy management games with a heartfelt story.
[b]You might not like Spiritfarer if:[/b] The game contains various (not exceptionally detailed) stories of death/end of life, which might not be for everyone.
[b]My favorite part:[/b] I spent a lot of time just doing the various acrobatics Stella could do because watching the animations brought all sorts of joy.
[b]My least favorite part:[/b] The repetitive NPC dialogue.
[b]Hours played as of review:[/b] 90+ hours
[b]Completed?[/b] No. Hear me out... I'm pretty much at the end game. I need to drop off one last spirit, and I'm not going to. My wife thinks I'm being ridiculous, and she will not sway me to finish the game. My buddy, Stella, and Dandelion will be cruising my save file forever because I learned nothing about death from the game.
[b]100%?[/b] No :P

I really want to like this game, but there are just too many things that irritate me.

The whole game seems like a huge fetch quest. Go here, get this, go there, deliver that. I kinda don't mind, if not because of the things I'm going to mention below.

Every time you travel between islands you have to wait because the ship travels in real time. Even when you use fast travel, you still need to slowly sail some distance. You can't even alt+tab out of the game while traveling, because the whole game will pause. This is so frustrating.

You can do some mini games while sailing, like fishing, cooking, sewing, cutting woods, but just like most mini games, it gets boring after a while, and you have to do those mini games frequently to progress through the story.

The ship passengers get hungry and sad often, so you have to cook for them and hug them to keep them happy. You can't even feed them the same items twice in a row, and everybody has different preferences. This is annoying. They are freeloading on my ship and I still have to spoon-fed them all the time!

I force myself to complete one person's whole quest, and the story seems interesting. However, I just can't stand to keep doing the boring repetitive tasks any longer, and the whole waiting while sailing is such a waste of time. I suppose this slow-paced game is just not for me.

This game absolutely lives up to the hype. I am loving EVERYTHING about it. This is a game where you have goals and tasks, but there is no time limit, and you can explore as much as you want in-between. It is an EXTREMELY chill game, however, there is never a shortage of things to do. There is just no rush to do them. The characters guide you subtly, with tips on what might progress you next. The world, which is set in the ocean, has stationary towns and islands, but also changes, with new shipwrecks to uncover or more creatures to catch. You can choose to progress forward, or grind for items/money (glims) - or a bit of both! The game is fluid, with a path to an ending, but so many options on how to get there. The movements are intuitive, with most actions coming naturally. The music is so soothing, I actually barely notice it's there. And the sound effects are just ON POINT. I have not found it to be glitchy at all, and to top it off, this game is GORGEOUS. I have not enjoyed a game like this in SO LONG. Highly recommend!

Would highly recommend. One of the best games I’ve played to date and one I hold as a solid comparison for most other “cosy” games I play.

This is a very cute and fun game with emotional elements that keep the story interesting. Charon, the ferryman who delivers souls to the afterlife, has passed his job on to you, Stella, so that he can finally pass on into the afterlife. You sail your boat across the seas of the spirit realm with your cat, Daffodil, visiting islands, gathering supplies, and finding souls who are nearly ready to pass on. You take care of each soul while completing tasks for them and hearing their stories until they are finally ready to move on. This is so fun. You have to keep your boat moving so that you can complete tasks at a decent pace because some islands are farther to get to. You can fish, cook, grow crops, care for sheep, and make all kinds of materials for adding on to your boat. It's not super grindy as far as getting enough supplies to add on to your boat which is nice. I would recommend this for anyone wanting a casual, relaxing game.

It's quite genuinely one of the most, if not the most, emotional experience I've had playing a game. The absolute comfort I felt allowed me to indulge in my feelings and face my emotions around life events, and for the game to put it into such a beautiful cohesive perspective was something I really needed. All characters are genuine and feel very real, their stories are all relatable in some way and you can't help but love them all, regardless of how flawed they may be.

The music stands out as being at the very top of any game soundtrack I've heard before, still listening to it at least weekly ever since I've finished playing, alongside Gris, Transistor, Chicory and Mutazione. I would recommend the game for that alone. Makes me absolutely bawl every time and I can't help but being grateful for it.

This is an experience best enjoyed when you're in the right mindset for it, but if you are, allow yourself to be overtaken by it, that will make it that much more powerful and enjoyable.

[b]My Score:[/b] 9/10

[h1]Prologue[/h1]
In a world covered by a vast ocean, people come together to build their cities on islands, thus making all types and sizes of boats become something vital and part of the culture of this world. They are so important that even the ferryman of souls, the legendary Charon, has his own boat for when he goes to fetch the souls of those who are close to the day of they departure from this world, but even the legendary ferryman gets tired after eons of doing this service, and now wants to make the passage to rest. ^^

Not before choosing not one, but two successors to his position as a boatman, these two are the young girl Stella and her cat Daffodil, who one fine day wake up on an isolated island in front of the old boatman, who names them the next ones, to assume the title that belonged to Charon. Now in possession of the new title and a somewhat old boat, but nothing a few repairs won't fix, our duo must navigate the islands, learning about their new role and gathering resources, as they search for the souls of those close to their final rest, and so together with the player, help them to resolve any pending issues in this world, before crossing into the afterlife. ^^

[b]Pros:[/b]
+ Beautiful arts of the characters and scenarios, along with several very well done animations, both for moments in the story and in the various activities that we can do during the adventure.
+ So relaxing soundtrack that perfectly matches the various moments and locations of the game, combined with sound effects that make this world even more vivid.
+ In my opinion, the game is very fun, with several activities to do, charismatic and unique characters to meet, several improvements to the boat that can be customized and a different and interesting story.
+ So much to explore and discover, there's always something new to explore, whether it's an undiscovered fish to catch, what resources a new island might have. Just the cooking part, for example, has a repertoire of over a hundred recipes just combining ingredients.

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Many resources have a mini game to collect or refine, some of them even increasing the amount produced when done perfectly. I found these mini games fun, but for those who don't like it, it may not be very satisfying.

[h1] Game mechanics[/h1]
A young girl and her cat, in a pose of great powers and a boat in need of some attention, this is how our protagonists' adventure begins, sailing through the islands in search of people who are not far from their great rest, when these When people are met, they reveal the true form of their spirit and move to the boat, where they travel seeking to resolve any pending issues from the past, be they places, objects or memories, in order to achieve peace and be ready for the next stage. ^^

But it's up to our young boatwoman to decide the route of this trip, after all, even though it's close to leaving for the afterlife, the boat's passengers still need food every day and each of the passengers has their own list of things they like and do not like, thus making it necessary to plant and what is not possible to collect to produce delicacies that please them. Another point is comfort, as passengers like to have their own rooms that resemble their old homes and to produce them, resources are needed. The more things passengers like are done, the happier they are, and the greater their happiness, the more they help on the boat. ^^

[h1] Art and sound[/h1]
Produced by the Thunder Lotus Games studio, all I can say is that I am shocked by the incredible quality of the arts and animations, all very well made and very beautiful, at various times I was really distracted just watching the arts, or just stopped watching the character animations. Something enhanced by the incredibly relaxing soundtrack, I found it very pleasant to listen to while exploring and discovering more of the story, always positively punctuated by good sound effects from the environment or the various activities that we can do. ^^

[h1] Conclusion[/h1]
Spiritfarer caught my attention the first time I saw it as it seemed to be a different adventure game, and I was really happy when I saw that it was that and much more. With a vast and unique world to explore, lots of things to find, discover and make, a colorful and very interesting cast of characters both those who become passengers and others, a different and very interesting story, complete with an amazing art and soundtrack that I will definitely remember for a long time. All this makes this game that I highly recommend for everyone who likes a good story, with a vast and beautiful world to explore. ^^

This is a tricky game to review because it ultimately greatly frustrated me, yet also deeply gripped me and made me love it. So ... 

The good part: it's an amazing game as far as characters and sheer beauty. I have never had a game make me literally sob out loud, but the characters really touch you and it is so hard to let them go. The artwork, particularly the sunrise and sunset art on the ship, is just stunning. Many of the minigames are fun, and the crafting is amusing, works well, and leads to a funky, surreal-looking village-ship. 

The bad part: for me, I hated the platforming mechanics and the sudden ramp-up in difficulty for some of the later quests. I didn't finish the game because there is literally nothing I will ever enjoy about trying to make the same jump 357 times because it requires intense concentration and precision, only to fail at the next leap and have to start all over. I loved the people and characters but in the end I hated the game play. If you like platformers (and if you do, please seek help), you may enjoy it more - but honestly, I'm still glad that I bought and played the game. Maybe some day, when I am feeling very patient, I will dust it off again.

Some quests are meant to take longer than others, and if you just happen to leave those quests for later, or approach certain areas in an unintended order, as I did, you may encounter long periods of waiting for things to happen. Also an essential NPC [spoiler]Stanley[/spoiler] is an RNG encounter you really need to know about to look out for.

I'm writing this review while still in-game because I must idle for hours and have nothing else to do.

This game is like 50% crafting, 40% waiting (slow animations, super slow ship, fast travel just sucks, NPCs ask to come tomorrow), 9% primitive and uninspiring exploration, and 1% crying that you're here for. The problem is that the game is wayyyy too long for its own good as everything gets beyond tedious and basically broken in late-game.

Spiritfarer is amazing in the first 1/3 of your progress:
+ Tons of things to do
+ Lots of places to be
+ Everything is exciting
+ You can chill out and really take it in
+ Incredibly likeable characters
+ You love taking care of them
+ You cry like a biтсh when they go

Then flash-forward ANOTHER THIRTY HOURS or so:
- Characters include a pathologic cheater, a violent criminal, and other unlikeable people
- I dump them at the Everdoor in bulk to save me a trip, I don't care anymore
- Every single thing has been crafted in excessive amounts
- You've been to every location at least several times over
- THERE IS NOTHING ELSE TO DO YOU JUST IDLE
- Quests are literally "wait 2 in-game days to be able to progress, 6 times over"
- There is no time skip and one in-game day takes 30-40 real-time minutes or so
- Every late-game quest is "go to three distant locations all over the map"
- The ship is very, very slow at max upgrade and fast travel is still crap
- There is nothing left to craft anymore
- "Run in background" option does not actually work (game pauses on focus loss anyway)
- Meditation to skip time has been cut from the game
- IT'S SO BORING I CAN'T DO THIS ANYMORE
- RELEASE ME TO THE EVERDOOR

I just wish was the game was shorter. Like half as long. Or less. It starts nice but to actually finish the game (let alone 100% it) it's so incredibly tedious and boring. At least 20 real-life hours sunk into it feel like a complete waste of time. And another 20 spent on just crafting things - which isn't bad, but I'd do with ~5.

EDIT: any% speedrun of this game is clocked at 5 hours. A speedrun. Of any%. Five hours. Christ. My 100% run took 45 hours - and I've used guides and cheatsheets extensively.

(For example, you can climb to Susan and the CEO as soon as you have Double Jump, but I couldn't quite get it to work so I was convinced I was doing something wrong. But you also can't really progress without talking to them, so I spent a lot of time faffing around trying to figure out what I was missing. Maybe if you have more platformer experience this won't be an issue? I don't know how much of this "issue" was me/my keyboard.)

Overall, I'm enjoying this game. The artwork and stories are beautiful and interesting. I do find the Everdoor (gate?) super slow but I realise that's kind of the point: to slow down and take a moment to appreciate each spirit as they leave the world. I still want to hash all the keys to make it HURRY UP and get it over with, though, despite enjoying slow games. I just hate sitting there not being able to do anything; you aren't even rowing, you're literally sitting there doing nothing as the scenery passes you by for what seems like hours.

So I guess there are more things about this game that frustrate me than I realised, but I would still definitely recommend it!

Genuinely incredible and definitely worth my time and money, and almost certainly worth yours.

That said, I'm late to the party on this one, but it's a game well worth playing.

I absolutely love this game, and highly recommend it if you're still grieving. It's just as it says: a cozy management game about dying. You meet spirits, get to know them, fulfill all of their requests, and at the end you bring them to the Everdoor. Tears are optional, but for me, many have been shed. It's also a platformer, and you get to do lots of things with the facilities you build on your boat. And your spirits will have their own little homes which are perfectly decorated to suit their individual personalities.

It's a game that reminded me that yes, I have feelings, and yes, everyone dies, but even if you know it's your job, there's nothing you can do to prepare yourself beforehand.
