I bought Spiritfarer on its launch week, after 18 hours I gave up. Life happened and the game has a big grinding problem. I returned to it due to life circumstances being aligned with the theme of the game.

Spiritfarer is a great game. It is able to do things that other games failed doing so. More than once I can feel the developers exploring themes and with anecdotes exploring real people with real lifes. I feel like I knew people that would fit most characters in this game, and the game gives you the opportunity of seeing sides of said people that you can only imagine or speculate in real life. It may sound weird, but more than once the game fit things I've went through. This may as well be a me thing, but I cannot omit this from my view of this piece.

About gameplay, the game has a huge problem with pacing and grinding, something that it does hit it really badly. The amount of items needed for most things is insane, the upgrades to alleviate this problem comes way too late in the game and you'll find yourself going back to the same places for things that are meaningless. Even though the cooking system is great and there's beautiful art for it, it feels under used. Once you discover one or two dishes that someone may like you rarely is encouraged to explore unless for your own curiosity in seeing said beautiful art. Most of the things you have to do end up feeling like chores, and there's mechanics that makes the most active tasks useless. The animations are beautiful but because you have to grind the same thing a lot of times you'll get sick of some of them, like puling vegetables out of the ground, cutting trees or Smithy, the worst minigame.
Everything else feels good, didn't get any bugs or problems with the game.

The art is impeccable, you will not find a game like this one out there. Spiritfarer is unique in its style, animation and polish, everything fits together really nicely, it's a world you'll find yourself noticing small details, stuff that you get impressed they put in there, that's how much the team cared. From characters, to scenario, to VFX, SFX, UI, writing, everything art/asset related is perfect. I've found myself always being surprised by that.

The game shines in all parts, it pains me to give a harsh critic on gameplay but that is necessary, if that was streamlined or had a mode that cut the necessary cost for most things in half this game would be A LOT better.

I will not spoil anything, I just want to say that if you dealt with loss in any shape or form in your life, this game is something that you may find comfort in. It's very tender, warm and sober. I'll refrain from talking about it given it's the real diamond in this project.

I do recommend Spiritfarer, I would say it is a must buy and play if it was shorter, more streamlined, less grindy, still I think it's one of the best experiences I've ever had with a game. It's weird to say, but I feel the hug mechanic isn't just for the characters, I feel like the intention of the developers behind this was to hug whoever could relate to the themes in here. I'm thankful for this, I'm happy a game like this exist. I'm grateful.

Thank you Thunder Lotus Games.

SPOILER ALERT: The following is more of me venting, and less of a review. So, TL:DR: If you are the patient, introspective kind of people, or maybe if you're dealing with loss and grief yourself, BUY THIS GAME, it is fantastic. Enough said.

So, as my personal experience with this little gem...

This game really got to me. I got it a while ago, I don't remember when, but I played a little of it, got kinda bored, moved on. It sat on my library for a while, until a couple weeks ago I decided to give it another shot on a whim. And the experience has been unique. I'm still processing what just happened, and it has just dawned on me how different of a person I was when I played it the first time to now. So, story time.

Two years ago, my grandmother passed away, but it was miserable. She got really sick, and I helped my mother take care of her on her last months. She couldn't even talk. Brain tumor. And it came out of nowhere: One day she was fine, the next we had to carry her on a wheelchair to her bed. I'm pretty old (27 right now) but that was my first experience facing death so directly, and it left a pretty big impact on me.

Now, this year my father is sick. He's quite and older gentleman (81) and his kidneys don't work anymore. Since December of last year, I have been helping take care of him. I take him to the hospital, I give him his medication and treatment, I change his diapers. I'm no nurse, but this year I spent so much time inside the hospital that I learned a lot about how people deal with grief. And I had to face some pretty dark moments, all by myself, since I am also pretty unwell and have been for a long time now.

So, me being in this headspace, dealing with my own inner demons and trying desperately not to crumble to pieces, I decided to play this game. And it broke me, multiple times. I saw people I know in the characters, I saw parts of myself too. One character in particular, a pretty unlikable hyena, struck me the most. From his struggles to what he says towards the end, I saw myself. And it hurt real bad. As I said, I'm still processing what I just experienced, and I'm not sure if I'll do a good job at that. But that is one of the most important, hopeful and heartbreaking lessons of this game: How we deal with the pain is entirely up to us. We can't control death, but we can control how we react to it. And that thought can be really uplifting to some, and terrifying to others. I know, because I've been so close to death lately, and I've felt both ways.

A game, or any piece of art really, that can move someone so deeply, and can provoke such intense emotions and thoughts, deserves to be experienced. You deserve to play this game, if only to appreciate the beauty of the animations and the music. And hopefully, after you play it, you'll think a little about yourself and the people around you, and realize that we all are going to die someday. And that's OK.

Spiritfarer is a slow paced simple adventure platform game with very easy game play where you help get people (animals) on your boat and fulfill their last requests before dying. You can collect things through cooking recipes, gathering, fishing etc, play minigames to gather materials, create items and buildings, and go to shrines to improve your abilities. As you fulfill the requests you learn more about the animals backstory and why they're saying goodbye. This is what the game revolves around, learning their stories (through bad monologues unfortunately). In the end you learn about your own. A lot stays unexplained though and for some of the characters it makes no sense why they're included in the game, even after spending so much time on them.

This game really takes a couple of hours to get good. In the beginning I thought it was going to suck and I wasted my money, but stick with it. The dialogue unfortunately doesn't improve and stays absolutely horrible and cringy with all the swearing for no reason and very forced cringy 'wisdom' the characters are constantly spouting. Especially at the everdoor. It's so bad and really drawn out too, you can't skip those monologues. There were maybe 3 characters in the game with believable, passable dialogue. I wonder if they had an actual writing team or if a guy by himself who got carried away. 

I also don't understand a lot of the character choices, there weren't many main characters so why were 2 of them so similar (bird & porcupine)? Others were just extremely unlikable and it made no sense why they were in the game. I still don't know how the main character related to the bull & hummingbird. As a whole the characters didn't seem a coherent bunch if you put them together and it made it the whole game feel a lot more sloppy than it could have been. It's a story based game.. Make sure the characters and their monologues are good and the story makes sense..

I also thought it was a real shame they didn't give a realistic interaction after finding out certain things after big, drawn out quests (the lion and the lynx). The end to those felt hollow and rushed combined with the annoying monologues and the long build up. Some characters were well done though. Like the two with progressing dementia. That was believable and actually sad. You felt for them. I wish they kept it going at that level instead of taking you 'out' of the story with the poorly done stuff. The owl was super cliche and cringy as well. Why wasn't he incorporated in the ending (again after the big build up, multiple achievements) in some way instead of that long ass song you couldn't skip? 

BUT it is a fun game to pass the time with if you have nothing else, I'd give it a 6,5/10 and it's worth about 30-40 hrs of gameplay. It is a weird combo of the top notch cutesy visuals and very wholesome elements like the hugs and the cooking etc, with cringy/edgy dialogue to suffer through. And the plot holes and rushed goodbyes after collecting tons of carrots and peaches for nothing for example. What was the point?  

The decor saves the game by being really varied and nice as you travel around (but why is the cow in a completely different art style LOL) and it's a very easy game to get through, you just kind of gather what you need along the way to level up your boat. So there is little grinding for materials or any hard puzzles or quests. The focus is on the story. But I personally didn't like the characters and the underwhelming story that much. The artwork, gameplay and easy navigating on the boat saved it for the most part.
What a fun, relaxing jaunt! 10/10 will play again

This is a game about closure. For the spirits, and for us--Stella. Its about moving on and letting go and how sometimes you really never DO get that closure you need. Everyone is different, has different pasts and worries and troubles, and that leaves different wounds. Wounds that heal, and wounds that don't.

It's not an easy game, emotionally. Death never is, and this game is mature in its handling of it--its not always fair, its never without sadness, and it leaves an empty ache.

My previous complaint was in how--real or not the game was, but in a way, I don't think it matters. Whether this is Stella getting closure on her deathbed or some world Charon made for one like us to help those we knew--and ourselves--move on, is I think besides the point. Everyone in the game finds closure, in some way. Even the Spirtfarer. And while this game hits hard--VERY hard in some cases--it really deals with death on a masterful, heartrending level. 

Just ready the tissues.

I don't know. This game is kind of fun at first, but it becomes extremely tedious really fast.

It's an interesting blend between a farming simulator and metroidvania. Game about death that is somehow ridiculously cheerful. A game about building houses and growing trees on a boat filled with furries. Yeah, this is an extremely weird game.

So you take place of Charon to ferry spirits to the afterlife. But before they leave, you need to build them a house on your boat. Catch fish, grow crops and cook to feed them. Talk to them. Hug them. Do weird quests. It takes ages. In the meantime, you explore the world, water you crops, visit cities and ports and mines, water your crops, upgrade you ship, water your crops, gather resources, sheer the sheep and water your crops, learn to construct new buildings so you can process resources into different resources, water your crops... basically the game becomes a chore very very fast.

Eventually you also learn new abilities like double jump or gliding that allows you to explore further, gather new resources, upgrade your ship so it can pass through ice and rocks and whatnot so you can gather more resources... At the end, you're just doing the same thing over and over and over again.

I managed to get rid of 3 spirits and I had enough of the game. The characters you meet are mostly just annoying, self-centered or outright obnoxious. And they always want something. I tried to push on, tried to finish it but after several hours of gameplay, I only got to 35% and I don't see myself continuing further. The game has absolutely nothing new to offer at that point and is outright boring.

On the positive note, the graphics are really nice and cute. Great relaxing music as well. It has some funny moments. And it has this super relaxing feel.

But it isn't really relaxing itself as you have to constantly water plants, cook, feed spirits, catch fish, plant vegetables, smelt ores, make wooden planks and fabric, there's just too much of the same thing over and over again and almost every activity is a minigame that takes way too long. There is no time limit or anything, you can't overcook a food, plants won't die and spirits won't starve to death (they're already dead) but I had this constant feeling of having boring work to do.

So at the end I don't really know what review to give it. It's really not a bad game but it's fun for only a limited amount of time. And it's practically impossible to finish if you value your time.

I would say give it a try but probably wait for a sale because you, like me, may not get the full value out of the story.

If I could give a neutral rating, this would be the game for it. But between "yes or no", it seemed unfair to go with a negative. If this game is in the sale, I can recommend giving it a go and supporting smaller developers, but otherwise maybe try reading some of the negative reviews as a lot of them have fair points to give. Perhaps my biggest issue is I went into this game expecting a character driven story, and instead got grindy fetch quests and resource gathering for 25+ hours, so my expectations weren't met.

[b]The positives:[/b]
The art is beautiful, and I absolutely adore a lot of the character designs.

Music is great.

Not created by a large AAA company so hopefully your money will be lining the pockets of people who actually deserve it.

[b]The negatives:[/b]
Long animations that start to get old when repeatedly seeing them - while I understand this game is about taking time to appreciate the environment around you, it leans so heavily into forcing you to do the same tasks over and over that eventually I reached a point where I was desperately hammering the same button just to try and skip frames on animations. The tree cutting is especially egregious, more so when your cat companion has decided to get stuck somewhere so you're stuck waiting for the game to reset its position. 

Tedious mini games - Virtually every single item you need to collect and make has some sort of mini game attached to it, and they got old very quickly for me, not helped by the fact that many of them are the same task (aka jumping around on platforms to stand on or under a thing). Jellyfish event? Jump on platforms and collect jellyfish coming horizontally across the screen for several minutes. Thunderstorm? Jump on platforms and collect lightning coming vertically across the screen for several minutes. Meteor shower? Jump on platforms and collect meteors coming horizontally AND vertically across the screen for several minutes. And so on. If you need something, you HAVE to go through the same motions over and over again, and if you don't enjoy one of them or aren't very good at it, you're shit out of luck, you'll HAVE to do them for any sort of progress.

The entire game revolves around fetch quests - For most your time you'll just be jumping from island to island (or event to event) collecting resources and filling a request on of your passengers has. The trouble being even when it's a passenger request, there's rarely much they want you to actually do beyond just... taking them somewhere or getting them something, and often have you bouncing back and forth between the same two places. There's very little meaning behind most of what you do, and the travel time in early game makes it slow going.

Resource and inventory management is non existent - There were plenty of times where I reached a point in a game where I needed one specific resource to continue (both for room upgrades and boat upgrades) but it wasn't fully made clear WHERE to get said resource. On top of that, the inventory is slow to navigate and has no filters. For instance, you can make up to 105 different recipes, each character only loves one specific dish. If you want to give them their favourite dish, the only thing you can do is scroll through a 100 tiny thumbnails of dishes, hoping you can remember roughly what that item looked like or where it was in the rows, otherwise you just have to go through the list one by one looking for it. If a character likes comfort food, you can't just highlight all comfort food in your inv, you have to scroll over each item and read its tag. There's also no bulk select abilities, so if you want to weave 50 cloth, or sell 100 fruit, you just gotta start button mashing.

I just couldn't get attached to any of the characters and the gameplay makes it even harder to do so - I'll just go ahead and say it.... while I love the designs of the characters, I found most of them obnoxious or just completely uninteresting. The game is so focused on everything being gathering or fetch quests, that it seems to leave character development on the sidelines much of the time. Most characters will only have a few lines of dialogue occasionally, and the rest of the time they're nagging you for food CONSTANTLY when the kitchen is right there, or just drifting around doing nothing. They never have anything to say about any other character on the boat, and don't interact with each other either. Usually you're only required to do a few quests for them, and then out of nowhere they're just like "well time to die" and ask to leave. 
You can just do their quests immediately as they come and never get a chance to really know them, and even if you want to get to know them, they have nothing to say. This is made worse imo by the fact your character supposedly knows them all already, so having someone show up going "hi, i'm your best friend" is jarring for the player, and seems like the game is relying on you to have attachment solely because they told you to.
I've seen a fair few reviews saying this game made them cry, but I just felt absolutely nothing when seeing off most these characters. Or worse, at times I was bored and desperate to get rid of them, which is weird because I cry at basically every movie and TV show ever. Heck, I even sobbed when Terminator went into the magma. 
Most the characters have absolutely no sort of closure or purpose to their quests/storylines, and quite a few storylines are similar tonally that it feels like you're repeating yourself (both old characters have memory problems and that is their entire arc, for instance, which feels terrible when taking them to their 'end' without their consent.) 
To add insult to injury, the only character I did kinda like and wanted to take to the Everdoor ended up just vanishing and no one seemed to have anything to say about it or gave a shit. 
I was expecting the Everdoor to be more like The Good Place where characters find closure or you help them come to terms with their existence, but instead nothing ever seemed to change or matter, and the problems they have at the start remain at the end. (Maybe that's a commentary the game was trying to make, but as a player it felt unsatisfying, and I've seen it done better in other media).

No replayability - Despite the fact this game has several achievements that you could only get by playing twice (aka an achievement for saying yes to a piece of dialogue, but a different one for saying no), there just doesn't seem to be a reason to replay this game, especially when it's essentially just grinding resources.

Overall I thought this game could have benefited a lot from being about half the length it is, and focusing much more heavily on character interactions (both with player and between each other). If much of the resource grinding and mini games were stripped out, and there was more time to really get to know and understand the characters, I think it would be a much improved game, and I say this as someone who usually isn't a fan of dialogue heavy games. But still I respect the developers for creating something that they wanted, and I guess this game got me thinking, even if for all the wrong reasons.

I actually already owned Spiritfarer for Nintendo Switch, but I decided to pick up the Steam version when it was on sale because I love it that much. On the surface, it's a cute little game where you wander the world helping spirits get to the afterlife... But it's so much more than that. There is a beautiful story, poignant story that gradually unfolds as you play. The characters are well-written, and it is so easy to grow attached to the spirits who board your boat.

My first time playing through Spiritfarer (on the switch) was in fall of 2021, and I found it so therapeutic, especially after losing my grandfather in early 2021. Playing through it again, it is still holding up amazingly well, and it still evokes so much emotion from me. (Also, the soundtrack is gorgeous!)

I think this game had promise. I tried the demo a few years back during some game-jam type event. It has great art style and fluid animation/controls. The premise of deciding when to let your friends pass on into the other world is a really cool concept that attaches some player emotion to the final decision.

The problem was for me that I didn't find myself attaching to the characters strongly enough to care about the final send-off. Their stories were unique and sad, but I wasn't gripped in the way I think was intended. There was also some mystery behind the main character, teased after the first spirit sendoff, but that plot-line didn't continue after the next 7-8 hours of play and next 2-3 spirits sent off, so I lost interest.

Without that connection, the game becomes more of your generic farming simulator/resource collection grind. I did not complete the game, I got the 2nd major upgrade for your ship that allows you to explore the next part of the map (rock-breaker). At that point I decided I did not want to continue.

I'm lukewarm on games like Stardew Valley, which probably makes sense for why I didn't connect with this game. I might come back to this game on occasion when the time hits, but it isn't a game I felt investing too heavily in. This isn't a bad game, but it isn't a great game that I'd actively recommend to other people.

I don't think this game is strong enough to recommend universally to all players, but if you enjoy slower paced resource collection games with a bit of heart, this would be worth picking up on sale.

This game is so phenomenal that I bought it twice. 

When I first bought the game on my Switch, I literally played it for 8 hours straight. I was sick at the time (just 4 days ago) and wanted something to do while I was in bed; this game is everything and I was legitimately surprised by how instantly enamored I was with its gameplay. I am almost 60% through it (with over 50 hours) and it hasn't gotten dull or boring one bit. Along with the respective challenges to which each spirit introduces you- one can't help but be overcome with nostalgia and a sense of sadness once they've left your side and "it" pops up while you're traveling. This game is a work of art- literally and figuratively. The artwork is absolutely lovely, and the story lines, along with the quests (and other things), keep your attention. The care and creativity that went into this project is more than apparent; I never want to put it down. I am unable to physically become tired while playing this game because of how engaging it is. 

I've noticed that Thunder Lotus Games uses darker skin protagonists. Being made of black girl magic myself, I love the idea of the protagonist being a woman of color. I feel as if there are many games out there in which we are misrepresented or just outright omitted. The inclusion is totally refreshing.

But let me say that I made the conscious decision to buy the Deluxe Edition on Steam for the sole purpose of supporting this project. Aside from it being a great game, I just truly want to show my love and appreciation for this and fund the next creation. I will definitely be playing Spiritfarer on Steam alongside the progress on my Switch- playing it from the beginning again and knowing what I know now will still be loads of fun; I can even do certain things (not going to spoil anything) to see what incentives can come from certain actions. Anyway, I just want to say:

Thank you ! <3

P.S.
If you're thinking about getting this game- don't think. Just buy.

The game is good, and I recommend it. Graphics are very nice, music creates atmosphere, characters look original, and have cute individual animations of different emotions, exploring the world is fun (except for mines, they look the same and dark and depressing), trying to determine everyone's favourite dish is a blast. However here are the problems I noticed while playing:

- It says it has local coop, but you can't both play on one keyboard, one of you needs a controller. Shame since controls are just 6 buttons, could have easily fit both players on a single keyboard.

- Too dark most of the time: night and evening, down in the mines, meteor showers, thunderclouds, dragons etc. It's more than half of playtime. It looks logical and nice, but it just strains the eyes too much to have to do some chores or try to build/edit houses in this darkness. Would be nice to have a setting for this in graphics section.

- Could use a map. To see where you are you have to go to the engine room and try to choose a new destination - only then you will see your current location. And if it's night you won't, because it says "too dark to navigate". Yeah, but I just want to see the map. And if you are on land you can't see where you are at all.

- Would be nice to see which buildings are already fully improved, and which are not.

- Doors and creatures in one spot - and there is only one button to enter/speak. For example sheep who eats vegetables from the garden when you don't feed it, lies near the door and it is extremely hard to catch a moment to interact with the door (to get out) and not the sheep.

- They talk TOO much in one go. 10 dialogs to read - ok. 20 - I'm not having fun anymore. Even more - I skip without reading. It is supposed to be an important part of the game, but I skip every time there is too much dialogs in a row. A shame there is no "skip the entire conversation" button. Next thing I'm going to say is even more subjective to me personally, but here it goes: the dialog is not that interesting to be this long. It's mostly pieces of their pretty simple life stories: recalling people and places I have no idea about, complaining about their life partners, asking/thanking for food in too many phrases which are always the same, and saying "..." A LOT - and none of it is too creative or immersive to actually enjoy reading it like literature, or funny to keep reading just for lols.

Mild Spoilers:
[spoiler] - I'm 55 hours into the game, wrapping it up - and I just got what safe travel mode means. I think that one could be explained better - safe from what. Or I am just slow, which is possible.

- Too many XP potions are needed to build everything. And XP potions event is too hard to trigger - only once a day (why?), only sometime in the evening (why again?), and only when you manage to actually click on the table while Buck himself lies behind the table. If I needed like 10 of them - rare triggering is fine. But I need like 50 for all the updates and one events gives out only about 5. Just too much grind compared to other resources types. It also says Buck should give them to me if he is super happy. He doesn't. He gives out popcorn.
[/spoiler] 

Bigger spoilers:
[spoiler] - I am not doing a second play-through for one achievement (about Giovanni). You can not do anything else in the game differently, so why make people play again? It's better to either be able to collect all the achievements on one go, or to have only like half of them doable first time, which means adding more choices thus adding some replayability - so people have more motivation for a second play-through. 

- Not being able to satisfy Elena without someone playing music for her to hear is honestly just a bad decision. No hugging ok. No decorations - fine. But then let her be more happy about the food or something...

- Stanley buggily locking himself in for too long, though all of his requests are done, not allowing to collect bottled ectoplasm is too much. Got completely stuck without the ectoplasm for a long while, not even knowing it was him who had it in his room, I thought it was gonna be on the map like the rest of them, so I decided I was missing someone. Then I gave up and looked it up, and it was buggy Stanley all along. I traveled, slept, waited, reloaded for like 2 game weeks before his Mushroom Majesty finally deigned to open the door. I might return to get the last achievement later, or I'll just hack and get it that way, but for all intents and purposes, I've 100%-ed the game. Fifty-six hours of this shit, goodness gracious. Spiritfarer is easily the most overrated game I've played in my life. 

The game is very beautiful. Not gorgeous. But very beautiful. Bit too plain to reach "gorgeous." The music is great. Not wonderful. But great. Bit too samey and exploitative to reach "wonderful." Now, the premise... The premise is awesome. Really is. The idea of an almost pathologically altruistic palliative nurse on her deathbed hallucinating taking over Charon's duties to take her family, friends and patients that she saw off this mortal plain further into the afterlife is brilliant!

Unfortunately, almost every good thing in Spiritfarer is ruined by the game DRAMATICALLY overstaying its welcome or its overall bloatedness. The rest is ruined by clueless game design. Sorry.

I saw a review that simply said "galley slave simulator." This phrase perfectly sums up 90% of the game process. Every single task relating to resource production is done manually, repeatedly, one by one, always. You will watch the plant watering animation hundreds of times. Literally. Same for harvesting, taking cooked food out of the oven, shearing sheep, smelting metal ingots, waking up and several others. None of those are skippable. They all have a secondish-long delay at the end with you just standing there.

Several of the production buildings, namely the Cellar, the Chicken Coop, the Cow Stall, the Crusher and the Smithy, might as well have not existed. You will unlock the cellar at about 60% completion, use it twice to make five or six dishes (it has three slots) for the collection and never use it again. Same with the rest. Wait, my bad, the Smithy is good for 40-50 uses, and it allows you to enjoy the animation of Stella hammering a glowing blob of material into a sheet about 10-15 times per item. The minigame is literally to hold and release the mouse button repeatedly. Gameplay! Fishing… is bloated, boring and terrible, and might as well have not existed either. Thank god Astrid does most of the fishing for you!

This game makes me feel like I'm working at a call center most of the time. I know this game will make many cry but not me. I'm totally used to these artsy indie games trying to pull at your heart strings, But damn it I'm The boatman. and the boatman only cares about one thing. And that is my work ethic. My boss Hades gave me a job, and I'm getting that job done! 

I'm glad to see them go. It's my job to get these spirits where they are going to, and they can't take it with them, and neither can I. So I just go through the motions as a boatman. I don't develop an attachment to my customers. Don't come crying to me about how you don't want to take the plunge into the afterlife. I've heard it all before. Don't give me your sob story, and go already.

I have errands that need running and Daylight is burning. If spending hours baking cookies, and building you a fancy new shack on my boat is what it takes to get you to no longer be my problem, then so be it!

I just put up a facade that I actually care about their problems. But the fact is all I care about is Those sweet coins they were buried with. No coin? better learn how to swim! It's just like any job, and this is how the sausage is made.

The Music is ambient stuff. nothing memorable. The story is blah, but genuinely nice in some areas. The gameplay reminds me of mobile pet city builders, but without all the predatory microtransactions. However the bones of such a game is there. 

There is lots of hurry up and wait gameplay mechanics, which is definitely a quality you see in all those countless thousands of farmville clones still being made to this day. Waiting for crops to grow. Waiting for your boat to reach another area. Waiting to cook food. All signatures of a game that was designed to make you spend your money. Strangely building new buildings on your boat is instantaneous. It's almost like they wanted to make this yet another mobile game where you pay for crystals to make your tasks go faster, but scrapped that and turned it into an actual video game late in its development cycle. and I have to say that it's better for it. Cause those games suck, and are a symbol of the decline of human decency.

For everyone else-
After finishing the game and exploring it as much as I could, I can't recommend it and genuinely don't get how this game has gotten so much praise outside obvious emotionality surrounding its themes. It starts off strong narratively, but that initial energy only carries the game so far before dropping you squarely in Fetch Quest: The Game. It's a pitfall I hoped wouldn't plague the bulk of the narrative, but outside a few segments of platforming and base building that exist really just to service the many, many fetch quests, this game doesn't have much else going for it outside pleasant visuals.

Of all the characters you meet in Spiritfarer, only one really managed to feel organic, alive, and connected to the game's core narrative, and you pass them by early on. Nearly all the others felt largely tacked on with story arches contrived in a ways that either made it seem like you could almost see the writers reaching for your heart strings or whoever was in charge didn't consider the overall flow. Many had me going, "Neat. Couldn't care less about your backstory," and others felt kinda like the devs intended the game to be played in a specific way and failed to consider how flat things fall when the player deviated from that flow.

Perhaps this game would've done better with voice acting. Hard to say though. Apart from the writers realizing less is more with only one child-like character, voice acting may likely have revealed how flowery to woody to long-winded the dialogue can get - especially with a couple characters towards the end of the game. The over-reliance on mechanics that halted all progress until you figure out where to get a single item from a single location/activity/character for a single upgrade was also a massive misstep. This comes to a head especially with one that requires a chance interaction using a specific activity that's (was for me at least) largely pointless by that point in the game. 

All in all, it was a nice game, but certainly could've used more mechanical revision (like the irritatingly long wait animation after overcharging the pick axe) and narrative polish.

I also have misgivings on Jackie's and a related character's story arch as someone with experience on both sides of the proverbial couch, but this review is long enough. If there's a sequel, there's certainly a lot that could be done with what's here though. Here's to hoping they capitalize on the potential.

I really, really enjoyed the story of this game, however, I felt that it was really getting buried behind the collect-a-thon gameplay. I have seen a lot of people saying they cried while playing this game and formed strong attachments to characters. That didn't happen to me and I have teared up at video games before. I think the primary problem is that the game wants you to become attached to the spirits  on your boat but your primary mode of interaction is doing chores for them and collecting items to improve their houses. You spend a lot more time sailing around collecting resources than you do actually talking to them or befriending them.

I also think a huge amount of the story is not readily apparent enough to keep my interest. i am getting a ton of character backstory from  the Wiki which cites the art book. Maybe it's all laid bare at the end of the game but when I am 14 hours in and having to have the gaps of characters' lives and backstories filled in by the Wiki that makes it even harder to care about these characters. I think more of my time is spent trying to decipher how they died or why they know Stella than it is getting to know them.

In short, the story is cool, but I finally got so tired of sailing from island to island to collect resources and play the same tiresome minigames over and over that I am taking a break. I might finish it, I might not, but it's just exhausting and not fun. For instance, the part I'm at requires you to upgrade a character's house which involves metal sheets.

Step 1: Go to the blueprint table to figure out what you need.
Step 2: Make ingots by playing the foundry minigame. If you don't have the ores, sail to collect them. If you forget what you need go back to the blueprint table.
Step 3: Get powder by playing the crusher minigame which is literally just mashing e. If you don't have the rocks you have to sail to pick them up. If you forget what you need go back to the blueprint table.
Step 4: Forge the sheets by mashing E in the foundry minigame. Go back to the blueprint table and realize you are missing something else and have to pick it up.

It gets really old, really fast.

This is part review, but mainly a way to express my thoughts about the game and how it has positively affected me. This isn't specifically meant to be read, more of a way to find my own voice and express myself.

I'm someone who tries to see the beauty in things when times are tough. When things get difficult, I try to at least see the best in it. I try to see the beauty in life, no matter how hard it gets. Even when things are at it's hardest, I try to get myself to see the best.

Recently, I have had a relapse of 'unpleasant thoughts', something I haven't had in a while. it started with a sudden intrusive thought, which almost led me to the end of things. Thought to be a one-off thing, I brushed it aside but those thoughts became more common. I suddenly started realizing that I was not in a good state of mind. Despite being communicative to my friends, I couldn't tell them this. I felt shameful, even partly detesting the idea of telling them. My voice felt caught in something, I didn't feel my own anymore nor that I had my own ideas or thoughts. I felt irrelevant, but couldn't help feel like I'm just cosmic dust then waiting to drift back into the world. I was losing grasp of my own reality, but in the midst of it all it reminded me of this game. Seeing that it went on sale recently, I turned to it and got a copy.

The game reflects the way I perceive concepts of tough times. It doesn't just dull out and become bleak. It's almost calming, colourful, serene. Almost eerily pleasant. It was a way to emotionally relax and stabilize, despite all the rough things. It felt right to play it, the beautiful animation and colour palettes. The soft to engaging music. Most importantly, the characters. The way each of them are written and have different ways to express themselves. The way they all have different stories of how they got here to their journey in the past-life, all leading to the Everdoor. It was beautiful.

Something I didn't expect was how hard the first character would go. I adored them upon introduction, and I loved the dynamic that was played. However, when I approached the Everdoor and was met with the dialogue and moment of their end, I couldn't help but break. Something inside me tore open, and all these repressed feelings poured out. I was open, most importantly to myself. There was a rush of so many conflicting thoughts, but it was something that needed to come out, something that needed to happen.

I can't help but thank this game for getting me to that point, a bravo to everyone who put this together. Though it can be hard to stick around, the beauty of this game captures the beauty of living life that I needed to see.

Thank you, Spiritfarer.

Ignore the playtime.  My old laptop was a potato.  I have it on PS4, I have it on Switch, and it's very likely my favorite game of all time.  I've played this game.  And apologies for the following wall of text.  tl;dr:  It's good.  Buy it.

Let's get into the basics:  Spiritfarer is, at its core, a game about service.  Where most management/life sims are about the accumulation of more and better and bigger, the general end result of all that effort is money.  You don't need to put your veggies in preserve jars in Stardew, but you have an entire basement filled wall to wall with preserve jars anyway, because you get more money that way.  Spiritfarer approaches things completely differently.  

You don't build the mill because flour is worth more money.  You build the mill because someone said their favorite food was a type of pie and it's the easiest way to get flour.  You don't feed your passengers because you're punished otherwise, you do it to make them happy.  You hug them, and listen to their troubles, and build them homes and places to work and play, because the point of the game is service.  There is no tangible benefit to doing something if it's not going to make one of your passengers happy.  You can stick to selling the valuables you find that are meant for selling.  You can even grow valuables in your garden, if you like.  But you will likely never feel any pressure to grind for money; rather, it serves more as a measure of time played for upgrade rollout purposes, and I completely forgot there was even a currency system near the end of my first playthrough.

Here's the bad:  This may sound like there's not a lot of things to do.  On the contrary, it's easy to get overwhelmed.  My typical day early game consists of waking up, watering all the plants and replanting, gathering food from the kitchen and setting the next meal in the oven, shearing the sheep, passing out food and hugs to all my passengers, realizing it's the late afternoon and I forgot to set a destination and have been sitting idle, plotting a course to my next destination only to veer into some rainfall so my plants will get watered overnight.  I didn't reach my destination.  I didn't move the story forward, or accomplish anything of note.  And it took a lot of effort to not accomplish these things.

In most life sims, this would absolutely drive me nuts.  But in Spiritfarer, I actually succeeded that day.  All my passengers were fed and happy.  Job done.  Some people may not like the lack of a tangible reward from this kind of gameplay loop, but generally the drive to see the passengers happy will keep the player moving forward.  The endgame can become something of a drag as a result though; for reasons that become apparent once you begin understanding the story, the later passengers just aren't as enjoyable as the early ones.  As a result, I found myself at the end having missed two spirits, neither of whom I liked in the least, and running across the map not really enjoying their company while I finished up my completionist needs.  The end of the game is beautiful; but the endgame, depending on who's left on your boat, can feel like a grind.

Now the good:  The music is beautiful.  The characters are well-written, with a surprising amount of depth behind the game's lore.  The progression path is simple, easy to understand, and sufficient to drive the player forward.  The emotional moments vary from neutral to profound.  One of these spirits will remind you of someone you've known and lost, and that spirit will break your heart.  The gameplay is solid, with a wide variety of things to do, places to explore, skills to unlock.  And due to the nature of the game, it will always have replay value so you can hang with your favorite spirits again.

And it's good hanging with them.  Interactions aren't in-depth, but you have just enough daily activities to deal with that you don't really find yourself wishing for more.  Sidequests are generally enjoyable, with a dry and simple tongue in cheek sense of humor that never feels inconsistent with the tone of the game.  There is no combat, and no failure condition, but that lack of stress over dying is made up for by the constant need for new materials, meals, ingredients, fish, ores, lumber, berries, spirit activities, and all the work that goes into service.

The game has co-op, and is Remote Play compatible.  One player will control Stella and can do everything that can be done in singleplayer.  The co-op partner will control Stella's cat, and can work the foundry, sawmill, kitchen, loom, etc.; but cannot advance the story or talk to NPC's.  It's an awkward experience for two people who are both new to the game, but an experienced Daffodil helping a first playthrough Stella can significantly reduce the amount of game time spent on things like lumber, planting, and smelting.  In a sense, Daffodil's player is simply adding onto the game's overall theme, providing yet another layer of service.

I want more games like this.  Games where being good consists of doing good.  Where the end goal is a better, happier world, achieved through something other than exploding the bad angry people.  Where we can be proud of being unproductive because it made our virtual friends happy, and where the generation of happiness in and of itself is the thing which makes us feel good.  This game is not perfect, but I will love it to the Everdoor and beyond.

[h1]A beautiful character-driven game that has a lot to say on the topic of life and death[/h1]
[b][u]Characters / Story[/u][/b]
First and foremost in this game are the characters / passengers that drive the story. As you are playing through, you get the [i]uncanny[/i] feeling that you know these passengers: All of the people aboard your ship will remind you of aspects (good or bad) of people you know in real life. They are fully fleshed out with deep backstories and unique personalities.

[b][u]Gameplay[/u][/b]
This game mixes elements of [u]Exploration[/u], [u]Platforming[/u], and [u]Farming Sims[/u]. There is no combat in this game and yet it is still fun to play (similar to the game Gris). There are also a bunch of mini-games that are actually kind of fun instead of obnoxious time drags. Everything has added audio cues which makes it easier for my ADHD to stay on task.

[b][u]Art[/u][/b]
The artstyle of this game is just plain beautiful with a lot of added polish. The colors are vibrant and alive. I love all the little animations thrown in here and there. You can tell that a lot of love and effort was put into making this.

[b][u]Music[/u][/b]
A very memorable soundtrack covering a wide range of emotions. From scaling a writhing sea dragon to serenading crops as they grow: Precious few albums sound as good as this.

[h1]Final Grade: [b]A+[/b][/h1]

This Game saved my life

I am 55.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiralling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

I was playing this game and really fell in love with it. I loved the concept, art style and animation and the management system (though it can be a bit tedious at times). 

However, after a week of playing and saying goodbye to animal spirit friends, my best friend/dog died. I took it pretty hard as anyone would. I didn't know what to do; all I knew was to distract myself. I continued to play this game, but it took on a much different tone. I never got to say goodbye to my dog. And even though Robocop visited me in my dreams, I never got the real closure. He didn't die of old age, so it was unexpected and awful for me to handle. But the game's tone shifted and I was suddenly caring about every character. I was bawling my eyes out with every departure. 

This game really did give me a relief, a form of acceptance of his early departure. Thanks devs for such a great game. I am sure it was meant to teach a bigger lesson with human souls and themes of death, but he really was my best friend. 

Thanks for the fine game.

I will warn people that this game deals with some heavy topics, mostly death. But I'll say it's done in a very charming and not at all graphic way. It's all through dialogue and some vague pictures of people during their life before getting to the end.

Anyway, prepare to cry, but not in a depressing way, if you pick this game up.

You may ask why? And the answer to that is. I don't know. I finished the game, i attempted most if not all of the achievements, i spent hours gathering resources and feeding sheep and passengers and farming and. I think at some point i realised it just felt like. a checklist. of sorts. at the end after I had all the buildings that let me make whatever I wanted and I had access to every location, I had cooked every meal, caught every fish, all the requests took minutes. Jackie boarded my boat and left the next day. I don't know. I just don't know why I didn't love it. I think i thought I would be heartbroken, seeing these characters I was meeting "die". The only time I shed a tear was Atul's parting, and I suspect that that was because he broke out of the formula. The checklist. It affected me because of its abruptness. Spiritfarer has become one of my favorite recent games, and I say that as someone who's not usually into this genre. Stuff like Minecraft or Terraria makes me feel overwhelmed with how many recipes and options there are, combined with very little guidance. Spiritfarer feels much more welcoming in its resource management style.

NPCs will help you figure everything out as part of the game's story and there are no penalties for taking your time with anything. Spiritfarer wants you to be able to take in the game at your own pace.

That relaxing game play is contrasted nicely with a story that is often emotional and giving you food for thought about life's big questions. You'll get to know a variety of quirky passengers who board your ship, some fun, some a little more abrasive. But the thing they all have in common is you are tasked with helping them come to peace with passing over to the afterlife. It leads to moments that can be heartbreaking as you have to grapple with how to say goodbye to characters whose time has come.

The beauty of Spiritfarer is that beneath its bright, charming aesthetic is that it has emotional depth. It'll make you contemplate the significance of life and how to carry on despite the grief of losing people you care about. It's a thought-provoking, satisfying experience.

Like many management style games, it does have a lot of repetition in the tasks you need to do, so your mileage will vary for how fun you find that. But especially now that the game has been upgraded to the Farewell Edition, I found the experience entertaining as a nice stress-free management game combined with some platformer elements. You'll probably get between 30 and 40 hours out of a playthrough.

Definitely one I'll be replaying again in the future!

Sometimes the tone changes are jarring, but a whole lot of the time, they hit you squarely in the gut. Not quite Disco Elysium level gut checks, but it's a modern game that handles a ton of themes with incredible empathy, touch, and humor. Highly recommend. I see why Yahtzee from The Escapist lumps this with Obra Dinn and Undertale as indie gems of the last good while. It's special.

[b]Minor pet peeves:[/b]

[b]A personal note:[/b] When playing this game, I was coincidentally doing counselling for building my resilience to overwhelming emotions. This game allowed me to practice sitting with grief, over and over again. It was intense, but I wish I had a game like this when I was younger to become more familiar with this type of loss.

TL;DR: Love a lot of what's here, but the gameplay loop and characters are really unsatisfying.

There’s a lot that I do really like about this game like the art, character design, music, and movement controls, but it’s just not enough to keep me going.

A huge focus on the game seems to be the characters you bring onto your boat to progress, but they’re all a part of this weird kind of gameplay loop. You bring them in, do them some favors, get some snippets of their lore with no context, and then after all that they’re just like “aight im done lol bye”. I don’t feel like I’m given enough to really connect with these characters before they decide to leave. The game only gives me the option to talk to them when they give me more chores to do in order to get to the next part of their specific story. I’ve had Gwen and Summer on my boat for what I’m guessing was like 4-6 hours each, but I didn’t really feel anything when I took them to move on. I mostly just gave them food and hugs while I worked on getting the things they needed.

It doesn’t help that the rest of the game feels like a lot of going back and forth between the same islands looking for new materials and never really knowing exactly where to go. I want to explore and find new spirits to bring aboard. But it turns out by the time I find one, I end up needing something that I don’t get till way later. And I only find this out after going all across the ocean looking for it. It’s not so bad early on, but after a certain point it gets pretty tedious. For a specific example, here’s a single quest I need to do for Atul’s story: 

I need to get him some fried chicken to progress his story, so of course I need chicken and fat to make it. Turns out chicken is unavailable until I get the icebreaker, so I go to the shipyard to see if I can make it. Apparently one of my shipmates needs to pass on so I can get their Spirit Flower, so I need to wait until Gwen’s ready to go. Meanwhile, Atul’s just asking me “Hey where’s my chicken?”, and it's basically one of the only things I hear from him the entire time. I can’t talk to him about anything else, just feed him and hug him. So now Gwen decides to go to spirit heaven and I got the flower I need for the icebreaker. Great. Get the icebreaker, go to Nordweiler, get the chicken, step one done. But where’s the fat? Turns out I need another two specific spirits to come aboard in order to get the building I need to make the fat and Atul’s still nudging me about getting his chicken. But now I have this owl guy who wants me to get a certain ship upgrade that requires another material that requires more specific material and after a certain point of trawling the whole ocean filled with apathy I’m just about ready to let this frog starve.

From my experience, the characters have some traits I can pick up on, but I’m just not given enough to really get attached to them. Yes being able to hug all these animal people is cute, but talking to them and being given the option to learn more about them before I send them off seems pretty important too. It also makes the final hug you give them as a send off much less impactful because you’re encouraged to hug them every single day. It’s a small thing, but I feel like it means at least a little bit. I may have gotten a bit off track, but I’ll try and summarize it like this. During my hunts for materials, I’d much rather be talking to the people I feel I’m supposed to be attached to and not just hugging and feeding them. It’s like a Tamagotchi with extra steps.

I’m willing to admit that as far as the characters go there might just be something I’m missing, but it’s not helped by the gameplay loop of find someone, get new chores, scour the ocean for a specific set of items, get given some backstory I hardly understand, repeat 3 times, then say goodbye. I really do want to like this game, but I think at its core it’s just not for me.

In Short: Not only is this game MEGA POG, it is also CRY TIME.
The art style and music are lovely and fun to look at and listen to. The mechanics are easy to grasp and the stories that you get to experience and see are amazing and sad.
A beautiful experience that sucks you in with wonderful art, music and character. A truly charming experience and I cannot wait to delve further into what it has to offer.

The fun and colourful characters, and beautifully written narrative is what makes this game super unique and an overall great game. The whole game at its core is a cozy management game about dying, but there is so much more to it, with each character finding their purpose and understanding parts of their lives.

The design in this game is beautifully detailed and everything is completely cohesive throughout. From the animations, to the soundtrack, to the character design everything immerses you.

Death is a topic that many people find difficult to talk about, which is why Spiritfarer has a good way of doing so, it shows that time doesn't wait for you to make amends or make the decision about understanding your story and who you are. Death comes without warning and can be sudden or prolonged, which is seen throughout each of the characters. There are some characters which you will lose, who have finished everything and characters who haven't. Spiritfarer also teaches you how to let go, and as someone who has found it difficult to let go (in both the game and in life), it has made it a little easier somehow.

An overall beautiful experience. I cannot recommend this game enough!

"You've never been alone. You will never be alone."

Such an uplifting, unpretentious, peaceful game! Very deep. Thought-provoking. Heart-warming.

GAMEPLAY is intuitive. Pretty straightforward. From the very beginning, no need to check control menu. It's getting easier and easier to keep up with events, quests, discoveries etc.

MOTIVATION
There's always something to do. I set my own pace. And that's the beauty of it.

CREDIBILITY
Authentic protagonists and a credible interaction structure. Actions & reactions of characters seem non-generic, i.e. quite appropriate and understandable from a realistic point of view, albeit not too predictable. I get to know the personalities and i gotta say, i get to love 'em. How I interact with the crew members is just like family. Acknowledging different parts within me, I find a profound sub-message within each character, thus being able to identify with those i take care of during the journey at sea while taking care of those parts within me during the samsaric journey we all participate in.

STORY
There is an intricate, almost intrinsic reward system at play. And that's what I appreciate about it so much. The self-paced story line makes it clear that it is truly about the journey, not the destination. Whatever I do, it is up to me when i do it. Which brings me to the final point and, for the time being, my conclusion of this review.

P(E)ACE
Starting out, I caught myself rushing into the doer-maker-achiever-mode. Since then, I've been slowing down somewhat since i came to realize that the crew members come up with their ideas at the appropriate moment anyway. So no need to hurry and worry. What a relief, especially for those of us who, when entrusted with the task of taking care of lost souls, succumb to the helper syndrome time and again ;)

Spiritfarer is incredibly beautiful and that's what I'll remember the most. Art, music and animations resonate with the themes of the game: sprites are drawn out carefully, with relaxing colors and lines, and the slow animations set up a very therapeutic mood. Often I would stop moving and remain idle just to enjoy the neat animations of Stella and her cat knocking around.
As in all management games, I think the key is making all repeatable actions enjoyable, and they mastered that in Spiritfarer. Small, short actions that you will have to perform a thousand times, such as fishing our taking vegetables out of the ground, simply sound and look so good. The game is undoubtedly grindy, which might be an issue for many; even when the endgame approaches you still get new buildings to work in and new tiers of items to process, maybe unnecessarily. In any case, moving around with your boat (and specially customising it! it was surprisingly entertaining to rearrange all houses and buildings a la Townscaper) feels relaxing until the end.
I won't cover much of the plot here, but it does have room for subverting expectations. Soon you get to know the game loop of meeting cute animal spirits, taking care of them and eventually releasing them to the Everdoor; but, as the story unrolls and the world widens, characters start deviating from that process. Some might not be as adorable as you'd expect or demand you to tend for them in different ways. This has a big impact in the player and ensures the spiritfaring process remains fresh until the end.
